text: I do have a problem with the public transport part. It's like saying that we can all(7billion of us) technically fit inside L.A.; and humans are selfish for not just doing so. Sure, you're right; but theres a lot that you're missing in regards to personal freedom and stuff like that. Humans wont just simply stop driving cars, and switch to very dirty, very uncomfortable massive boxes on tracks, it's very unrealistic. The best thing we can do is at least make sure our cars are clean(and maybe that we start mining for batteries somewhere else that doesnt hurt the planet. Right now, gas cars currently burn twice as much fuel than they actually need to run(1 for the tank itself, and 1 for charging the batteries). Hybrid cars burn 1.5x, and electric cars burn about 1x(to charge the batteries(tho this doesnt mean they're not burning unnecessary fuel)). Electric cars wont solve the problem, they are just a stepping stone to help us solve the problem. We need to completely move towards electric vehicles, and then we need to move towards renewable energy. Nuclear power is great for this. Also, a good, but more futuristic alternative is to launch satellites that gather energy from the sun and beam it back to earth(the Star Raker was a good program that would have made this very possible in the 70s and 80s, but was ultimately cancelled). Even that won't be enough tho. If you want to make public transport more viable, we need to completely change how we look at public entirely. No longer shall we look at it as a poor man's way of getting around town. We need to look at it like a fun place to hang out. A good social gathering if you will. Make it fun! However, have plenty of spaces for peace and quite as well. We need to make it all electric and full self driving as well! Whatever we do, we need to use our imagination. Take it one step at a time. Each and every victory we make against climate change will reward us with a bit more time to make bigger and bigger moves. We'll only be prolonging the inevitable in the moment, but maybe we can prolong the inevitable enough to make one more victory each and every time, until maybe in the long run we'll actually have won enough battles to turn the tides of war. Also, we need to HEAVILY invest in that technology of removing carbon from the atmosphere. I know it seems impossible now, but keep in mind, it's just a concept; but it is hope. We need to hold on to that hope and advance that technology as much as possible. Even if we cant remove much, we need to keep investing in it and remove as much as possible. Maybe find a way to make use of the carbon without releasing it again into the atmosphere, whatever; just try and make it fun and worth it, then more and more people will start using it. Whatever happens, remember, these are just guidlines, and I know nothing, so dont take this too seriously, but we CANT give up. Please dont give up. You'll only seal our fate. We need to keep fighting, its the only thing we have left. I know it sounds cliche, but please, Dont lose hope now. Its all we got.

text:
This video doesn't make sense though...
If there's a feedback loop between CO2 and climate, then how would CO2 levels ever drop?? 
If more CO2 -> less CO2 removal -> MORE CO2 -> LESS CO2 REMOVAL -> etc, then by that logic Earth would've been slowly but inevitable torched to crisp back 400 million years ago when the CO2 levels were 4000 ppmv - 10 TIMES MORE THAN TODAY!! 

Or maybe it's all bullshit?
author: Zacharie Etienne

text:
I should mention I received a reply from Simon Clark himself on another comment thread here. Since he's the go to man, figured I should repost his reply and mine for honesty's sake.

Simon Clark
Because it's not that simple - there are both positive and negative feedback loops. For example more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more photosynthesis from plants -> less CO2. But then at the same time more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more water vapour absorbing thermal wavelengths of radiation -> warmer planet. There are feedback loops all over the place, hence the need for complicated models!

Zacharie Etienne
Holy shit a reply from the man himself!!
If there are both positive and negative feedback loops - that only means they would either cancel each other out, or they average out into one positive feedback loop, or a negative one. 
If it's positive or negative, the Earth would've been screwed from the get go regardless of humans.
Therefore, when there's no human input, the Earth's CO2 levels must be self correcting , i.e. when CO2 levels are too high, the negative feedback loops have more punch, and when CO2 is too low, the positive feedback loops win over. Only this scenario would create an equilibrium allowing CO2 levels to remain stable over time, any other scenario would have CO2 levels spiral exponentially to either 0 or infinity due to effects of chaos.

And if that's the case, then while an additional human input of CO2 will produce a temporary rise in temperature, eventually we will again find a natural equilibrium, because although we've increased the CO2 levels, because we've done that, the net negative feedback loops will become more pronounced, while the net positive feedback loops will diminish, and (as long as human CO2 input is constant), they'll be a point where the loops once again reach equilibrium.

I can make an analogy with air resistance vs gravity. As you know, falling objects have air resistance, and the faster the velocity, the more air resistance. Therefore this is an example of a negative feedback loop, because if a falling object momentarily goes faster than the terminal velocity where air resistance and gravity are in equilibrium, then the object slows back down to terminal velocity. Likewise, if the object momentarily goes slower than the terminal velocity, gravity win over the air resistance, creating a positive feedback loop, and making the object speed back to terminal velocity. Any other universe where the object didn't have a positive feedback loop when going to slow AND a negative feedback loop when going to fast, would inevitably result in the object either coming to a complete stop or speeding up indefinitely. 

Now in this analogy, human input of CO2 is equivalent to reducing the object's surface area. By doing so, you'll have decreased the force of air resistance, making the object fall faster/have a higher terminal velocity. But the same positive/negative feedback loops apply, so although the object will temporarily fall faster, it will inevitably reach a new terminal velocity again, where the feedback loops cancel out and it's all ok.

text: On longer timescales (hundreds or thousands of years), CO2 is removed from the atmosphere by silicate weathering. As the climate gets warmer, rainfall increases and so does erosion and weathering. This acts as a negative feedback, although on a significantly longer timescale than humans are emitting CO2. Thus if anthropogenic CO2 emissions stopped now and never resumed, processes like silicate weathering would, over many hundreds of years, draw CO2 out of the atmosphere. I have heard it theorised that without anthropogenic emissions, this process would aid in transitioning towards another ice age, but with human emissions, the next ice age has likely been delayed for thousands of years. Eventually, human CO2 emissions must slow down and cease, even assuming we survive the next 1000 years, because fossil fuels are finite in quantity, and once they are gone, we have to move on to renewable (and low carbon) energy sources.

text: The production of meat's impact on the environment is based on highly contingent models. And in fact, pasture lands are a carbon sink and crop land is not (in fact quite the opposite). And not all land suitable for pasture is suitable for crops (or at least not without fertilizer and irrigation). Beef methane emissions apparently can be mitigated by changes to their diet. by And more to point, plant calories are not equivalent nutritionally to animal products, neither in density or quality. And if you eat a diet that does not contain carbohydrates (which are entirely sourced from plants, i.e., grain) there is a typical spontaneous calories reduction of about %15 (i.e., people eating carbs typically overeat due to the biochemistry of insulin). This issue is not straightforward.   Also, not all meat has the same carbon footprint by a long shot. There is a tendency to believe that not eating meat is healthier for the body and the planet, but it is not an obvious conclusion in either case.

text: Zacharie Etienne.  You seem to want to reduce this to a simple +1 or -1 equation, but it doesn't work that way. Equilibrium is by definition a dynamic process, like filling a lake at one end with several creeks and draining it out the other end with a river. The level of the lake can stay constant even with different forces acting on it (like the terminal velocity in your analogy, but that only has two forces that constant or heavily bounded in our world). Even small changes will change the equilibrium level, and big changes like a dam or a drought can have massive, irreversible impacts. To suggest that with this simple model the world would either be frozen (lets say zero CO2 in your analogy) or baking hot (infinity CO2 in your analogy, which doesn't make physical sense at all btw) is reduction to the absurd. The bottom line is that the world is quite different than at points in the distant path, how we got from there to here was natural feedback mechanisms over millions and billions of years, but humans have made measurable changes over a very very short period of time. If we change the temperature by even a few degrees, it can have a huge impact on the oceans, jet stream, water cycle, sea level etc. that the planet would survive and adapt to, but humans would struggle to adapt to. Just imagine the number of people who live in poverty and within 5 miles of the ocean or 50 feet from sea level. If they start being displaced, what impact will that have on humanity? How will we keep ourselves healthy and safe even if we are not affected? (which we will be because the food system will be disrupted by climate, disease and desertification).

text:
+lalílulelo
Actually, meat consumption is kind of baked into the second of those two things you mentioned.
Basically when you eat meat you are contributing to increased transportation as first machines are used to produce the plants that the animal you eat had to eat itself.
Then other machines transport that plant material to a factory that produce animal fodder.
Then that is transported to the farm.
Then the animal is transported from the farm to the slaughter house.
Then the meat is transported from the slaughter house to the factory actually producing the food you're eating, this might in some cases involve several factories and several stages.
Then the finished product is transported from the factory to the supplier of your grocery store.
Then that is transported to the actual grocery store.
Add to  that the use of energy at every step of this process...

Meat also closer to us in content so bacterias and fungus that can make meat go bad are also more likely to make us get sick meaning that keeping the meat cold etc is more important then a plant, while half-bad plants are still eatable by humans, in other words energy consumption for meat preservation is also higher, and the stricter rules for when meat has to be removed from the shelf means that tons of it are removed and transported to be disposed as waste all the time.
Not exactly reducing the enviromental impact...

author: Luredreier

text:
+John Hall
Climate change is a result of global warming.
Global warming is still a thing, it's just not used in day to day usage because people can get the erronous impression that global warming means that any one location is going to get warmer when infact it might get *colder*.
For instance the increased heating of the planet as a whole is causing ice to melt on the north pole.
That in turn reduces the effect driving the gulf stream that is transporting heat from the gulf of mexico to northwestern Europe.
That in turn means that long term global warming might make large parts of Europe colder due to less heat being moved there from the gulf of Mexico.
Similar effects are found all over the place.
Weather is a complex thing after all.
But the fundamental cause is still that balance of energy comming into and leaving the Earth system has shifted in the direction of more staying here, aka global warming.
author: Luredreier

text:
+claytonsmoking
There are also other approaches.
The planting of trees seems to have quite a possitive effect plenty of places without the negative side effects on the enviroment as the trees actually increase the absorption of CO2 instead of increase its emissions like the animals do.
And the dung in question, sure it might help plants grow, but it also contributes even more to climate change prior to becomming usable by the plants.
Don't get me wrong, in some cases meat is the lesser evil form the point of view of the enviroment.
Production of vegan food is more difficult in some parts of the world then others and sometimes local meat consumption is preferable to shipping in vegan food from far away.
After all, there's exceptions to pretty much every rule.
author: Luredreier

text:
+Garry Mcgrath
Sure, but the amount of food you have to transport to feed an animal through its lifetime till it is ready for human consumption far outweigh the amount of food you have to transport to feed a human.
Basically to get 1 kg of meat you need multiple kg of plants as fodder, how much depends a bit on the species, race, the plant type used as fodder, when you slaughter the animal etc, etc, etc.
But it can get as high as 10 kg of plants for 1 kg of meat in some cases.
To give a human the equvialent amount of nutrients as that 1 kg of meat requires far less plants then what you'd have to feed that animal in the first place.
As a result there is a lot of savings in transportation of said plants directly to humans instead of sending it via an animal first.

text: 400 million years ago free-sporing vascular plants evolved (small plants and later, trees). As there were not yet any animals evolved to eat such plants, eventually all the land on Earth was covered in trees. These trees sucked up carbon dioxide, died and become buried, essentially carbon capture. After tens of millions of years of this, the carbon dioxide levels became low enough to cause global cooling. Those buried trees eventually became oil, which we've dug up and burned, causing this video to exist.

text: Old Frugal One Hyper-Drive Movement You misunderstand. CO2 creates a positive feedback loop which leads to more warming. You are correct in that CO2 increases lag behind patterns of global warming in the past, but that isn't the full picture. CO2 itself DOES cause warming by reducing the efficiency in which Earth is able to radiate heat. Basically, as you may have heard before, it creates a sort of "blanket" in the atmosphere that traps the Sun's heat. And we're pumping metric tons of it into the atmosphere every day. That lag you've seen in previous records is due to CO2 in glaciers and the ground being released into the atmosphere over time, but that CO2 does lead to more warming due to it's "blanket" property of trapping heat. And those old records do not take into account all of the new CO2 our modern society is emitting into the atmosphere, which adds to the warming effect.

text: Lots of people have told you some great reasons but one more thing to consider is feed. In the US most feed for cows and pigs and chicken is primarily corn based. Think about a field of corn, one field of corn takes a LOT of space and a lot of water (costs money and electricity ie CO2 to move it around) and a lot of farming equipment (burning gas) and chemicals (pesticides and fertilizers that disrupt already weakened ecosystems). So we have this huge carbon investment where we're making all this food for livestock. The problem is that livestock have generally a 10:1 ratio for weight of food in vs weight of food out. In essence every 10 kilograms of corn you feed a cow you get one kilogram of steak. Think about how wasteful that is, 1 kilogram of steak is roughly 2000 Kcal of food, so like one day but 10kilos of corn is nearly 10,000 Kcal of energy or 5 days of food (roughly). In addition storing and preserving plant based food is much easier and less prone to food safety problems making it easier to grow food in one area and then distribute it around the world. To move a steak from texas to NYC you need refrigerated trucks and food safety inspectors. To move dried or canned corn to NYC you can put it in an un-climate controlled truck and as long as it doesn't get wet keeps for like 2 years.

You know what the concentration of that is? 25 ppb. 25 parts per BILLION is enough for people to be getting sick and put at increased risk of cancer. Methane is measured in ppb and co2 is measured in ppm and they are having real effects of the changing of the climate.

text:
A D Well, raising farm animals like cows is incredibly resource intensive, so it takes up a lot of water and space. With so many cows, you also get a lot of cow dung, farts, etc, all of which have methane. I'm fuzzy on this, but from what I remember methane has a higher greenhouse effect on large numbers than other gases. This would be bad already, but it gets worse because the more methane is released into the environment, the warner it gets, and that melts permafrost in areas like Siberia, which of course have massive stores of methane. It's too late because...it's already starting to melt. So technically, not eating meat would reduce the demand for livestock and ultimately reduce the methane they produce. But that's a bit unrealistic to ask of people in certain areas. With lab-grown meat, however, you wouldn't need to stop eating meat, and could probably by a cut of meat made a certain way (more fat, or higher density). 

Long story short, meat animals release harmful gases, so not eating meat over time will reduce the need for them, so people will raise less of them and less of those gases will be released. Or we should switch to lab-grown meat.

text:
The climate has always been (and is still) changing, all the time.  Mostly effected by the sun, but to a much smaller extent, the increase in cities/populations can and do have some affect.  Steel, stone, concrete and asphalt used in construction for buildings, roads, and other construction, retain heat from the sun’s energy during the day and dissipate that heat during the cooler hours.  

While attending the University of Arizona, during the early 1970’s, many “climatologists, meteorologists, scientists and other weather ‘experts’” were hysterically protesting and demonstrating (while professing) that we were entering another ICE-AGE.  We obviously were not entering an ice-age then, and are not suffering “global warming” now.  These are political hoaxes to attempt to separate your money from your wallet.

Former Vice President Al Gore predicted that within ten years the oceans would rise about twenty feet.  That was ten years ago and so far they have not risen even inch.  Nothing, no, Nada not even a mili-meter!

Let us use some common sense:

Fact 1:  Humans can not change (or make) the weather, we cannot even accurately predict it much less change it. Maybe we can seed a cloud here or there, but we can not stop or change the direction of a tornado or a hurricane or even a thunder storm or cold front or any other weather phenomenon.

Fact 2:  The air we breath (the Earth’s atmosphere) is made-up of about 77% Nitrogen, 22% Oxygen, and less than 1% argon.  That leaves LESS than 1% of ALL OTHER GASSES and airborne materials (such as water vapor, dust, etc).  Carbon Dioxide makes up less than 2/100’s of one percent of Earth’s atmosphere.  Like spitting into the ocean, not enough to make ANY difference no matter how many times we spit.

Fact 3:  Global warming “experts” say that animal (primarily cow) flatulence (FARTS) help to increase the threat of global warming.  Cow flatulence are NOT Carbon Dioxide.  Like most animal flatulence, that gas is a methane gas NOT C02.

text: @Zacharie Etienne  fair question. It boils down to the fact that the feedback is non-linear. Eventually, the amount of heat radiated out to space will equal to the amount of heat received, and the temperature will stabilize. If the feedback was linear (meaning only positive, and always increasing proportionally), then the temperature would go to infinity. But in reality it's not linear, nothing is. Eventually the strength of the feedback is diminishing and the temperature stabilizes, albeit at a much higher level, than without feedback.

text:
@Zacharie Etienne  - Very well argued.  Yes, shifting equilibrium points are what happens all the tie, or else, we'd be Venus (which was likely caused by catastrophic volcanism, not gradual greenhouse gas heat buildup).  Also see Monckton where he points out that humans have been basing their CO2 warming models based on the wrong temperature term.  As more CO2 is added it causes additional heating (it's a greenhouse gas) which causes additional water vapour to go into the atmosphere which then causes additional heating (the water vapour feedback).  Well guess what?  It turns out that (dumb as it may seem in hindsight - but perhaps an error not so easy to spot initially) that the temperature term the modellers were using wasn't the actual temperature of the atmosphere, but an additional warming temperature term due  to the presence of greenhouse gases.  Meaning that instead of reasoning something like - due to CO2 in the atmosphere the temperature has increased from 270 Kelvin to 300 Kelvin causing increased water vapour to go into the atmosphere, which the - INSTEAD, according to Monckton, they've been arguing (without realizing it) something more like THIS - due to CO2 in the atmosphere we now have a temperature of 30 Kelvin which is causing additional warming due to additional water vapour.  See/  They're attributing ALL the additional water vapour feedback to the extra 30 Kelvin of temperature, but NO FEEDBACK from the already existing 270 Kelvin of temperature due to the sun shining!  When that is done, the predicted water vapour feedback which loops into everything else is massively exaggerated, causing the models to all predict catastrophic warming (which we haven't seen and won't see).  In summary while there is a tiny amount of warming due to additional CO2 being put into the air by humans, it's not much warming, and therefore is nothing to destroy economies and lives over.  And certainly no reason to avoid eating meat!  In fact it's likely all political in nature, as the arguments to try and curb climate change dovetail precisely with the aims of those who wish to rule the planet and regulate it with an iron fist of control over your life.  THAT NEEDS TO BE AVOIDED AT ALL COSTS.  See:  
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cZhcnRe3qd8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P-H_sf4WCtA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dj43O98HL5c
author: tubewatch59

text:
​ @DMart  
Somehow I'm here reading this a year later. Better late than never lol.
Ok there are 2 halves to your comment. I'll start with the 2nd half first, that the small changes now will have devastating impacts on the environment, which us humans will struggle to adapt to.
I don't agree or disagree with this. I have no idea what the impact of climate change will be on us. Take your example of the poor being displaced by rising sea levels, what will happen? Will they become more poor? Will they all die? Will they all turn to anarchy and start attacking the rich? Definite possibilities, but I don't know. And yes the impact on humans could be our extinction or worse.
But that wasn't my point. I was talking about negative/positive feedback loops. I'm saying that no matter how much CO2 we contribute, as long as it is a constant amount, there must be an equilibrium point where it is stable, where CO2 doesn't grow or shrink. 
In other words, sure, seas and temperature will rise, natural disasters will get worse, but not forever. There will hit a point where the temperature cannot increase further. Maybe after +1° C, maybe 10° C, maybe 100° C. 

Now to the 1st point half of your comment. There's a difference between the equilibrium level of CO2, and the actual level of CO2. Equilibrium level of CO2 means the level of CO2 which is stable under all planetary forces (including human). A severe drought could cause there to be a temporary spike in CO2, but over the long time the drought fades away, CO2 would go back to the equilibrium which hasn't changed. And after the severe drought(s) you would get more humidity-heavy events like rain and floods, because there is an equilibrium for water as well. The only way you would change the equilibrium for CO2 with droughts is if the planet was on average in a constant state of drought, which defies the definition of being in drought.

text:
@ranter7100  
That's a fair point, but it doesn't change my original point, only makes it less relevant. Humans reducing the number of trees on Earth does raise the CO2 equilibrium point, the same way humans contributing more and more pollution (actual CO2), raises the CO2 equilibrium point. But eventually there comes a point where humans won't produce more pollution, in fact this will happen as a sudden drop when we run out of fossil fuels. Likewise there is an equilibrium point where humans won't cut down more trees than we grow, which would could be the point where there are so few trees that they're as expensive as gold for example.
Remember, my point is that no matter how bad it gets, it must stabilise. It can't simply get worse and worse out of control forever nothing we can do. But I'm not saying it's not going to get worse. It will. But it's always reversible.
As for your second point, see pascal's wager for that.

text:
@Zacharie Etienne  - "It's not just the sun that makes the natural 270 Kelvin of temperature, it's also the water vapour produced by the 270 Kelvin of temperature."  Monckton is saying they are not accounting for that 270 K (or whatever the no water vapour surface temperature would be) to be causing any water vapour to enter the atmosphere.  They seem to be assuming that initial temperature causes no water vapour to enter the atmosphere.  Why?  Probably because the math is a bit complex and if we've buried an error in there and for a long time no one has noticed it, it can be hard to uncover it.  The only thing that caused Monckton to suspect something was wrong was that the modles were predicting much more warming than what was being observed, causing Monckton and other scientists to look into it to see iof they could figure out why.


According to Monckton, any proper treatment of water vapour feedback estimations would first calculate the amount of water vapour feedback (the amount of water vapour able to be dissolved in the atmosphere without there being any other greenhouse gases present) due to what would be the total temperature if the atmosphere had no greenhouse gases (also meaning - no water vapour).  So assuming an atmosphere with just oxygen and nitrogen, you'd have a base temperature value (caused by the sunshine).  Then based on that temperature for a dry atmosphere, a certain amount of water vapour could enter the atmosphere, which would then increase the temperature somewhat, which would then increase the amount of water vapour a small amount more, etc. until an equilibrium temperature and amount of water vapour are reached.  THEN adding some CO2 greenhouse gas as well, would cause some further warming of the atmosphere, which would cause more water vapour to be dissolved in the atmosphere, so a little bit more warming would result, etc. until a new equilibrium amount of water vapour is present corresponding to the actual temperature we have, which is due to the warming caused by sunshine, CO2 and water vapour in the atmosphere.  So this means that the initial temperature causes some water vapour to enter the atmosphere.  And then adding some CO2 causes a little  more water vapour to enter the atmosphere.  Each of which increases the temperature a bit.

But according to Monckton this was not what was being done.  He says that only the CO2 greenhouse warming change in temperature value was being used (not 270 K but something like 30 K) to account for all the water vapour feedback, so all the water vapour feedback (increase in water vapour) was being attributed to this change in temperature value.  Meaning according to him that the 270 K was (in the equations they use) assumed not to cause any water vapour feedback!  So all the water vapour in the atmosphere is being generated (he says they assume - probably without realizing their error) by the change in temperature due to greenhouse CO2 in the atmosphere, not the total temperature.  

Meaning that whether they realized it or not, their calculations assumed the sunshine caused no water vapour to enter the atmosphere, but when the CO2 was added, then THAT greenhouse temperature increase due to CO2 alone, is assumed to account for all the water vapour entering the atmosphere.  But that's wrong because even with no CO2, the heat from the sun alone will cause water vapour to enter the atmosphere.  So he says they fouled up the water vapour feedback calculations!

The takeaway point is - when that mistake is made, the models will over-predict the amount of warming due to water vapour feedback because the models parameters are wrongly tuned, because they are using the wrong temperature term to calculate the amount of water vapour entering the atmosphere due to additional CO2 added.  

In summary he says that, for a doubling of CO2, instead of expecting to get from say 3.5K to 8K of additional warming, we are instead only going to get around 1K to 1.5K additional warming, which isn't a climate emergency (and may actually be beneficial).  But for a more precise explanation (from someone who knows a lot more about it than me!) watch the video links I provided in the other comment.

of course, other factors - such as a change in the solar output, or cloud cover, etc. could cause warming (or cooling) that is independent of the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere.

text:
@tubewatch59  
Oh ok I get what you're saying. That seems quite unbelievable to be honest. I have difficultly believing scientists make mistakes that you and me can see through without the science community exposing them first. One such complication that comes to mind is the fact that measuring the amount of water vapour isn't as straightforward as you'd think.
Most common scientific measurement for that is called relative humidity. That's the metric used for weather forecast for example. 50% relative humidity = 50% chance of rain tonight.
But what you're talking about sounds more like absolute humidity, which is a very different measurement. Absolute humidity is basically how much water vapour there is in the air by volume. But relative humidity? Idk wtf that shit is. It's like the pressure of water vapour compared to how much the atmosphere normally has or something? Weird.

Edit - Oh btw who is Monckton?

author: Maximus Asauluk

text:
@Zacharie Etienne  - Monckton is the fellow (a mathematician who has been looking into climate science in recent years) who has been giving talks on this.  I'd say here it's absolute humidity.  It would have to be.  Apparently the water vapour goes up a lot with increasing temperatures.

Unbelievable?  Maybe.  Don't forget I'm just repeating what Monckton pointed out.  I wouldn't have had a clue as to what he says was going on, but now he has pointed it out, it makes sense.  He says in one of his talks that they applied control theory (which involves feedback effects) but didn't apply it correctly.  That's pretty plausible, after all one of the touted benefits of science is that it is self correcting, and sure enough, along comes Monckton to point out an error, eventually.  But I can absolutely understand how an error could slip through at first.  Especially when scientists go outside of their field of expertise.  I remember when I was in university and in lab. experiments, we'd be reading about work we had never studied before, all these results and equations we were told to use in the experiment, and to be honest, most of the time I had no idea how those equations were derived and sometimes didn't even know what they meant, but you plug in the numbers and get results.  A certain amount of "faith in the work of others" comes into play, and if that work is complex, and if there isn't the time or interest, and especially if it seems to make sense after a while, there could be mistakes in there and you'd just never know it.  It takes someone competent and with the motivation to really dig into the work and check it all out.  Remember that science can be very wrong on a subject for a long time before errors and flaws are realized.  And sometimes the  only reason things change in science when the disagreement isn't so cut and dried as an error in an equation, is because the old guard with a vested interest in that way of doing things, dies out!  Also, given the current political push to "fix the climate" I dare say that even if a scientist with vested interests did spot such an error, he may not be inclined to point it out.  After all, if you believe it, the choice is - keep on helping to save the planet, or point out an error which may help "the enemy" who is likely "working for oil companies" etc.  See what I mean?  There are a lot of factors at play here.  Monckton happily points out the error because he has long suspected some of the supposedly settled science here, is bogus.  look up Monckton on youtube and look for the videos time filtered withing the last few months.  I gave you some links in the first comment I made, at the end.

@Simon Clark  It seems you can reduce CO2 emissions without reducing consumption, by eating beef cattle as veal could reduce the carbon footprint on these herds by up to 40%.
The 2019 Australian Beef Sustainability Annual Update shows that the red meat industry reduced absolute emissions by almost 56 per cent from 2005-2016.
https://www.sustainableaustralianbeef.com.au/annual-update
See how a UK Salers herd aims to be carbon neutral by 2035
https://www.fwi.co.uk/livestock/beef/how-a-salers-herd-aims-to-become-carbon-neutral-by-2035?name=how-a-salers-herd-aims-to-become-carbon-neutral-by-2035&category_name=livestock%2Fbeef
According to Red Meat Advisory Council, Australia aims for it's beef to be fully carbon-neutral by 2030.
https://www.sustainableaustralianbeef.com.au/managing-climate-change-risk
https://www.sbs.com.au/food/article/2019/08/05/carbon-neutral-beef-it-guilt-free-steak-environmentally-aware
This newspaper article explains "The use of mob-grazing methods produces "healthier grassland, cattle grazed on rotation are said to increase the soil’s capacity to store carbon"... and can even reverse C02 emissions.
https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/cows-beef-farming-reverse-climate-change-global-warming-a8202121.html
Also it seems there is no increase in the number of ruminants on the planet, the number is roughly the same as 300 years ago when massive herds of bison roamed the earth (and methane emitting non ruminate elephants) . Satellite data does not show any evidence of high emissions of methane over Brazil and Ethiopia caused by the large cattle herds there. Are cows changing the climate?  This presentation by the Global Warming Policy Forum concludes not. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GJ1LImHvdxw
See website of Cows Milk and Climate. Clarifications by Professor Dr Peer Ederer
https://www.milkandclimate.com/
Background:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f9cwa9QD7gw

text: @Wolfgang Ricky  I don’t eat meat, but the methane comes from the atmosphere already —it’s created in the cow’s gut. It’s already part of the carbon cycle, and the cow gets it from sequestered carbon in the grass/food it eats. Then it farts it out, returning it to the atmosphere, where turns back into CO2 after 12 years (hydroxyl oxidation) and gets absorbed into plants etc again.. so ultimately Methane doesn’t increase CO2.. but the 12 year process is a problem maybe
author: Tom

text: @Simon Clark   But aren’t dead oceans a bigger concern. Methane turns back into CO2 after 12 years by hydroxyl oxidation, essentially continuing the carbon cycle. Same with the water cycle — cows don’t subtract water but are part of the cycle just like all biology. But oceans create most our oxygen and they are dying..Shouldn’t this concern be at the top of the list?

Oe cannot remove CO2 below Mt.Everest air mixes too fast, and when emissions finally end, oceans outgas their excess CO2 to keep levels above 400ppm for >>120,000yrs. 

Our extinction 3.5ky-5ky away with BAU, unstoppably like any glacier on Earth ending below a rising sealevel cannot be stopped from quickly melting from below by warm oceans and altered jetstreams, check.

text:
I was looking into natural ways of capturing carbon and found that hemp captures more CO2 from the atmosphere and puts it into the soil than your typical plant.

Being a plant that grows quickly, can grow in a lot of different climates, and having so much use (clothing, textiles, paper), I think we could also start growing hemp again, though we'd literally have to cover the planet in hemp to quickly remove CO2 from the atmosphere. But it could be used in combination with other carbon capture tech to increase our carbon capture potential.

text:
People, the larger public, don't yet realize the level of change and inconvenience they will face to keep things not nearly as good as they are now.

What I mean is many people don't want to be forced to drive electric cars. What is really needed? no motorized personal transportation. It's not about the driving, it's about the manufacturing of giant effectively disposable vehicles, the mining, smelting, polymerizing of cracked hydrocarbons, and the million other energy intensive aspects of supporting our consumer driven economy. 

Food processor broke? buy a new one from Amazon. Seemingly more sustainable solution: fix it. Actual solution: learn to use your grandmothers old knife. We simply cannot reach sustainable CO2 levels that will allow long term survivability of human society if we continue to buy everything and have others manufacture it.

We won't change though. I've tried and will continue to try. I'm better, but the numbers clearly show not good enough. hopefully our kids and their kids are more clever than we are, and hopefully more forgiving too.

(Why so hopeless? Feedback loops. Not environmental feedback, economic. The more altered the climate becomes the more energy we need to spend to deal with it- building seawalls, running air conditioners in London,... and the fewer resources our governments will have to take meaningful large scale action.)

text:
Here are a few questions I'd like people watching the video to ask themselves:

1. Why would any scientist worth their salt publish their science on Reddit instead of a respected scientific journal?
2. Why does this video base it's whole argument (that extracting carbon from the atmosphere is expensive and hence nothing can be done to reverse climate change) on a single paper that isn't peer reviewed?
3. If we are to pretend the previous two questions are invalid: do you personally think that using 3% of the global GDP yearly is too much to save human civilization and countless of species from extinction?
4. And if you don't: what should we do with the "saved" money instead?

An additional point to be made is that if we were to spend this hypothetical figure of 3% on extracting carbon, then every single kg of reduction in pollution in the future brings this figure down. Speak about an incentive to reduce emissions...

text: I have an issue about the recommendation to “don’t eat meat.” Acknowledging the fact that humans in wealthy countries consume too much meat, it would be unwise to exclude meat from our diets completely. First, humans are omnivores and it is natural and healthy for them to eat meat and unnatural and unhealthy for them to exclude meat. This statement is backed up by numerous scientific studies. Second, if we do not raise livestock, what will consume all those weeds that these animals can digest (but we can’t) and turn into meat and diary products that we can consume? What will provide the fertilizer? If we don’t raise livestock, we will have to expend energy and produce emissions to remove all those weeds and clear more land for vegetables. We will have to use more petroleum-based chemical fertilizers as replacements for manure. Thus eliminating livestock and the benefits that they provide is very bad for the Earth. So I would revise the first recommendation to read as follows: do not eat meat or vegetables that has been produced using petrochemicals or unnatural industrial agricultural processes.

text:
That IS NOT what that word means.🙅🏾‍♂️

🔥🔥🔥  Here, since some of your trolls are inferior to the ones I'm use too . I will be periodically posting troll and disinformation manuals throughout the evening. Please step your game up , sheesh. 

Making outrageous comments designed to distract or frustrate. This is a Saul Alinsky-style tactic employed to stir emotion and angry reactions.


Dominating discussions. Trolls may attempt to throw a discussion off course and frustrate participants whose purpose is to engage in a serious and respectful exchange of views.

Posing as a conservative, liberal, etc and making comments that discredit the movement. After claiming to be a member of the movement, such as a tea party organization, the troll then proceeds to post long, incoherent diatribes to appear either racist or insane. In some cases, these “Trojan Horse Trolls” have been known to make posts that advocate or incite to the use of violence in an apparent attempt to provide evidence to critics and government sources that the organization is comprised of “radical extremists.”


Making false associations. In this technique, the position of honest posters is characterized in derogatory terms. For example, a troll may call advocates of Federal Reserve reform or abolition “conspiracy theorists” or “lunatics.” Or, by suggesting certain political arguments are “racist” or otherwise outside the accepted confines of serious political discourse, trolls attempt to dissuade readers from examining the evidence objectively.
Exhibiting false moderation. By pretending to be the “voice of reason” in an argument with obvious well-defined sides, trolls attempt to move readers to relegate the argument to a “gray area,” such that holding or seriously considering the argument is a leap away from reasoned judgment.
Raising straw-man arguments. Here a troll will accuse his opposition of subscribing to a certain point of view, even if the argument is irrelevant and never actually raised...   🔥🔥🔥

text:
If we do not start treating climate change as an existential threat to humanity itself (and honestly, we really are not), our political arguments in the latter part of this century will be about how quickly we will drive ourselves over the cliff of extinction as opposed to avoiding this catastrophe.  The problem is far too many people want to play on the cliff’s edge and far too few seem to realize that doing so is very precarious.

Witness discussion of the use of carbon tax revenues to fund things like reduction in income inequality. Indeed, if climate change is the existential threat that it is made out to be (and I have no reason to doubt that this is not the case), then we should care about NOTHING else other then solving it.  Ever single cent generated from a carbon tax WITHOUT EXCEPTION should be used SOLELY for either alternate fuels or technology designed to mitigate or reverse carbon in the atmosphere.  Politicians on the right need to embrace this tax and politicians on the left need to stop seeing this revenue as something they can redistribute to causes outside or addressing this issue.  If we are all going to go extinct if we do not do something NOW, well, that means that whether we spend $3 Trillion or $30 Trillion every year, it is worth it.

The mere fact that we have a climate scientist who actually argues that spending $3 Trillion a year is not something we can do speaks to the real problem here.  To reduce all of our consumption by 3% or even 30% and instead spend those resources on a mechanism to rid us of the excess carbon in the atmosphere is an exceptionally cheap bargain in comparison to our species’ extinction.  Yet the reality is we do not have to do ANY of these things because the world’s GDP rises by more than 3% a year already.

So I really want to know - if it is the threat to us that it is made out to be, why shouldn’t we agree to keep our current living standards the same every single year for the next 1,000 years (world GDP grows by a little more than 3% a year so we can theoretically maintain our current living standard but never increase it for a millennia if we decide to spend 3% of our world GDP on this carbon neutralizing technology)?  Isn’t our species’ survival worth such a small cost?

text: So, we need to start talking about how to survive and thrive at different levels of climate change, so we can prepare for what is coming. For instance we might want to build our houses differently so that they will provide more shade during the day and have white rooftops to reflect light to minimize the need for air conditioning and so on. You may want to have a separate water system in your house, so you can use stored rainwater for flushing and showering, so you don't use valuable drinking water for that. We might want to not have trimmed lawns that need frequent watering. We need to find out how to secure a stable food production and distribution and so on. We need to plant trees, not only to bind carbon, but also to provide shade for wildlife and to retain moisture in the soil. We need lots and lots of small local smart solutions that actually work and aren't pie in the sky. There is much hard work to be done.

text: (approximately) 6:00: This would make more sense to me if it were put in terms of totally excess tonnage of CO2 in the atmosphere, at the time  when carbon neutrality is reached. Talking about 32 GT every year is picturing a situation where carbon emissions continue unabated, and carbon capture is used to compensate for that. I happen to think that's a ridiculous picture, and one that is never going to happen. Carbon removal is never going to happen unless the World has already largely converted to renewable energy, and that energy is cheap. (I happen to think that time is not far off.) It wouldn't be hard to calculate this. I know I've already done it at least once, but don't have the results at hand. You take 1 bar of pressure, multiply by about 0.013 (give or take a bit according to personal taste) for the excess CO2 percentage, and multiply by Earth's surface area (land and water). The multiply again by about 2X, to account for CO2 coming out of the oceans as it depletes in air. Voila, you have your tonnage. What is it, about a trillion tonnes of carbon? Two trillion? I forget right now, but it's something like that. Say it's $100 a tonne, then it's maybe USD 100 trillion. But that's at present prices. From then, you talk about how much it can be reduced. I have a feeling a major reduction is possible, and in fairly short order, just by the magic worked by Wright's Law in so many things. But that's the discussion we should be having—not how to offset today's emissions por dios.
author: Ronald Garrison

text: I have to tell you, I'm already suspicious of these claims when I see CO2 compared to nuclear waste. First, any exposure to nuclear waste should be assumed to be bad, whereas CO2 is only harmful in excess—and not as a toxin, but in more complex ways. Second, nuclear waste radioactivity does not decline in a simple exponential fashion. It declines very rapidly in a few weeks, more slowly over a few hundred years, and more slowly still for tens of thousands of years. That long-term exposure is mainly from plutonium-239 and technetium, and is not equivalent to shoter-lived isotopes in a simple fashion.

text: It is "too late" to change the climate.  Better put it would be "stupid" to attempt this given the geo- and cosmic forces at play - just check out huge climate fluctuations in the last 300, 000 years (not ignoring - as "progressives" do - the Dansgaard-Oeschger cycles).  Yet, it is not "too late" to keep pushing forward with technology with two goals in mind: (a) don't cause more damage than we have already done; (b) be technologically (this includes agriculture) prepared for climate fluctuations that we can't possibly control, and that will be larger than even today's doomsdayers predict (1-3 degrees is nothing).  Any impartial observer would conclude that this level/quality of preparedness cannot depend on "renewables" since all of them are climate-dependent (would be massively impacted by large climate swings), and we need just the opposite.  Regrettably, impartiality is not the buzz word today; it's been replaced with the idiotic Mother-Earth mass mania.

thats a good question, tho a simple google search would have given you the answer lol 
basically, When sunlight reaches Earth, the surface absorbs some of the light's energy and reradiates it as infrared waves, these infrared waves are what carbon dioxide absorbs and then redirects back to earth in all directions

edit (btw infrared waves are basically heat)
author: Oliver Ridderstolpe

text: That is by no means a "stupid idea". The sunlight (also known as ultraviolet radiation) enters the atmosphere because of its short wavelenght, but when it hits the Earth, the sunlight is absorbed and re-emitted as infrared radiation (which is a higher wavelenght). Infrared radiation cannot directly go through the greenhouse gases in the atmoshpere as UV rays do. This is a phenomena you can experience yourself if you have a car and leave it sitting in the sunlight.

text:
If we want to effectively tackle these problems, what we need is to focus only on measures that have a real impact

1) distance tax: a tax that increases the longer the goods are shipped or transported- this incentivizes a local economy and stops the mess of goods running around the world for no reason.

2) female education- the more educated the less children they will have, as overpopulation is a huge problem

3) tackle income inequality- tax the super wealthy and the multinationals, make them pay the right share, no more tax avoidance or producing in countries with lower regulations. Big companies need the most resources and make up the biggest polluters, so local and smaller is better.

4) universal basic income so people dont have "to make a living" at any cost and follow their passions- no damaging, stupid or unnecessary work

5) make hemp biodiesel (and other biodiesels) make up 30% of all fuel compulsory in the economy and make investments. Tackle food waste and make it maximal 5% of all produced. Go towards 0% fossil fuels with improved technology. Swap most plastics for hemp-derived materials

6) sustainability index- make an index of the worst environmental offender-practices. Ban those that are not needed and bring within limits those that can be made sustainable. Use taxes to incentivize/disincentivize

7) go towards a bio-adapted infrastructure such as passages for the wild under highways and so forth. Go back to natural farming, drop all intensive farming, is healthier anyway. Decrease production of animal products. Abandon chemicals, fertilizers and pesticides, all not sustainable. 

8) we need a working UN back in some form, to protect areas such as the amazonas and other strategically important parts of the world for the ecology. Besides that we need first nation countries to invest in countries that are lagging behind, as the investment would yield much greater results. This is a global challenge.

9) drop all the measures that wont make any difference and accept that we cant control it 100% at this point. Maybe there are some benefits in a warmer climate too.

Feel free to copy/paste

text:
@Thomas Maughan  ohhh, sry. I forgot how the world looks like to an US-citizen.
I will elaborate: cost of removing yearly global emissions is about $3E12 t divided by the global population of 7.8E9 is about $380 per year per capita. Yes, a steep price for some and still on the low end of cost, especially if we do nothing. That is why I proposed a distribution by wealth. It would certainly be more reasonable to distribute by responsibility, which would leave the US with an even bigger share, but still not all the burden. But don't worry, Koch Industries, ExxonMobil and Co are going to stop your politicians for taking responsibilities anyway.

"its irreversible". The carbon will remain for a long time, yes, that is why this video was about sequestering it from the atmosphere. Didn't you listen? The change in climate would be reversible, as long as we do not hit tipping points. And we might be damn close to hitting some (west-antarctic and south west greenland ice-sheet melt, Amazon forest degradation, AMOC state switch or even its collapse).

IMO that point is mood though, since for the removal you need a lot of energy and too many of these installations to be build on a moments notice. My point was, that this as a thought experiment is not a matter of cost. Also, the future cost of not stopping climate change and doing buisness as usual, is going to be a lot higher than that and is actually civilisation ending. It is likely that neither you nor I will experience that, though.

"What do I get for that?  Nothing!" You already got the benefits for burning fossil fuels, or more like the top 10% got them. Climate change is the aftermath of that party, it is clean-up time. Meaning we have to deal with the consequences, sooner or later. What do you get for a clean-up after a house party? Less roaches.

text:
Water vapor is the predominant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere and helps to maintain the planet’s temperature. As carbon dioxide, methane and other greenhouse gases are added, this amplifies the greenhouse effect which further raises temperatures. Besides hiking evaporation rates, the warmer air is able to hold additional water vapor. Warmer global temperatures, also, ramps up the rate at which permafrost and oceanic hydrates melt, thus releasing more and more ‘methane’. This further amplifies the greenhouse effect and increases temperatures that again, in turn, causes increased levels of evaporation and melting. The even warmer atmosphere can now hold even more water vapor, which, of course, is a greenhouse gas .....

Note: To read about what happens when CO2 levels are decreased to abnormally low levels, search:
‘Snowball Earth + cyanobacteria’

Related links:
https://samslair.blogspot.com/2018/10/ancient-greenhouse-gases-givers-and.html?m=1

https://samslair.blogspot.com/search?q=Snowball+earth+cyanobacteria+&m=1

text:
The trouble with animal agrucilture (& particularly, raising cattle) is not just the massive amount of greenhouse gas emissions it causes, but also just how resource intensive it is.

To give you a feel for the scale of the issue, meat still makes up a small fraction of calories consumed globally.  Last I checked, meat + dairy products together make up less than 25% of global calorie consumption, & meat even makes up a relatively small minority of protein consumption.

Even with that being the case, raising animals takes up about 80% of global agricultural land.  What that means is, we could reduce our global agricultural land use (& water use, btw) by almost 4/5ths if we just stopped farming animals.

text:
Unfortunately, no.  Nuclear is a good thing to have, but it will not be our solution to climate change.  Aside from the enormous cost & technical challenge to build nuclear power planets, which many countries cannot manage, nuclear power plants take far too long to build.  Even in the US, the average time to construct a single nuclear plant is nearly a decade.  And it generally costs tens of billions of dollars.

And we would need thousands (most estimates are in the 10s of thousands) of nuclear plants all over the world to take care of our current global energy need, nevermind our constantly growing global energy demand.

Unfortunately, even if we had been building nuclear plants at break-neck pace since the 1950s & never quit, it still would be too slow to solve our problem.

text:
Trees can't be relied on. First, every quarter century, fools like Trump or Bolsanero come along & allow their cronies to cut down what you've planted. See what's done to Bialowiecsa Forest, Poland by the PiS government. 
Woods are on fertile soil, timber is value, even stabile govt can't keep it safe- even swedish old growth is dwindling.

More important, there's simply not enough open land to plant them co2 Capture trees. Farm folk live there, if not, it's already forest or it's unfertile or too dry. Greenpeace calculated about 2 times the surface of india is needed for current offset schemes using trees. We don't have that kind of empty land surface.

Third, emissions are enormous. 
The average Car drive of 10-12 miles emits ca. 2 kilo CO2 gas, about 1m3. To reduce 1 cubic meter to 1ppm, you need 1 million m3 of air, that's twice the payload of a major container ship, for reducing one commute emission to one lousy ppm. 400 of those rides, doubles the CO2 content in 2 big container ships, or equals the emissions of a single flight, or about 30 cubic feet of cement concrete. Yep, better use trees for building, which is all right, except that wood buildings burn easy. 

Same goes for tree based Carbon Capture Schemes

text: Great question! The answer is that the light coming into the atmosphere is composed of different wavelengths to that which is leaving the atmosphere: light from the sun is full of short wavelengths (like UV) while light from the earth is full of long wavelengths (infrared). This is basically because the sun is much hotter than the earth. And CO2 only absorbs long wavelengths of light (in a certain spread of wavelengths, specifically), while not absorbing short wavelengths like those from the sun. This is because of the way the CO2 molecule is built. I hope this helps!

author: Ben Godson

text: Trees aren't even a great way to remove carbon from the atmosphere. There are way better plants. Grass is actually better because it locks down more of the carbon when the snowfalls happen in northern climates that then gets locked into the ground, and it can do it faster than a tree can. A tree is a long lived organism that can by itself lock up way more than any others, but it's a very slow process. Grass, hemp, microorganisms that use photosynthesis, etc. Trees are a useful one for humans for sure, but it is not that fast. I believe about 70% of the o2 created every year is from micro organisms. These are actually really good, because they tend to float on the ocean and other bodies of water, and when they die they sink to the bottom of the ocean, effectively locking up the carbon they used to mature down there, where as when a tree dies, it will decompose and release its stored carbon again. Trees are only a good method of locking carbon for as long as they live.

text:
People are afraid of being treated like objects. The fact is it's not a bad thing, if none of us existed. The only part which can have that is in being alive. Non-experience, non-pain, is always neutral state. You can't lose with that. Likewise, you might be thinking, 'well, then you can't win either!'. Yes, that may be true, if you think pleasure is winning , but if you realize pain to less pain creates the illusion of a reward through relief, then you will realize 'the game' is duped and we're not playing any important role, at all, that I am aware of. It's all cyclic. Anything we believe is of urgency or purpose, is designed to keep us to fight for our survival and continual reproduction, because that's what DNA does best. It's physics. Nothing wrong with that, but that's what it is. Most people probably won't wanna play after they realize it, so don't. Just step outside of ego and want, and the void will be open. The fear of the unknown keeps us from it. Obviously, since those are the main mechanics of our motivation, you can't step out, without being dead. There's no reason to rush the process, just flow. Your trip will come. Don't get too attached, if ya don't wanna wake up here, again. That's my hunch, anyways. 😉

—Shalom—

author: spillarge

text: @spillarge  I know the numbers. You haven't grasped how sensitive the climate is to changes in atmospheric composition (or indeed how finely tuned everything is to allow life to continue on this planet). If the oxygen content was to increase by a few per cent, for example, wood would become so flammable that civilization wouldn't have made it out of the bronze age. Decrease oxygen by 5% and we would've had a lot of trouble making fire at all. I don't get my info from media, I don't have a TV licence, I don't watch the news, I don't read newspapers. I get my information from highly intelligent, educated acquaintances who work in the relevant fields, along with the smartest youtubers - Elon Musk, Veritasium. All the smartest people I know - and I know some extremely smart people as I went to Oxford Uni myself - are certain that climate change is man-made, it's creating 'positive' feedback loops compounding the problem over time, and it is/will cause extraordinary suffering. But what they are not prepared to say is that it is the sheer scale of human ignorance, stupidity and consumerism that is at the root of it. People like you.

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de Géophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15°C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

author: Peter Griffin

text:
Except that is really IS real:  Speaking as a researcher who is working on a book that is partly about global warming, we know that the climate emergency is real, lethal, urgent, and WE caused it. How do we know human activity is the main cause of almost all recent global warming? Here’s how: 

1) Burning fossil fuels increased the levels of greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide) in the atmosphere and oceans. For the atmosphere, the change was from 280 ppm of CO2 to 415 ppm of CO2—a 48% increase. For the oceans, they absorbed enough excess CO2 to make them 30% more acidic. 

2) We know the additional CO2 in the atmosphere was mostly due to human activity because as we burned more and more fossil fuels, the relative proportion of carbon 12/carbon 13 isotopes in the atmosphere gradually shifted towards the ratio produced by burning fossil fuels (2% more Carbon 12). 

3) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the lower atmosphere and the oceans got warmer than before--just as the theory of man-made global warming predicted they would. 

4) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the upper atmosphere got cooler--just as the theory of man-made global warming predicted it would: This happens because the additional CO2 we added is now trapping more of that heat in the lower atmosphere. 

5) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there was an increase in the lower atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. Again, this was just what the theory of man-made global warming predicted would happen.

6) As human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there was a decrease in the upper atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. Again, this was just what the theory of man-made global warming predicted would happen.

7) Models of the relationship between levels of greenhouse gases and average global temperatures have predicted global warming with impressive accuracy. 

https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming

8) Research that takes into consideration the effects of multiple natural factors (sun’s activity, earth’s orbit, etc.) and anthropogenic (man-made) factors on global temperatures has found that the addition of greenhouse gases due to burning fossil fuels caused all of the recent observed warming. 

Taken together, ALL EIGHT of those pieces of evidence prove conclusively that recent warming was caused by humans burning fossil fuels.

In terms of climate science, evidence that strong is like investigating a murder scene and knowing the suspect had motive, opportunity, you know the means of death, the suspect’s fingerprints are on the murder weapon and you have a videotape of him committing the crime. All recent warming and climate disruption is due to us burning fossil fuels.

To dip your toes into the evidence, try all three levels of content in the link below, but especially see Figures 4b, c, and d in the “Advanced” level: 

https://skepticalscience.com/empirical-evidence-for-co2-enhanced-greenhouse-effect-advanced.htm

http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2004/12/how-do-we-know-that-recent-cosub2sub-increases-are-due-to-human-activities-updated/

Also see

https://www.theguardian.com/science/2019/jul/24/scientific-consensus-on-humans-causing-global-warming-passes-99

Finally, it’s the SPEED of temperature and CO2 changes which is so lethal to the web of life—TEN TIMES faster than when coming out of an ice age. Most life can’t adapt to the rapid and cascading changes that brings, and our civilization is totally unprepared for the tsunami of rapid and harmful changes coming our way in the next century (but already beginning now). 


If we stay on the path we are on, that leads towards the degradation and then collapse of ecosystems and thus the collapse of ecosystems, and thus the collapse of our food supply, society, and population. I’m almost 60, have two young adult kids, generally care about people and nature, and wish we didn’t do this, but we did. 

Happily, there are hundreds of strategies for healing and restoring a healthy balance, but we will need to switch to lifestyles and an economic model that actually obey the limits and laws of nature. That includes a RAPID transition away from burning fossil fuels and simpler lifestyles in wealthy nations (especially for the rich folks whose lifestyles cause by far the most damage).

Take care.
author: Karl Wheatley

text:
Unfortunately, everything in your post is inaccurate. After overestimating climate sensitivity to CO2  in the late 1970s, climate scientists have it figured out quite well now, and their models have been quite accurate, and we know that our burning fossil fuels offset the cooling that should have occurred plus created all recent global warming (whether you look at the last 65 years or the past 150, all net global warming was due to us burning fossil fuels [with a helping hand from deforestation]). How do we know human activity is the main cause of almost all recent global warming?

1) Burning fossil fuels increased the levels of greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide) in the atmosphere and oceans. If we stay on the path we are on, that leads towards mass die-offs and extinctions of most human and planetary life. I’m almost 60, have two young adult kids, generally care about people and nature, and wish we didn’t do this, but we did.

text:
@Lewis .Ludwig  I forgot this critical bit: You said "If you say we have to do something about this, my question is what is your solution?  Give me a solution that cuts man made CO2 by at least 75%.  With current technologies, there are only two ways to do that; nuclear power and/or stop all economic activity." Stopping all economic activity is a straw man, but we do need a fundamentally different economy and fundamentally different lifestyles to secure the survival of humanity, and there are actually hundreds of solutions for cutting CO2 by 75%, starting with reduced consumption of both energy and material goods, and then reducing global trade and this Earth-destroying way we make things like tennis shoes. After that, here are 80 of the best researched ways of drawing down atmospheric CO2 levels (we have to reverse warming and to do that, we need to REDUCE atmospheric CO2 levels):


https://www.drawdown.org/solutions-summary-by-rank 


The book that grew out of this research project is fascinating. However, in the past, increased efficiency seems to have fueled further consumption of energy, and we have to put an absolute lid on carbon emissions just as a family would put an absolute lid on spending. It's worth noting that when a group of five retired GOP senators and five retired DEM senators were put together on a task force to solve America's biggest problems, one of their solutions was a gas tax of 10 more cents every year, ending up at around $1 more a gallon. 


Take care.
author: Karl Wheatley

text: @Karl Wheatley  wow that is quite a list.  But there are a lot of NA's on the list, and I notice that nuclear power is well down the list.  Also the cost/benefit numbers for wind/solar look to be way off.  So sorry I have to reject this list, but I will say that perhaps I am rejecting it because I don't understand what it is saying.  And I'm not sure you can get the world's population to adapt to even 50% of what in on the list in any event.  And this list does not address the problem of China and India.  These two countries are building coal fired power plants as fast as they can, and they are both competing in the world market with the US.  There is no way the US is going to spend the kind of money we need to to get to zero carbon and then watch China and India take away a bunch of business from us because they have a huge energy cost advantage.  And unless you can get China and India in line with this program, everything everyone else does will be wasted.  Yet China and India are smart enough to know that you cannot expand your grid with wind/solar, they are unreliable sources of energy.  Kudos for you for at least outlining something that in your mind would work, but I think you are being unrealistic in thinking that you can get enough people on board to make it happen.
