text:
No matter how well managed, land used to graze livestock or raise livestock feed could sequester VASTLY more carbon if it was allowed to become wilderness/forest again. Basically, to save the Earth, people have to start eating a LOT LESS beef, lamb, and goat meat. We need to do much more than that, but there's no way to get our economy/way of life within the Earth's limits without cutting down on beef. Beef is just an incredibly and unsustainably wasteful way to get calories and nutrients. In terms of land use, wheat is 25x more efficient for providing protein than beef/lamb are, and pulses/legumes are 100 TIMES more efficient. (For providing calories, the advantages of plants are even greater). So the reality is that the only way we can get the greenhouse gases problem under control and save the planet is for people to sharply reduce beef consumption. Here's media coverage of two very large studies published in top scientific journals in 2018 basically reaching that conclusion:

https://www.commondreams.org/news/2018/10/11/save-planet-climate-catastrophe-new-study-says-put-down-damn-meat

https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jun/08/save-planet-meat-dairy-livestock-food-free-range-steak

For some simple charts showing just how wasteful and unsustainable beef consumption is, see

https://ourworldindata.org/agricultural-land-by-global-diets

As you can see from chart 2, if everyone the way Americans did, we'd need 2.7 times more agricultural land than we are using now, and that's more habitable land than even exists on the Earth. Similar patterns hold true for other developed nations--are diets are one big part of what's destroying the health and livability of the planet, and cutting down on beef consumption is the #1 most impactful act people can do to help the situation. 

Also, it's well-established that eating a plant-based diet kills fewer animals than raising animals does, and more broadly speaking, eating plants uses far less of the Earth's land, meaning less deforestation and loss of biodiversity, less global warming, less and smaller dead zone and toxic algae blooms. 

So, yes, WHERE beef is raised, it should be grown using the managed grazing methods that sequester more carbon than do lousy grazing methods. However, forests sequester VASTLY more carbon than do grazing lands of fields of livestock feed (and are far better for biodiversity and ecosystem health). So if people worldwide sharply reduced meat consumption (or went vegan), we could reforest an area the size of the US, ultimately sequestering hundreds of billions of tons of CO2. Thus, after having fewer children, reducing beef and lamb consumption is the next most beneficial thing you can do for cooling the planet and healing Earth’s ecosystems.

Take care.
author: Karl Wheatley

text: @Karl Wheatley  Hi Karl. Thanks for the great comment. Remember that prior to human agriculture vast plains in Asia, Africa and America were grazed by enormous herds of herbivores. Buffalo in America numbered in the tens of millions. Today we still see this play out in east Africa. Watch Joel Salatin {on YT} talk about this at length. Secondly, we cannot expect people to allow forests to grow unmolested. We can see what is happening to the Amazon. Where food is being grown and the land properly managed, this will be of greater benefit than hoping lands left to wilderness will not be exploited by people. I have a personal prejudice against wheat though I know it feeds a lot of people. I also believe animal derived foods are an important part of our diet. Of course a reduction in human population is the real solution.
author: mad woof

text:
@mad woof  Thanks for your reply. Put 66 million large herbivores in America, Asia, and Africa respectively and we are still 800 million short of the number of cattle we have on Earth today. There are just TOO MANY CATTLE (plus sheep and goats) to keep Earth's ecosystems viable long term. They just take up too much land, and if people ate must less meat, 70% of the deforestation that has happened in the Amazon would never have happened because our more plant-based diets wouldn't have created any demand-side pressure to chop down/burn rainforests to graze cattle or grow cattle feed. I've watched Joel talk--interesting guy, but he tends to talk about isolated patches of land and doesn't REALLY reason globally. Yes, it will be great when our population goes down, but it is what it is, and if you have to choose between and vegan/almost vegan diet or a typical (not even high meat) diet that uses FIVE TIMES as much land to feed a person, only one end of that continuum is feasible on a planet of this size. We don't have to "hope" the wilderness isn't exploited by people: If we sharply reduce meat consumption (and palm oil too) we simply have no reason to chop down all that rainforest. Then enact tough laws to protect them, but that's easier when you aren't working against the profit motive from Big Meat.
Take care.

text:
This might be out of the question in the video, but the lack of any direction on how to change or what to do is baffling. You did go over what to do as a person, and yes being aware of your implementations on the environment is important, but there are countries that are producing a lot of Co2 such as, China, USA(mainly Military), and India. Climate change is a political question and always will be due to the fact that it can cut into a countries GDP heavy such as China. China will most likely never try and reduce carbon emissions because they are getting a huge amount of money form production, and manufacturing. USA is quite suborn with a strong military and thus will have a hard time lowering carbon emissions, and India is the same with china. You sort of glanced over renewable energy which I can under stand why you did not put much effort into discussing it or if the main point of the video was on the Co2 extraction machine. Although renewable energy is almost a complete scam. Solar panels use extremely toxic materials inside of them for the chemical to electrical process and have a life span of about 10-20 years and the toxic waste is essentially  unusable. Wind turbines are expensive while also taking up a huge amount of land to make a wind farm. Also wind farms have been know to kill birds indiscriminately. Hydroelectric dams also emit methane from there reservoirs with decay plants and animals. We need to stop pushing the false products that will end up doing more damage than good and find a better solution. You did mention that in the year 3000 the radioactivity of nuclear waist is reduced by 3000x which is a great point that i would move into. Nuclear energy is possibly our greatest option for our energy crisis, besides fusion reactors, where the nuclear waste is the largest issue. 


I hope that some people will read this brick of text and learn or question something about the topic of climate change and it would be amazing if this comment got pinned.
For clarification I am not insulting Simon Clark or anyone.

text:
@Damn Dirty Ape  there is a theory that Earth may become as hot as Venus due to the CO2 feedback loop continuing as we all enjoy our hummers and airplanes.
So the big hunk of rock will still be here, orbiting the Sun for millions or potentially even billions of years. But everything that's alive will probably be scorched to death, without the possibility of adapting to their new environment. Even now, while the climate is changing slowly, it appears we are losing certain species. When the overall temperature starts rising exponentially, no amount of evolution or science will be able to help. And no, Mars is not a solution. Whatever people may think, it doesn't take centuries to terra-form a planet. It's more like tens of millennia :) And even if by some miracle we were able to do it, there's no guarantee we won't forget our history and screw that one up too :D

text: You are talking mostly about global warming. Not climate change. Global warming is the subject you have to use if you talk about carbon emissions and the whole process around it. Climate change is the subject you use if you are talking about the causes and effects of global warming which is rising of sea levels, the impact on ecosystems, hurricanes, tornados, changing entire climates,... Global warming first, then climate change. Climate change is irreversible I agree on that since the causes and effects have already happened or are happening. Global warming is reversible by reducing carbon emissions, but most scientist are aware that global warming is irreversible as well since humanity is NOT succeeding in taking drastic measures to save the biosystems. Not because the tools and ideas are there, but because of the essence of humanity itself. Humanity is a vile hypocritical being that only leeches. There is no such thing as a collective hive. Humanity is selfish, ignorant, fools that only think about their selves. And thus global warming will keep occurring. Earth will end up having the same effect that Venus its atmosphere has, basically a big thick atmosphere filled with greenhouse gases which makes it extremely hot with no chance of life at all. Earth will go through that process as well. It will end up having a similar case as Venus but will then slowly gradually get out of the irreversible loop that Venus has. By then of course humanity and other sentient species will be already dead. I’m talking about this century and the 2 centuries next to come. By god, I hope your ideas you present in your video about the nuclear waste is true, but just imagine how it would fuck up everything if the climate is going through some bad shit. That scientist of yours is bit optimistic, but she is not facing the reality of the fact that carbon emissions still keep rising. Her data needs to be updated. But besides that, you made the video on 2018. Now it is 2019 September. The scientist her paper is from 6-7 years ago? Why didn't you used scientific research of 2017 - 2018? If you present scientific research, you have to use the most recent information because scientists are still doing what they do, they research so their findings change and get much more and better insight.

text:
Plus ça change, plus c’est la même chose.


'Twenty five years before Greta, there was Severn, and we ignored her.
“Coming up here today, I have no hidden agenda. I am fighting for my future.
Losing my future is not like losing an election, or a few points on
the stock market. I am here to speak for all generations to come . .
. We hear of animals and plants going extinct every day, vanishing
forever . . . Did you have to worry of these things when you were my
age? All this is happening before our eyes and yet we act as if we
have all the time we want and all the solutions. I’m only a child
and I don’t have all the solutions, but I want you to realise,
neither do you. If you don’t know how to fix it, please stop
breaking it.”


Reading this you could think it was from any one of the youth climate
strikers. Greta Thunberg, or Saoi O’Connor from Cork. Instead,
these words were spoken more than 27 years ago, by then 12-year-old
Severn Cullis-Suzuki at the plenary session of the Rio Earth Summit
in 1992.'


https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/twenty-five-years-before-greta-there-was-severn-and-we-ignored-her-1.4022656

author: Andrew LaPorte

text:
@Blaise Semenya  But most people who complain aren't complaining about climate change because things are changing; many are progressives who seek change after all.  They complain because the current phenomena is understood to be caused by humanity and is threatening the livelihood of people as well as the ecosystem. 

 For instance, the reduced ice in the Arctic has allowed for the Gulf Stream in the Atlantic to push farther north and shifted the arctic winds over Canada to push farther south to more habitated areas periodically, resulting in the "polar vortex."  

For a second example, in Cambodia droughts that are believed to be caused by climate change threaten the livelihood of fisherman who live and work in the country's delta.  More sporadic rainfall has resulted in lower water levels to the point where even in the rainy season regions that are supposed to flood are bone dry, except in the occurence of floods.  This means severe economic losses for the nation and the likely relocation of tens of thousands of workers within an impoverished region.  And don't get me started on the Pacific nations that have swaths of territory vulnerable to rising sea levels.  

You might think that the environmental movement is all about primitivism and "save the whales," but honestly that's not the reason that almost every nation on earth has declared it to be a problem.  It's because billions of lives and trillions of dollars might be lost if nothing is done.  

Perhaps I should've used a different analogy; cancer has always existed, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't stop smoking.  But that's just me.  Take my words with as much salt as you like.
author: Andrew LaPorte

text:
One thing is absolutely certain - the Earth’s resources are finite and humans will be finished when those resources are exhausted and used up. 
Humans have been heading for disaster ever since they came into existence - now we have a situation where the population is ever increasing 
And resources are depleting faster than ever.  In other words, ever more people for ever fewer resources.  Things may have got worse since the 
Industrial Revolution but before that people were no ecological saints - there is plenty of evidence that species were going extinct from human activities such as hunting thousands of years ago.   And it is certainly true that species were going extinct before the Industrial Revolution happened, like the Dodo in the 17th Century, It is simply going to be impossible to change our economy completely in a decade or two, 
If it ever were possible, it would take a minimum of a century or two, and by then it would be too late. 
No, given human nature,  humans will continue to kill each other in wars that will always take place somewhere in the world, 
And given the number of nuclear missiles Is now apparently increasing , it is still very much possible, even if not as likely as during the 
Cold War, that one of those wars will go nuclear, destroy civilization, making climate concerns of course irrelevant.

text:
The theoretical minimum energy required to remove 1 ton of CO2 from the atmosphere is about 100 kWh. Assuming 10¢/kWh, that means the theoretical minimum cost of carbon capture is $10/tCO2. The problem is that CO2 is so diffuse in the atmosphere that you have to process a huge amount of air in order to capture a ton of CO2, so most proposed systems sacrifice a significant amount of operating efficiency to keep the capital cost manageable. For instance, you don't need as much surface area for absorbing CO2 if you increase the flow rate of air over a smaller surface area using a fan, however; operating that fan uses more energy. So, sadly; no the cost of CO2 capture can't fall by 2 or 3 orders of magnitude.

Unless of-course you had some sort of magical CO2 capturing system combined with a factory that used solar energy to capture CO2 AND build more of itself out of that CO2! Oh, wait, that already exists. It's called a tree...

That is not the case. The increase is only about 1.3 ppm per year. Most of the carbon dioxide must be captured by other sinks such as the oceans.
A proper study shows that even this increase with 1.3 ppm mainly comes from the warming of the oceans. 
I presume you are aware of that the solubility of a gas in water decreases when the temperature increases.
The amount of humanly produced carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is totally negligible.
Please make a thorough study of the science with the use of carbon isotopes.

As an example of irrefutable evidence I cite a number of papers that prove not beyond a reasonable doubt, but beyond any doubt, that increasing CO2 to 600ppm in greenhouse experiments has doubled plant growth. text:
@Kerry Parks  The article you have referenced is related to a long-term research study into the affects of CO2 concentrations on plant life, that is being conducted with the support of multiple universities across Australia. 
While there is increased growth in their weather-controlled hermetically-sealed greenhouses as CO2 levels increase, in much higher concentrations the plants do die. Energy consumption dramatically increases as CO2 levels increase to maintain constant temperature/humidity levels, and oxygen masks are provided to researchers that enter these sealed greenhouses as concentrations above 500ppmv is considered to be toxic to humans (according to this study's safety procedures). 
Unfortunately, I can't provide you an online source for these current results as it's part of a restricted journal, with the full public report expected to be released in the next couple of years. 


By the way, the computer performance required to calculate the variables you have identified simultaneously is beyond what any supercomputer is capable of processing. Unfortunately, with traditional statistical analysis (aka what every "skeptic" relies on) is not capable of even processing let alone representing the results expected. You're essentially asking for a 2D or 3D graph to present a multi-dimensional (+1 Trillion dimensions) outlook on the entire world. Even if we had the computing power required, we still wouldn't have a means to present it in any meaningful manner that the general public could ever comprehend.

text:
​ @Swilly Swoggiston  Thank you for all the s(w)illy fake unsupported, unreferenced conflicted rubbish . There is no secrecy nor lack of research available into CO2 enhancement of plant  growth in greenhouses. http://www.co2science.org/about/chairman.php Moreover I know first hand of several small  hydroponic farmers using CO2 to very successfully enhance plant ylelds. 
"the plants eventually die"  What are u trying to imply? You mean they dont live forever? What we do know is plants die when CO2 falls to 150 ppm  and growth doubles in 600ppm CO2   Moreover submariners survive quite well in 3000-5000ppm CO2 levels https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29789085
"Energy consumption dramatically[sic] increases as CO2 levels increase   (what 1, 3, 5 degrees?) to maintain constant temperature/humidity levels,  Thats why we as carbon based lifegorms survive b/c of what photosynthesis is,  6CO2 + 6H20 + (energy) → C6H12O6 + 6O2    Carbon dioxide + water + energy from light produces glucose and oxygen.  
"heat  and oxygen masks are provided to researchers that enter these sealed greenhouses as concentrations above 500ppmv is considered to be toxic to humans (according to this study's safety procedures)." Rubbish for the reason above!

 "computer performance required to calculate the variables......"   *Yes , no computer model has and will ever likely be able to accurately predict climate change. It seems far easier to get a paper published if u deal in the virtual world of computers. Climate science deals in fewer and fewer studies that utilizes the scientific method, aka real data. When u cant take into account all the parameters (listed above) that effect climate any conclusions are at best speculative.
Conclusion *The sad story of climate alarmism is that proponents  are about controlling the world not saving it. Governmental Policy is based on model projected output, while ignorant of or, conveniently ignoring a vast array of real world data that would convince them otherwise. 
A question for an honest climate crusader Can u give us just one credible piece of real world data that show beyond a reasonable doubt that  CO2 has caused  the "average" global temperatures to rise one degree in several decades 2) that said 1 degree is in anyway unexpected rather than a natural variation 3) that fossil fuel's contribution  rather than destruction of rainforests on a massive scale,  is responsible?

author: The Prophet

text:
Extinction is irreversible. For everything else there are methods to make improvements.

The many variables (human activities) that are adding to anthropogenic climate change can be managed in a way that reverses how much the climate changes in the future. Within the context of the Earth's systems that contribute towards the climate, it's never too late to transitions towards a more sustainable culture (Some, not all,  monetary biased (corrupt) fossil fuel companies just want to burn all they can). However, it's taken hundred's of years of human activity (e.g. CO2 emissions, deforestation etc etc) to bring about a human changed climate, so it will naturally take many years for humans to help restore some of these environmental issues. I.e .The potential for a green economy is vast & the money some (not all) fossil fuel companies will pay (e.g. Spamming social media with fake information)  in order to try and maintain their dominant market position is also vast!.  

Massive problems can be broken down into smaller steps as a way to make them more manageable. Below are a few ways anyone can begin to be 'part of the solution' in mitigating human caused climate change (inc improving your immediate local environments).

1. Think of ways you can reduce your Carbon footprint that benefit your health and the planet. e.g., Cycle rather than drive (And get those politicians to invest in good/safe cycle networks. e.g. I use an electric bike, where piratical, that's charged by solar panels (or it could be charged via a home green energy provider).

2. Reduce your Plastic waste (and get those politicians to incentivise manufacturers too also). Turning the ocean (climate regulator) into a plastic soup will only worsen our environmental problems.

3. Choose green energy providers and “chat” (take peaceful action if they can’t/ refuse to understand) to those politicians to invest in green energy deals & quit burning fossil fuels.

4. Reduce your Air Travel. Electric Jets maybe on the horizon. But until then, flying by Jet planes are a serous contributor to CO2 commissions in the atmosphere. e.g. Do you really need to fly to a business conference every year when in fact it could be an online conference & may a face to face conference every third year, for one example out of many?. 

5. Eat less meat & dairy products. Meat is very energy intensive compared to Plants (inc fungi, nuts,pulses etc). Generally speaking, a whole grain (less processed) plant based diet is a healthier option and can provide all the substance your body will ever need. 

6. A manageable size family. If every couple whom wanted children had no more than two kiddies then the human population explosion would be sustainable (provided we learned to live sustainably).

7. Learn more about the ecosystem you live in (More  environmentally aware humans is the answer to cultures of people behaving in environmentally destructive ways). 

8. Join movements (or/and donate to organisations) that seek to mitigate extinction rates. Species are dying out due to human activity! (e.g. Deforestation & land change use). Help save them!.

In summary: The general degradation of the planets ecosystems due to human activities are "reversible" (can be improved upon by reducing/reversing the destructive behaviour). Whilst the variable (effect) of increased atmospheric CO2 levels, due to human activities, over hundreds of years (net increased CO2) will take many years to mitigate, it's never too late to make that cultural/economic change).e.g., Planting huge amounts of Tree's ( already happenning in areas of the United Kingdom among others) ,reducing Jet air travel (not happening in the UK) and F.F.S!, move towards a time when the burning of fossil fuels will be an “ignorant” behaviour (outdated technology) we did in the past (before we had all these more sustainable green technologies).
author: evolution rhythm

text:
Extinction is irreversible. For everything else there are methods to make improvements.

The many variables (human activities) that are adding to anthropogenic climate change can be managed in a way that reverses how much the climate changes in the future. Within the context of the Earth's systems that contribute towards the climate, it's never too late to transitions towards a more sustainable culture (Some, not all,  monetary biased (corrupt) fossil fuel companies just want to burn all they can). However, it's taken hundred's of years of human activity (e.g. CO2 emissions, deforestation etc etc) to bring about a human changed climate, so it will naturally take many years for humans to help restore some of these environmental issues. I.e .The potential for a green economy is vast & the money some (not all) fossil fuel companies will pay (e.g. Spamming social media with fake information)  in order to try and maintain their dominant market position is also vast!.

text: There is a mistaken belief that cattle and other animals cause a large chunk of global warming, and that replacing the land used to farm animals with plants would be better. But the problem is that it doesn't work that way. A majority of land used for animals is land unfit for plant growth of the type humans can consume, but it can usually grow plants that animals can eat. So it's more efficient for a land space to have both. The downside of animals is they release a lot of methane into the atmosphere which is more of a green house gas than co2 is, but it also doesn't last as long. So it potentially raises temperatures faster, but not for as long.

author: Infini_Ryu

text:
@Infini_Ryu  "We should want to change the climate, back to pre-industrial levels."

It's admittedly a nit, but climate does not have levels - I interpret that you wish to reduce carbon dioxide to pre-industrial levels.  At that level, 280 ppm, plants are barely surviving and compete with each other for essential CO2.

"It's going to take a massive amount of energy abundance to pull all that carbon out of the air,"

Indeed; and where will that energy abundance come from? Oh yeah, fossil fuels. 

"but humans can do it, while still growing economically."

No, absolutely not.  Few things in life I consider 100 percent pure unadulterated not going to happen -- well, okay, 98 percent.

The industrial revolution, and population growth about 10 times pre-industrial, depends entirely on fossil fuel.  It is a type of subsidy.  About 40 percent of petroleum ends up as fertilizer and doesn't really contribute to CO2 anyway at least until people and cows eat plants and fart out methane. 

What it would take already has a name: "unobtainium".  Room temperature superconductor that allows solar power collected in Arizona to be transmitted without loss whatsover all the way to Maine, or for that matter, Northwest Territories of Canada.

Fusion power would help but people need to realize that fusion power is still using fossil fuel -- deuterium!   But then, the sun itself is burning its own fossil fuel:  Hydrogen.  It will eventually run out and when it does, well somewhat before then, all life on Earth will cease.

text:
The title should be: "Climate change is locked in, but we can influence how bad it gets and buy time for our kids and grandchildren to solve it". 

Good video that illustrates the severity of climate change. What a unique situation that we are in, when what we do today defines the climate conditions for millenia to come. However, a title like this is quickly seized by the climate denial crowd to say "if it's locked in, there's no need to act". Fatally flawed thinking of course, but the deniers don't care about logic, just about creating FUD that allows fossil fuel interests to continue their business models as long as possible.

The thing is: climate change effects are not "on or off" like floodwaters either going over a barrier or not. It's not like when we stay under 1.5° or 2°C everything is humpty dory and above that it's all the same mess. Sure, 2.5° C would be very bad. But it would still be much better than 3°. And that would still be highly preferable to 4°.

At this point, every Kg of CO2 emissions that we prevent is effectively buying time to mitigate the effects in the future.

text: Yes, but air can hold just a certain amount of water vapor. If you increase the water vapor concentration high enough or, as happens in nature, you lower temperature enough the water starts condensing, it starts to rain. Water vapor is self regulating in right conditions. But air can be virtually 100% CO2. Thats why we are focusing on CO2(and other gases like methane), as if you somehow manage to be CO2 neutral and remove the extra CO2 from air, it would get cooler and the water vapor would just continue its natural cycle. On the other hand, if you increase temperature of air enough, it can hold much more water and therefore its going to be much better greenhouse gas. Its a vicious cycle caused primarily by CO2.

text:
@MrMichael4567  - A belief in God doesn't make us the center of the cosmos, it makes God the center (or actually the creator) of the cosmos.  We then should arrange our lives around what God wants.  The argument for why there is a God that created the universe, and not just the universe itself I'll go into shortly (I already have before, but I'll recap it).  But who created God?  The question is really this: If the universe is all there is (no God) then what created the universe?  If God exists and created the universe, then what created God?  Do you believe in the eternal existence of the universe in some form?  For example, for the big bang to take place, some kind of quantum system enabled that to happen.  Perhaps you believe it has happened many times.  Some believe it's happening all the time.  Whatever you choose to believe along those lines, what created the "system" that can originate universes?  I take it you don't disbelieve in an eternally existing system that can originate universes (or sets of them).  Right?  It's logical to believe  in a first (itself uncaused) cause which was not itself created, which can then gives rise to effects that are in turn causes for other effects.  Logically, the only entities that require creation are entities which had a cause.  It is illogical to believe in an entity creating itself.  Logic demands either an uncreated God (which is an intelligent and personal entity) as a first cause, or else an impersonal non-intelligent system, capable of originating universes as the uncreated cause.  Take your pick.  But I choose God, because as argued previously, the nature of biology (and perhaps the structure of physics as well, but for now most obviously in biology) requires the phenomena of intelligent design (the conscious and knowledgeable manipulation of reality) to explain the origin of life, rather than evolution / abiogenesis, because such ideas relying on chance arrangements (with some natural selection effects thrown in) fall far short of adequately explaining the origin and development of the functional chemistry of life.  Academia as a whole nowadays says evolution and abiogenesis are adequate to explain life, but they're not.  When pressed in detail, you'll see it's a conclusion based on lots of faith with little hard evidence.  There are too many nonfunctional configurations of chemicals to choose from, compared to the number of functional configurations for processes such as abiogenesis and evolution to have ever found enough of the functional ones.  Natural selection can't explain this since natural selection cannot even begin to work until functional chemical arrangements have already been found (via chance mutations).  See?  Now we have a big problem.  We first need mutation to "find" our functional arrangements first, by random chance, before natural selection can appear to try and preserve such new functional systems, and there's the additional problem that a new functional system isn't likely to be functional until there are multiple components of the new system that can all work together.  Also we now know there are no natural tendencies for chemistry to pre-select functional arrangements to help non living chemicals get to be living chemicals, other than the machinery of life itself.  Outside of the functional chemistry of life, nothing drives chemistry towards functionality, but there are many many tendencies that drive living functional chemistry towards non living chemicals!  Meaning that only life is observed to give rise to life.  And once life exists, it has a tendency towards ageing and death and breakdown, rather than a tendency towards greater functionaility!  SOMETHING such as BIOLOGICAL ENGINEERING (a form of intelligent design) must have taken place to get life going in the past, because there is no known natural tendencies that drive chemistry from non life towards life.  Hence an inference to God.  We never see life appearing from non living chemistry for some fairly obvious chemical and physical reasons.  It's logical to attribute that design to God.  If we attribute it to aliens of some kind, we have to then go back to their creator(s).  So we can skip that step.  


Here's an analogy of what I'm saying:  We believe a certain person can win a lottery of the usual kind (a winner per hundred thousand lottery tickets) once, or maybe very rarely twice in a row (or twice or more) in their whole lives, but we do not believe a person can win 10000 lotteries of that kind one after the other with no break.  if a certain person were to win 10000 lotteries on a row (or even 10 in a row) we would suspect some kind of cheating had been taking place.  It's theoretically possible they could win any number of lotteries in a row, but in reality, that's not feasible, it is never going to happen because there are far too many ways to buy losing tickets in comparison to the small number of ways to buy all the correct winning tickets.  So lets pretend we have a scenario where someone actually does win (if they could live long enough ;-) 10000 lotteries one after the other.  Do we conclude they did so by luck?  Or do we conclude there is some kind of cheating scheme or conspiracy to buy winning lottery tickets?  I'll just say that the second operation wouldn't be called a "conspiracy theory" because there would be hard evidence to conclude there was actually an actual conspiracy.  So here, an inference to a conspiracy to manipulate the continual purchase of winning lottery tickets equates to an inference to the intelligent design of chemical systems which operate biology.  Concluding that winning 10000 lotteries in a row equates to pure luck, is like concluding abiogenesis and evolution are responsible for the origin of life.  Also you tried to say that Christ points the way towards atheism (I think).  How so?
author: tubewatch59

text:
@MrMichael4567  - You've put your case as to why you disagree with christianity, but you claimed my logic was deeply flawed. How?  Maybe with reference to evolution?  Darwinian evolution?  I discussed the drawbacks of natural selection, which is the chief explanation for how evolution can replace design.  Yes, I know how the theory goes.  Here it is in brief:  We have an initial functional biological system (we won't discuss how that arose just now, as it evolution we're talking about which requires life to already be in existence.  That system then experiences a mutation.  In it's DNA if it's a one celled organism, or otherwise a mutation in it's reproductive cells.  Sometimes that mutation will change the DNA coding.  Rarely it will cause a fatal effect, killing the reproduced creature quickly or slowly.  Mostly it will have a nearly neutral effect.  Less often it will have a clearly deleterious effect, making the organism less fit.  Much less often it will have some kind of a beneficial effect on survival fitness.  All this has been studied at length.  We now know that in almost all known cases of beneficial mutations, the fitness benefit (which is a benefit that increases the representation of that mutated organism in the population) is due NOT because the mutation somehow helped to build a new functional system, but instead, the fitness benefit came about because the mutation damaged the organim in a "beneficial" way.  Huh?  Yes, that can happen.  For example if a fish lives in a dark cave with no light at all, and can never swim to an area with light, then the eyes of that fish are subject to damage, such as infection of injury.  but if a mutation takes place which damages the ability of that fish to form eyes normally, then even though the fish is now blinded by that mutation, in the environment (niche) of the dark cave, it was already blind anyway (no light) so the mutation actually gives that blind fish a survival benefit compared to other fish with eyes, because the blind fish isn't going to get an eye injury from bumping into something.  Over time these fish may increase their representation n the population and may even take over the population altogether!  But if the cave ever experiences a cave in, now exposing it to light from the outside, all these blind fish are now at a great disadvantage compared to any remaining fish that can still see.  The point is, this is how evolution works just about all of the time.  And as you'd be able to figure out, this kind of evolution doesn't build new functional systems, it only makes the best of a bad situation.  To build new functional systems is not easy for mutations to achieve because functional systems are very complex and finely tuned.  One might imagine that new systems are slight modifications of existing systems, but that is only true to the extent that we have slightly different variations to the same molecular machines.  When it comes to building new machines, there are no easy evolutionarily traversible pathways of functional interconnectedness.  Instead the various different functional machinery we see in life are isolated from each other by great gulfs of DNA configuration space.  For example, if all the different molecular machines were evolutionariy related, we should observe that the DNA codings all fit onto a branching tree showing how the coding of the oldest original molecular machines changed bit by bit into other machines etc etc and you'd be able to place it onto a tree.  The tree of life.  Guess what, that assumed tree doesn't exist in reality.  Of course, evolutionists have built many trees that attempt to link organisms and machinery, but these all conflict and do not resolve.  Any such data can be fitted into non resolving trees of course, but that doesn't demonstrate evolution.  To do that you'd need trees that resolve, but that isn't observed.  See: https://www.sott.net/article/173647-Why-Darwin-was-wrong-about-the-tree-of-life
These people still believe in evolution, but they have had to admit (since 2009) that the data doesn't fit what the theory predicted.  There are even what are known as orphan genes, which are proteins (molecular machines) that do not fit onto any known trees.  They are isolated and yet form a quite large percentage (10% to 30% or more) of proteins!  They actually look like they were specifically created to do what they do, with no hints of evolution (although you would find very slight variations within each orphan gene family as they have mutated a little over time).  In any case, building new functional machinery (including orphan genes) means you need to make many many mutations.  That is easy to do, but the problem is, there are so many more mutations that do not end up doing anything useful, compared to the small number which would.  And natural selection cannot aid in that process.  If you need to form the DNA sequence tcgcatagcttgctacgaatcgcattcacggatataggaaccgggtggccagctcaaagcacttcggagtcttacaagtcactcagcaacctcaggcagt to get something functional that will be beneficial then until you actually have a series of mutations which can build that sequence over a long period by altering an existing sequence.  That can be done, but imagine how many other sequences exist which could be built, that won't do anything useful?  Of curse, some sequences will cause death, and natural selection can easily weed those out, but most sequences are neutral.  These mutations are thought to take place in unused gene copies, so the mutations accumulating don't interfere with the actual gene being used (or happen in so called junk DNA).  But the problem is, the ratio of functional to nonfunctional sequences is astronomically small.  This is known from experiments on proteins, see Doug Axe's work: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15321723
So in reality it really is rather like the lottery analogy.  When nature is mutating a gene sequence, it does so randomly.  How can natural selection guide the process?  Since many mutations need to accumulate to build a new functional gene, protein, protein machines (which need mutations to link together the various protein parts that make up these machines, sometimes dozens or hundred of them) then how can we guide the process by natural selection?  Natural selection acting on mutation IS Darwinian evolution (the new synthesis - that is) so how can natural selection pick and choose which mutations are going to work in the sequence ahead of time?  But natural selection works by comparing different functional systems effects on reproductive fitness.  How can it choose the mutational pathway to a new functional protein etc?  Answer: IT CAN'T!  We really are in a random lottery like situation.  For ALL of evolution that is interesting, because evolution doesn't just explain slight variations, it needs to explain the origin of new function.  But it cannot!  There are too few mutations available, too little time to have them take place in, and too many nonfunctional DNA configurations versus functional ones, for evolution to ever be able to find them.  Well, once every now and then evolution may "find" a simple protein sequence that has some effect on something else, but that is not what we're talking about.  How are new protein machines that perfom complex biological functions evolved?  No one knows!  And don't forget, all these arguments presuppose the existence of amazingly complicated protein machines that make reporduction and life maintenance functions possible.  The simplest possible life form takes about 400 enzymes and machines in order to be biologically viable.  Any fewer and that life is short lived as it cannot function adequately enough to survive.  But how did all of that appear?  Abiogenesis has no explanations.  All this needs design.  See ICONS OF EVOLUTION https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AZh-VJ20uC8


As to why God allowed destruction and evil?  Who knows, but I'm guessing that at some point God's creatures (theoretically speaking, in an imagined perfect universe run by God) are going to ask the question, what if we go against God's will?  What happens then?  Might things be better than they are now?  Is God holding us back?  


Our current world may well be an ongoing experiment allowed by God, to answer what happens when God doesn't control what takes place.  God doesn't compel behaviour but allows free will.  It appears this may in fact be the case, that God allowed things to run out of his control in order to teach us a lesson we can never forget, while at the same times providing a means of salvation.  You already know you don't like the results of this experiment.  neither does God!  But he isn't going to stop the lesson until it's complete either.  There will be no "yeah but what if we had tried ..." excuses.  It will all have been tried.  Some want to try to re-establish order via novel utopian central control schemes, to make things work properly and relieve suffering, but they don't work either, usually many many die as a result of misguided attempts to do good that nonetheless ignore what God has to say on the subject.  Choices we make are not unlike biology or any other system containing functionality.  There are many many more ways to foul up our existence than there are ways to improve existence.  Best to stick with the original.  AND - don't get sidetracked by prior church systems that weren't about God, but about people seeking political power.  Not many people in politics can avoid corruption, including church leaders.  If such leaders choose to pursue power and wealth by ignoring what God says on the topic, they will be doomed to fail eventually.
author: tubewatch59

text: @MrMichael4567  - My long windedness is just me trying to tell you everything at once.  Ha!  Of course it doesn't work, but that's me.  You'd need to really want to discover the limits of what evolution can do (and what it can't), but that's up to your curiosity if you want to find out.  I'm incapable of arousing that interest, but again, evolution lacks the resources of time populations and mutation rates to really create anything new, because billions of years are too short by factors of hundreds of zeroes.  Evolution sirts the vast amount of pre-existing variety but it's not much of a creative force.  It selects from minor variations of what is already there.  Evolution truly is SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST (mostly though not always because natural selection isn't all that efficient).  The big question is, where does all that FITNESS come from?  THAT is what abiogenesis and evolution were supposed to explain but they can't.  All the examples you provided have to do with taking advantage of minor variations of what already exists.  That's what evolution is.  Where all that functional information came from in the first place?  That's what evolution cannot explain.  The best explanation is intelligent design.  Only engineering (intelligent design) explains the origin of functionally complex systems.

text:
@MrMichael4567  - It's not really like the Christmas example.  When looked into the child would be persuaded (as they all are eventually) that it was his parents or someone else putting the present in front of the tree.  But when it comes to the science of origins, there is no feasible "natural" explanation that accounts for our "biological presents".  In the Christmas example, that would be somewhat analogous to proving to the child that he is alone, his parents are not with him, and could not have made the trip to where he is, that no one else could have either, and yet, regardless, presents still appeared below the tree.  The kid wouldn't be able to prove Father Christmas placed those gifts, but he'd know no human did either.  So, knowing the Christmas story already, he'd think that maybe the story of Father Christmas was true after all.  See, he can't prove Father Christmas put them there, but he can prove no one else did.  That's the situation we have in biology.  It's not religious tradition that proves God made life, it's science that proves nature is incapable of having done so.  It's not mental illness to believe in god under such circumstances.  


But why were some church leaders so nasty in the past?  And in the present.  And not just church people, but people from all walks of life?  For all the usual reasons.  Back in those days the church was a chief route to political power, so many more were in the church in leadership roles then for the sake of power, than they are today.  Now the equivalent is congress, business, the military, etc.  The same holds true today where up to this point, in large institutional churches (and in many other large organizations) being in a leadership position gives one access to institutionalized children, and the power over them to do what one wants to do with them.  It's not so much a case of mental illness as a case of the pursuit of power for evil motives.  Christianity outlaws the abuse of children, but many church leaders do and did that anyway, because they believed they could get away with it, and were never all that interested in being obedient to the Christian ideology, which outlaws such behavior and threatens the worst consequences for doing that.  As Jesus said, it would be better for people who abuse children to have a millstone put around their neck and to be cast into the deep ocean, than that they should interfere with the little ones.  But these "church leaders" did it anyway.  Because they could!  But their judgement is coming.

author: tubewatch59

But knowing these limitations on certainty, we mostly do include educated opinions when it comes to origins because it's implicitly understood we can't prove everything we're saying on that subject.

Found on the internet. . . It seems you can reduce CO2 emissions without reducing consumption, by eating beef cattle as veal could reduce the carbon footprint on these herds by up to 40%.
The 2019 Australian Beef Sustainability Annual Update shows that the red meat industry reduced absolute emissions by almost 56 per cent from 2005-2016.

See how a UK Salers herd aims to be carbon neutral by 2035
https://www.fwi.co.uk/livestock/beef/how-a-salers-herd-aims-to-become-carbon-neutral-by-2035?name=how-a-salers-herd-aims-to-become-carbon-neutral-by-2035&category_name=livestock%2Fbeef

text: More half-truths on climate change. CO2 concentration is largely due to combustion processes in industry and automobiles combined with massive deforestation over the past few centuries. Most all plant life, both terrestrial and aquatic, convert CO2 into O2, among other compounds to provide themselves with energy throughout the photosynthesis process. It's not about too much of certain elements in the atmosphere as much as the global increase of heat and pressure through the enormously massive amounts of combustion from industry/big tech dumping millions of trillions of PPM of (insert compound here) on top of the simple fact that almost all forms of combustion result in an increase of heat and pressure as the energy from the combustible materials is released. Besides, anyone who has learned anything about the Earth knows that it has gone through several climate cycles so climate change in itself should be expected. Anyone with a thought-capable brain should be able to see that humanity itself has been exponentially accelerating climate change over the past century or more. And people act surprised or freak out that we are seeing climate change... Too busy focused on themselves to realize that the climate we have now is vastly different from what it was even hundreds of years ago. Biospheres have changed, plant life and animals have gone extinct due to either natural or man made changes in environment, this all has an effect on climate. And I didn't even get into how all the nuclear bomb testing in the 60s affects the ozone, and ultimately, the climate. The USA alone spent billions of dollars punching holes in the atmosphere. And here we are 50 years later seeing the ramifications.

text: The simple truth is that global warming is a side effect of massive human overpopulation. At the same time global warming is the solution for the very same problem. Global warming WILL be fixed- just not in the way you would like for it to be fixed. Before the industrial revolution people died by natural causes keeping the population down to a reasonable level. However humans, just like bacteria, will gobble up any possible resource until it is finally extinguished.Finally, just like bacteria, when those resources are used up, human population will naturally decline to a sustainable level again. History will remember our generation as the "population blip" of the 21st century. It will likely never be repeated for 100s of years. We are simple following a natural course of population evolution. We may be able to conceive of alternative courses, but history has proven that this will not actually happen. So, really, I would not give all my money away to study climate change unless I am just entertained by the idea.

text:
Climate change is not the issue, the earth's climate has been changing for 4.5 billion years. Global warming is not the issue, the earth has been slowly warming since the last ice age and will continue to do so until it starts cooling for the next ice age. The question is the effect of CO2 released into the atmosphere by human activities. This effect is essentially trivial. This point cannot be argued with someone who does not understand the scientific method and is governed by his feelings. Open your mind and listen to the real scientists and you will learn. FYI, computer models are NOT science! They are a technological "crystal ball" that is just about as accurate. I think it was the great sage Yogi Berra who said, "Making predictions is difficult, especially in regards to the future." Though we have all met people who have an uncanny ability to predict the past, unfortunately, the current models are unable to even predict the past behavior of the earth's climate.

Politicians are throwing money that they do not have at a problem that does not exist in order to finance solutions that make no difference.
Michael Hart


We were warned in 1961 about government funded "Science"!
President Eisenhower warned of a "Technological Elite" in his farewell address to the nation. I am sure he would have recognized the IPCC as exactly that.


He expressed his concern for corruption of the scientific process as part of this centralization of funding in the Federal government:

Akin to, and largely responsible for the sweeping changes in our industrial-military posture, has been the technological revolution during recent decades.

In this revolution, research has become central, it also becomes more formalized, complex, and costly. A steadily increasing share is conducted for, by, or at the direction of, the Federal government.

...

The prospect of domination of the nation's scholars by Federal employment, project allocation, and the power of money is ever present and is gravely to be regarded.

Yet in holding scientific discovery in respect, as we should, we must also be alert to the equal and opposite danger that public policy could itself become the captive of a scientific-technological elite.[1]?

text: I couldn't agree more.  About 30,000 people die every day from starvation.  The primary cause is lack of access to affordable clean energy.  Without energy, you can't grow food effectively, you can't cultivate or irrigate and you are at the mercy of the climate, which may not always cooperate. Several billion people have no electricity.  Many of them cook food over wood or biomass fires which are responsible for respiratory diseases which are the leading cause of death in developing nations.  All of these things are real and happening now, and we can fix them by allowing them access to affordable clean energy (that would be oil and gas). Fortunately, CO2 has helped quite a bit by significantly"greening" the earth and making crops more drought resistant.  This (along with modern agriculture technology) has helped increase crop yields by over 25% in the last 30 years.  Unfortunately, developing nations without access to affordable energy have not enjoyed these increased crop yields as much. If your motivation is rooted in altruism, and keeping people from starving to death, you will pray our climate remains warm and rich with CO2.  My fear is never about warm, but that the Holocene interglacial which has been responsible for the flourishing of mankind will eventually recede into another ice age, as it has done like clockwork every 100,000 years.   Cold kills.

author: Brian Betts

text:
They are trying to fix what is not broken. CO2 is not causing the atmosphere to heat.


Earth radiates at peak wavelength of 10 microns which corresponds to 59 degrees F, which is the average temperature of our planet. Most of this radiated energy( about 63 % of the total) is centered about 10 microns and within a couple of microns above and below 10 microns. That means whatever is absorbing the majority of the infrared radiated by Earth should have an peak absorption in the 8- 12 micron bandwidth. CO2 absorbs strongly at 2.7, 4.3, and 15 microns. Most gases including CO2 all absorb in very narrow bands around their peaks, no more than 2 microns on either side of the peak.


 This means that CO2 is absorbing only very negligible amounts of energy from the Earth. Coupled with that and the fact that Earth is not even close to being a perfect blackbody radiator(a perfect blackbody radiator does not exist in nature). The Earth is at best radiating with an emissivity of ..8 to .9. This means that the radiated energy of the Earth's surface is only a small percentage of the total infrared held by the surface of the Earth.


Furthermore, when CO2 absorbs a photon it vibrates over a period of time in the microsecond time range and then emits a different wavelength that is not in the CO2 absorption band. That photon has less than a 50% chance of being reabsorbed by the Earth since CO2 emits in a solid angle in all directions which includes back into space. What all this boils down to is that 1 molecule of CO2 is absorbing such extremely small amounts infrared that it's vibrations would be completely incapable of heating even a few molecules( say 4-5 molecules) of N2 and O2 around it to a temperature of even a fraction of a degree, let alone the 2500 molecules that surround it.

text:
Before Europeans spread throughout N. America the plains were home to Huge herds of Bison. Think very large cows. They were also grazers and produced methane as a result of this. No they did not deforest the plains but they did stop the plains from being forested. This is also true for parts of Africa where the populations of Zebra, Gazelles etc have been drastically reduced by humans to make way for agriculture. Yes cattle produce methane and graze, but are they present in numbers which match their predecessors? I think not. As for a vegetarian diet being healthier, that is very debatable. Those that have studied human anatomy know that our dentition and gastrointestinal systems are more adapted to meat eating than plant eating. We naturally digest meat while we depend upon bacteria to digest plant material. That is why cow farts have so much methane in them. This is also true for vegetarians if you are honest with yourself. That is because all of the energy contained within plants is not digested and released as methane.
   As for runaway greenhouse gasses, take a close look at Venus. I believe it's surface temperature is about 700 degrees C. This is mainly caused by its thick cloud cover which acts like a blanket holding in the heat. Yes the earth will still be here regardless of what we do, but I kinda like the idea that at present earth has a huge amount of life on it. We are the only planet in our solar system which has life. That suggests that it is relatively rare in our Universe. I would hate to think that my species of life f%%^^ed it up for all other life forms on this planet.

text:
You are a silly chump, Simon Clark, the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) on planet Earth is tiny in comparison with water (H2O), not witstanding the fact that H2O evavorates and falls back as rain, transferring immense amounts of heat into the atmosphere. In fact evaporation/condensation is the principle way in which the atmosphere gets heated. True enough CO2 does absorb some heat directly from sunlight (very little) and rather more from infrared radiationfrom the Sun but because there is so little CO2 the effect is truly miniscule. 
Not only does water vapour absorb much more heat radiation than CO2 but (liquid) water circulates directly from the tropics to the poles, taking tropical heat with it.
At the South Pole this has little effect because South Polar ice doesn't get heated by circulating water because it sits on solid rock like the ice cap on Greenland, both caps are kilometers thick.
By contrast, the North Pole has 4000 meters of (liquid )water underneath it and, at most, 10 meters of ice, floating on top of water circulating from the tropics.
Now this 10 meters of ice is rather fragile, quite different from the kilometers at the South Pole and on Greenland. 
As long as the North Polar ice is not broken the temperature gets very low (-70C?)
But if the ice North Polar ice is broken by wind or Russian ice breakers, water at about +4deg. C comes through the cracks and, wonder of wonders, the local temperature rises to +4deg. C!
This has an enormous effect on the surface temperature and completely changes the local climate, or even the North Polar climate if the break up is big enough i.e. if the wind is strong enough.
You may well agree that CO2 is not 'a climate change' villain!

Hi Simon Clark - a well done, concise video. However, two things that are crucial and very effective to scaling down, or at least helping curb the effects of climate change:

1. Population. It's not a popular choice, but it's really quite simple. STOP HAVING KIDS = LESS CONSUMPTION and LESS RESOURCES USED. Cultures who don't subscribe to birth control (i.e. men dominated cultures) are really lacking in sound and sensible education, let alone beliefs.

2. PLANT MORE TREES!! and stop over developing. Let's just stop building stuff, it's that simple. Trees are the lungs of earth. We would have a very, toxic atmosphere if we didn't have trees. If human development (i.e. concrete, steel buildings, etc.) keep getting erected, guess what? The trees suffer = more carbon in the air, soil erosion, flooding, mud slides, loss of habitat for wildlife, food source, renewable resource, etc. etc. etc.
And I'm talking about ALL trees, but especially the rainforests.    

These two factors alone work hand in hand. And I think they are not being talked about enough these days. Cheers! and Peace to you.

text:
Plants do not sequester carbon fully.  If you go through the literature on the "bern simplified climate model" you'll find some great information, and there was a 2018 paper on it with a great figure on page 10 showing the land uptake.

But put simply, think about the basic processes involved.  What are fossil fuels?  How do plants sequester carbon?

When a tree or animal dies, their body decomposes.  It's food for microbes that undergo respiration, releasing CO2.  Thus, when plants take up CO2, they more often than not release it after they die.

Fossil fuels are created over millions of years.  They're created on geologic time scales.  They require biomass to be trapped by geologic structures, and undergo incredible pressure to turn into a 'fuel'.

That's not a very fast process to sequester anything.  Limestone formations sequester carbon faster than that.

When the process of sequestering requires "changing the chemical composition of biomass to inorganic rock", you can be sure that will operate on very long timescales.
author: Killua2001

text: @Killua2001  I am completely aware of everything you've stated; what I'm saying is that the model does not assume the requisite uptick in plant growth; or any sort of adaptation for carbon sequestration from flora and fauna. The model is incorrect.
author: JMAC LIVES

text:
​ @JMAC LIVES  And I'm telling you THAT ISN'T SEQUESTRATION.  We've increased the atmospheric content from 250ppm to 410ppm, and yet biomass hasn't grown by 140% in the past 100 years.  Those extra gigatons of CO2 weren't taken out of the atmosphere, these are not slow processes, they have tens of thousands of years of decay timelines.

The model isn't incorrect, you're just expecting a different result than reality provides.  CO2 doesn't magically make plant volume double, doubling CO2 won't double biomass or sequester more than we're putting out except over incredibly, incredibly long geologic timescales.
author: Killua2001

text:
@Killua2001  C02 CAN actually make plant volume double, depending on the plants. Soy for example, doesn't experience C02 saturation until just under 2000ppm. Pine trees, for example - will consume all the C02 you'll give them until they run out of soil fertility to support the growth. 

Did we see an uptick of 140% plant growth coinciding with c02 increase? Well that's something NASA is trying to figure out (see below). The surface of the planet is certainly greener than it was just 20 years ago. I'm not trying to argue about carbon sequestration of geoligic timescales; it can clearly happen immediately and over large timescales - what I'm trying to establish is that the science is not at all settled; and there are many reasons why the existing models have not bourne out to date. I've tracked most climate articles through the mid ninties. Scientists continue to get it wrong. 

I'm not even trying to argue that there is a DIRECT correlation to plant growth and atmospheric C02, but there is clearly a correlation that has yet to be calculated. 

In regards to what exactly causes upswing in C02, and it's bering on the climate at large - have you read the Vostok papers and resultant reviews? They can only correlate temperature change to C02 within 1000 years' accuracy. 

I've seen your type of arguments literally 25 years ago. What you're saying is nothing new. The models will continue to be incorrect until they can establish all the predominant variables - and then predict outcomes. The 'climate scientists' have failed to do so time and time again. 



https://www.nasa.gov/feature/ames/human-activity-in-china-and-india-dominates-the-greening-of-earth-nasa-study-shows
author: JMAC LIVES

text:
​ @JMAC LIVES  

... Once again, even if you've seen an increase in biomass, *carbon concentration is still increasing*.  So clearly there's a lag between uptake, don't you think?  And again, that 'lag' is made all the more worse by, oh, I don't know, *decomposition*!

That link does nothing to 'invalidate' the model.  What on earth do you think the uptake is going to be in 50 years?  All of a sudden we go from 500ppm (at current production amounts) to, bam, 250 in the span of, what, 10 years?  100?  1000?  Cause if it's 1000+, you're kinda confirming everything this paper says.

And you're right, nothing I'm saying is new.  And you have seen this 25 years ago.  Because the IPCC reports from ~20 years ago (and the science leading up to it) have remained remarkably constant since then.

None of this is new.

As for the Vostok papers, what, are you pointing to ice core samples?  Have you ever noticed that nearly all of those papers show atmospheric ppm <300 during the past 400k years?

And we're above 400 today?  And you think that's the kind of thing that will have a short halflife in the atmosphere?!
author: Killua2001

text:
" In the past 100 years -  scientists, journalists and pundits alike all claim either an upcoming iceage or upcoming unstoppable warming; neither of which bear out. "

... This is a lie.  Fed to you by conservative press, arguing on behalf of the fossil fuel industry.  Truth of the matter is very few scientists ever spoke about an "ice age", although there were some National Geographic and Newsweek articles citing a minority of scientists because "scientists claim the earth will have a new ice age" sells.  The actual scientific community at the time was not arguing or warning about an ice age.  Global warming, on the other hand, you're right, the science goes back OVER 100 years.  CO2's greenhouse effect has been known for a while, so yeah, even in 1896 we had scientists talking about this.

Which brings me to the next point.

"Why are the predictions and the models so consistently incorrect?"

Astoundingly, they aren't.  In 1896 Svante Arrhenius predicted that doubling CO2 concentrations would produce warming of 5-6 C.  In 1896.  Well in 1896 CO2 concentrations were roughly 250ppm, we're at 410 today.  If we take A1B, emissions will peak in 2050, putting us on track for about 500ppm by then, and ~700 by the end of the century.  I'm trying to think positive but whatever.

Following A1B, we're on track for 3 degrees C above 2000s levels by 2100.  Which is, roughly, 1-1.5 degrees C above  the temperature in 1900.  Thankfully, because this model has peak emissions in 2050, by 2300 the model doesn't see warming higher than 4 degrees above 2000s levels.

Was his prediction, made in 1896, perfect?  No.  But given it was 1896, well before the advent of computers, I think we can cut the guy some slack.  If, however, you went with models from roughly the 1990s or later, like the original IPCC report... you'll find their predictions are pretty damn accurate indeed.  We've gotten better in the past 100 years.

"Isn't the point of performing scientific analysis to predict outcomes?"

I mean, yes, but that doesn't mean every problem is easy.  We still have a hard time predicting the outcome of fluid dynamics.  But it'd be a mistake to say we know less about fluids today than we did over a hundred years ago when the Navier Stokes Equations were created.

"Why are you so sure of yourself, and why does everyone think tax on an essential will deliver us from climate change and actual pollution?"

I was unaware that fossil fuels are necessarily 'essential'.  No one thinks that a carbon tax will solve climate change.  This video explicitly is about how climate change is irreversible.  How these effects are going to last in our environment for a long time.

But you know what a carbon tax might do?  Help us get to peak carbon by 2050 and let me keep using the predictions of A1B, because it's the most likely outcome given humanity's tendencies.  You know what I want to avoid?  A1FI.  Because there the predictions start looking a whole lot more "oh.  Look.  We're in danger of causing a Permian-extinction like event".

A1FI is scary.  Very scary.  Incredibly scary.  That's where these 'doomsday' predictions all come from.  It's from models where we say "what happens if we don't get our act together at any point in time".

And they're terrifying.

Most predictions aren't A1FI.  Most predictions think "we're not that stupid".  I really, really, sincerely hope they're right.

text: What a lot of rot! I am always astounded that every weather report today is predicted by climate change and the hysteria associated with this social media nonsense. A frenzy that is making Politicians form knee jerk reactions for political popularity built through stupidity. A climate industry leaching off the public purse. The average life span of humans is some 76 yrs, and few will make 90 or 100. The youth of today are less intelligent than those of my day and will rally to any populous fad or fake news or over emotional garbage. They need to understand that the world regardless of their vitriol will end! Climate has nothing to do with it. The reason, the sun will die — life on earth whether tomorrow or 1000 years or 100000 years or 5 billion years will end. Therefore a human travelling through this time is inconsequential to the outcome. Imagine the Neurosis of today's society at the beginning of the previous Ice Ages. However, the current scientific thought is that the Earth has some 5 billion years left. People need to understand that the lifespan and exsistance of life on the earth are wholly dependent upon the ageing of the sun. Scientifically in about 5 billion years from now, the sun is going to reach a point where its core can no longer sustain the nuclear fusion as it has been and it will evolve into a red giant. A red giant star is a dying star in the last stages of stellar evolution. Therefore, that means the sun could grow large enough to engulf the earth as well as our nearby planets, but even if it doesn't, life will still cease to exist on earth at some point during the sun's transformation into a red giant. Monies spent on climate paranoia would be maybe better fed into interstellar travel.

text:
Computer models are not science. They reflect assumptions made and are very very vulnerable to being tweaked to produce results to fit in with the underlying aspirations of those creating and using them. The only way that they can have any authority is if they are tested against real world results, which in this case is tricky because none of us will be around in the year 3000 to verify the extent to which the climate has changed and/or levels of CO2 created by man's activities now remain in the atmosphere that long. 

Almost all the climate change models assume that there will be positive feedback loops that increase the amount of warming created by CO2 by a factor of 3 or 4 or more. I cannot find any empirical evidence that that is the case and have seen respectable scientists suggest that the reality is more like a negative dampening effect of about 0.5. The argument will rage on, but regardless, trying to use a model to predict things out to the year 3000 is a waste of time and money.

text:
We are now in a period where the catastrophic effects of CO2 driven atmospheric warming are being offset by the melting of ice at the poles and elsewhere.  The melting ice acts as a buffer keeping temperatures relatively stable.  However, this is a limited time offer!  The big question is what happens once all that ice has disappeared?   There will be nothing to keep temperatures from rising exponentially.  By the 22nd century all intelligent life will have to find ways to build cities underground or underwater.   Elon Musk's  new boring machine has already begun this process,
A viable strategy for offsetting atmospheric CO2 levels has been known for several decades but the Lizards won't allow it to be deployed.    The addition of large quantities of low cost minerals, especially iron,  to the worlds  oceans would promote plankton growth on a massive scale.  The plankton are either eaten by fish or fall to the ocean floor when they die.  Either way, carbon is removed from the ocean which then allows the oceans to take the CO2 out of the atmosphere.  This also has the potential to massively increase the worlds food supply with an unimaginable abundance of fish.

author: Thane's Games

text:
Climate scientists are the reason you know that half fact. Its called a feed back loop, and they understand it well. Several times in the historic record, temperature changes starting rising before the CO2. (Not every time.) The CO2 increase then caused more heat to be trapped, increasing the temperature.
For example, rising temperatures enable permafrost to thaw out. We see this happening right now. Thawing permafrost allows all of that dead vegetation to decompose to methane and CO2. 
That doesn't change what the CO2 does. It helps retain heat. 
There have been several instances of CO2 increases driving the heat increase. But nothing like today. There has never been a time when the atmosphere's composition has changed as rapidly as it is right now. In the past, life has had time to adjust to the change - many things still went extinct, but species and populations did get a chance to evolve.
This current change is hundreds of times or thousands of times faster than any recorded change - even the dinosaur killing meteor had a slower overall effect on the atmosphere's composition.
It is very easy to understand why - we are taking carbon that has been sequestered under the earth for millions of years and converting it to CO2 in our atmosphere. We know how much - the world's use of fossil fuels is well documented and accounted for. You don't need to imagine any other source - this accounts for the increases in temperature that have been measured in many different ways by many different independent people.
Your first argument is just stupid - CO2 absorbs more infrared light, whether in a bottle or an entire atmosphere, like Venus.
Venus is ridiculously hot because it's atmosphere is mostly CO2. 
You should definitely make an effort to educate yourself. You are letting yourself be disinformed because you are ignorant.

text:
8:30 No. 1 is "Don't eat meat"? But I'm an omnivore! More importantly for the science: 99.99% of livestock carbon is atmospheric carbon (via the plants they eat) and if the cows didn't eat the plants, most of that plant carbon would return to the air anyway, via decomposition and fire. Our climate problem is CO2 from fossil fuel burning: without human action that geological carbon would not enter the atmosphere but would remain underground for millions of years.

Blaming meat consumption for global warming is therefore just wrong; it's like blaming it on our own farts and respiration, all part of the short-term C cycle. Worse, it plays right into the hands of people who like to shout "Look, they want to outlaw your burger!". 

So please let's stop this nonsense now. Yes, we should feed cattle seaweed to reduce methane emissions. Yes, we should consider eating less beef for an host of other reasons (health, energy, water, and land use, deforestation, to reduce animal suffering) -- but we should NOT muddy the waters by listing cows as a major cause of global warming. That's just a Cowspiracy Theory (pun intended).

I would appreciate being corrected if I am wrong about this.

text: Your anxiety is very understandable and logical, even though it's probably not productive. We're in a huge crisis that isn't treated enough as a huge crisis and that's stressful and paralyzing. It's very important not to fall in a hole that you can't climb out of. I have days of pure desperation thinking about the state of the Earth all the time and then I try to find solace in the fact that I have very little control over this crisis. I don't eat animal products anymore, I don't take airplanes anymore, I eat locally produced seasonal food, I'm not having children and I always vote for a very green party. As an individual, there's not that much more I can do. So, I try to say to myself: "I'm doing what I can. Us humans are amazing at adapting. Perhaps things won't be as bad as we think they're going to be. People could maybe create new technologies that could make everything much easier." At the same time, I try to be realistic in my choices which is why I'm not having children. They're not only bad for the environment, but they'd likely have a very difficult life in the next century. I want to spare them the pain of possibly living on a planet where most lifeforms will have increasingly difficult lives.

text:
Ignorance  and self delusion are already irreversible for some it seems. Einstein once said " you dont need a 100 scientists to prove me wrong (on  Relativity). All it takes is just one who can present credible evidence to the contrary!" So to all those who claim "we believe in the science" please present one credible piece of irrefutable evidence that proves beyond a reasonable doubt that there is a direct causation (not a mere correlation) between atmospheric CO2 and climate change.
As an example of irrefutable evidence I cite a number of papers that prove not beyond a reasonable doubt, but beyond any doubt, that increasing CO2 to 600ppm in greenhouse experiments has doubled plant growth. You do realise that CO2 is not a pollutant but fundamentally important to photosynthesis and heaven forbid,  all CARBON BASED LIFEFORMS? 
Then if u dare, please show that the fraction that comes from fossil fuels, is the prime suspect. Hint: forget about actual physical evidence, all you need to do is program another computer model that accounts
 for deforestation, wild fires, urbanization, undersea volcanoes, sunspot activity, polar shifts, earthquakes and continental drift. What chance then of actually making an accurate prediction? Now that will be a first!  https://www.climatecentral.org/news/study-finds-plant-growth-surges-as-co2-levels-rise-16094​
