text: I would encourage you to read the literature, do a PhD in atmospheric science, and then make a video of your own when you've learned why you're wrong.
author: Simon Clark

text: @Simon Clark  I have read a great deal about this CO2 hypothesis causing global warming.  There are many PhD's who do not agree with you and there is no consensus among scientists.
author: James Chambers

text: @James Chambers  yes there is an international consensus, as reported in the IPCC reports. While elements are still debated, such as the strength of specific feedbacks, the science of the broad theory is extremely clear and agreed upon by now.
author: Simon Clark

text: @Simon Clark  Consensus is not science.  The IPCC is an Intergovernmental panel report but is not a scientific research body per se.  It has an agenda and ,many of its projections have failed over the years.  There are many other videos by other PHD's that dispute the data and projections by the IPCC and other political organizations.  To say that the science is settled automatically disqualifies the statement.
author: James Chambers

text: @James Chambers  yes, it is a scientific organisation - its reports are written by hundreds or thousands of scientists from all over the world. The end document is a summary for policymakers, not by summary makers. Political bias does not come into the conclusions of it. If anything, most scientists would say that the IPCC is too conservative with its projections - THAT is its major flaw. And yes, when thousands of scientists all look at the same data sources (independent data sources, I should add) and draw the same conclusions, with a few exceptions on details, that indicates that the science is settled. There are error bars due to the exceptions, but the consensus based on data holds as fact. That is simply how science works.
author: Simon Clark

text: @Simon Clark  It is a government bureaucracy that cloaks itself in the mantle of science.  Its admitted goal is to support policy makers and is funded by the same.  The key word is intergovernmental.  IPCC over many years has made many dire predictions which have not come true and seem to be designed to create panic and ill conceived emergency action by governments. There are many well qualified scientists that do not agree with the IPCC reports and predictions and many have created videos far more compelling than yours. For example, there is the NIPPC which is the Nongovernmental International Panel on Climate Change to name but one source. Science is not a consensus game.

@stalemittens  Defeatist attitude? You're not paying attention at all. Don't you get it? Wodz30 already nailed it nicely about the situation. And what about you? Are you 100% sure that your lifestyle does not contribute to this mess at all? Wanna know a great example of Wodz30's analogy?

Come here in Southeast Asia. And behold the thousands of acres of forest being burned every year for the sake of Palm Oil plantation. It's so bad that those living in Malaysia (east and west), Indonesia, Singapore, and southern parts of Thailand, have grown used to expecting trans-boundary Haze every year, which bring about stifling heatwaves during the warmest months of the year. No amount of lobbying can stop it because it's too big to fail! Oh yes many have tried to no avail. Go ahead and check your household items. Do you own products by Nestle, P&G, Johnson&Johnson, etc? Guess what, these companies are beneficiaries of the palm oil industry. As long as you brush your teeth with grocery bought toothpaste, wash your hair with Shampoo, buy snacks or any food containing oil, you're definitely part of the demand that encourages the supply.

Don't even get me started with companies producing tech items that allow us to have this conversation on the internet. Don't you see? Even if you manage to get a large number of people in your place to do something, on the other side of the planet, there's a unified effort to render all your hard work futile on a scale of a 100 times over! And what about the Oil and Gas industry? You think they wanna stop digging and switch to cleaner fuel? hah! 

And those people filling the seats of governments and the UN? fat chance! All they do is talk and produce tons of paperwork for endless summits and conferences. At the end of it all, everyone goes home while they drive their petrol cars, consume products made by palm oil companies, checking wishlists on Amazon, etc.

Oh how about let's accelerate our scientific endeavors and push revolutionary energy technology or colonizing other planets? Oh wait. Sorry, there's no budget for that. Because developing weapons and researching new ways to kill each other is far more important. We also need to divert focus towards identity politics, religion, trade wars, etc.

There is nothing defeatist about it at all. It's called REALITY!

text: This is absolute codswallop. Regardless of how the soil on grassland is managed, there is no way you will a) not emit carbon, b) offset 30+ Gt/yr of emissions.
author: Simon Clark

text:
@Simon Clark  You do not have a clue about soil organic matter, what percentage of organic matter is carbon, plant root exudates, or how quickly soil can be created using no-till management do you?

a) Carbon emission is not a problem, if net emission is negative is it?  Especially when high sequestration drives the net emissions highly negative.  Apparently, you missed the class on carbon sequestration in places like the American prairie.

b)  Each inch of soil can hold between 4 and 8 tons of carbon per acre. There are about 10 billion acres of grassland, savana, and steppe in the world.  Half of that would be 5 billion acres @ 4 tons of carbon @ a minimum of 1 inch of soil per year, which gives a minimum estimate of 20 Gt/yr.  At the high end,  you get 120 Gt/yr at a 3 inch gain in soil.  Of course, this doesn't include forest sequestration, and phytoplankton would probably dwarf both.

In any case, you should really educate yourself on soil science in general and regenerative soil science in particular.

text: @I A   Perhaps. Are you certain? Clearly there will be less exhaust emissions on city streets to breath in. However charging them at night will require vastly more electricity than is currently used. Any excess electricity production most often comes from burning natural gas or coal. Then there is the battery issue. Where do all those expended batteries go? Landfills? Batteries are filled with toxins and hazardous materials. We have to mine for the lithium and other materials to create the batteries. Like fossil fuels these materials are finite. You may be correct and perhaps electric vehicles are more environmentally friendly than internal combustion engines, but they aren't the pure and pristine environmentally friendly entities that proponents want us to believe. That is my sole point.
author: Anthony Morris
I A

text:
@I A  - So what you're saying clearly has merit. I'm not arguing against electric cars and the known advantages that you have expressed. And while I would also agree "no-one claimed that the electric cars are the smoking gun for the environmental issues" I simply have to reiterate that there is evidence that many people either don't understand, or haven't thought about the serious affects that electric vehicles will still have on the environment. You and I both know that they don't actually run on magic. 

I have seen studies that effectively demonstrate that electric vehicles are actually worse. While these various studies made perfect sense I take every single study with a grain of salt these days. Unfortunately disinformation and personal agendas are ubiquitous today. My main contentions are - that there is climate hysteria, that fossil fuels aren't quite the evil many like to promote, and that the answers surrounding "renewables" or alternatives are far more complex than people, especially the zealots, are willing to admit.
author: Anthony Morris

text:
@Anthony Morris  of course, you'right, they're still going to affect the environment.  Generally, an electric car like a Tesla is going to emit more carbon in the manufacturing process than a standard car.


However, as I've said before, when using an electric car, the outcome is going to be better for the environment. 


In terms of fossil fuels, they ain't evil but they definitely pollute. I don't know where you live but in most major cities, and especially in Asia, air pollution is a serious health hazard and an environmental hazard.
It's my personal opinion that an increased proportion of electric and hybrid cars will help the environment.


I do know that the newer combustion engines produce far far less pollution that their 1960s and 70s counter parts so they ain't entirely bad.


Personally, I don't think there's climate change 'hysteria'. We can literally see extreme rapid changes all over the world. We haven't done enough, mostly just talk. People in the Maldives and Bangladesh, for example, could potentially become climate change refugees due to the rising sea levels. Countries like the Netherlands have technology to lessen the effects but for the poorer nations, they'll most likely be affected. We're living comfortable lives in the West. It's the poor, who contributed the least to the problem, ending up paying the highest price for our actions.

author: Anthony Morris
Anthony Morris

text:
@Anthony Morris  AOC didn't make that up though. The 12 year deadline is what the world's leading climate scientists are saying. If you want to deny years of scientific research then go ahead.

I sign Bangladeshi but you're completely painting the wrong picture of Bangladesh. It's a parliamentary democracy and is a capitalist country. However, it's still a poor and young country. There isn't a single technology Bangladesh is not embracing. However, their economy is quite weak so they're not as able to cope with environmental disasters which they face on a semi-regular basis.

You ain't responsible for the creation of technological inventions made in the West just because you live in the West. However, if you use such an invention, then you're responsible for what it does to the world. 
Cars are a great invention that help us travel long distances in a short period of time. The solution isn't to ban cars, the solution is to continue to find ways to limit the negative environmental impacts that are present in the manufacture and the use of cars.

There's no point of driving a fuel-devouring pickup truck when you live in the suburbs on flat terrain and don't carry large amounts of equipment. A smaller car would suffice.

America, China and India are the biggest polluters. However, China and India have populations exceeding 1 billion while America is at around 300million. Per capita, America is polluting the most. If America can reduce its carbon footprint, the better it is for the world.

At the end of the day, as I've said before, the poor will suffer the most in the long run when they've contributed the least to the problem.

text:
@Anthony Morris  
No, we just have to change our lifestyle. I'll respond to the "positive factors" chronologically.

In fact due to weather extremes, the vegetation everywhere will have worse conditions. Also, why are your first two positive outcomes of climate change something that stops climate change?

author: Anonym 1

text:
@Anonym 1  Being cocky and arrogant isn't helpful. "don't know what I'm talking about". This is the typical strategy of dismissiveness when people don't like what they are hearing. And yet, it is you who claimed, several times, that you "don't understand". 

Not only are we continually adding to the global population, but the movement out of poverty toward mass consumerism is exponential. The lifestyle changes required to defeat climate change will be draconian. These demands, that approach absurdity will not win anybody over. Nobody wants to go back to living in a mud hut. 

The entire climate change argument becomes disingenuous when it's proponents claim catastrophe all round. "It's going to get hotter, it's going to get colder, the weather is going to become more severe or extreme" etc. 

The fossil record clearly shows that tropical plants thrived above the arctic circle. The largest herbivores the planet has ever seen lived during these high Co2 periods. All plant and animal life from bugs to bears are all migrating north. This is already happening and will simply continue. Greenland will actually be green. It's already happening. 

A warming climate isn't going to cause tropical diseases to spread. Malaria is a poverty issue not a climate issue. There is no malaria in Miami. Wealthy nations, that utilize inexpensive energy will continue to advance technology, science and medicine. However, poverty will undoubtedly grow (along with malaria) if we destroy economies because of climate hysteria. 

Just a note, salt is effective because it melts snow and ice. Gravel or sand may help with traction but just creates a mucky mess. Hundreds of people died in winter storms just this week alone and the economic costs are horrendous. 

The "corps" ??  

Grizzly bear habitat is growing due to climate change along with a myriad of other animals. Less people destroy less animal habitat. The destruction of plant and animal habitat is no contest when you compare human activity and the climate. 150,000,000 sharks are slaughtered every year by humans. To the best of my knowledge the climate hasn't killed a single shark. Where is the hysteria over this slaughterfest? This is the epitome of the irrationality of climate hysteria. 150,000,000 sharks compared to a few starving polar bears who's numbers have stayed the same for 50 years. 

The entire agricultural and horticultural community along with biologists have already conclusively declared that rising Co2 has been a boon for plant life on earth. So perhaps it is you who doesn't understand this subject.
author: Anthony Morris

text: @Anthony Morris  "This is the typical strategy of dismissiveness when people don't like what they're hearing". text:
Few, if any of the models, include spontaneous emission of methane from subsea clathrates (methane hydrates), terrestrial bogs and permafrost,  or from "overfracking"....where the shale layer is fractured through it's thickness such that methane is freed into the overburden, slowly and inevitably exiting the ground over large areas and long timeframes.  There is a video of an Australian rancher whose station is surrounded by gas wells and he shows the gas emissions.  If there are sufficient hydroxyl radicals or methophagic bacteria in the ground, much of the methane breaks down, is oxidized, and then you get CO2 bubbles.  Better, but not good.  
The "natural" heating events of the last 800,000 years occurred when the sea began to emit CO2 after a period of neutral uptake.  Uptake slows as the average heat of the ocean increases.  Then it stops for a while, neither absorbing or releasing CO2.  Then the kill shot begins, the rate of CO2 emissions will be amplified by the rapidly increasing heat, with the atmosphere receiving not only the "natural" CO2, but the continued assault by carbon fuel emissions.  And methane decomposition.  And weathering of rock by acidic rain.  The dead zones forming NOW in the seas such as the Caribbean Sea will emit H2S which is toxic.  You will feel ill if you breathe air with 40 ppm hydrogen sulfide.  Incapacitated at around 150 ppm and dead at 200 ppm.  H2S is thought to have played a role as the coup de grace of the end Permian Mass Extinction event.  Perhaps others of the 5 Mass Extinctions we know about.  This is going to be the sixth, and I don't see any way to even do minimal effective mitigation.  Keep looking.  And DO something.  It may be that the ONLY job anyone will have in a few years is in mitigation or repair of the planet.  Nothing that is incompatible with survival would be allowed, and everything that enhances survival will be mandatory.  The old Soviet model... "Anything not forbidden is mandatory".  All hands on deck, everybody on a combat ship also does damage control duty.

text:
We might get lucky though, sun activity is very slowly decreasing (we should be getting closer and closer to a drop in sun's activity that would normally cause an ice-age), so the results might vary. To be honest, the main argument against pumping CO2 into atmosphere is "we cannot forsee how will the ecosystems change, so better stop doing that to avoid something potentially catastrophic" rather than "we know for sure, that this, that and that will happen if we raise temperatures by X".

Still, reducing emissions is a reasonable thing to do, but I kinda hate when people say "scientists predict", when the overall system is so complex, that in long time period almost anything can happen, if you tweak the parameters just slightly, and even a small error might compound into huge difference. There is so much we do not know about climate in general, that we can only make rough predictions like "oceans will rise" and "the areas of low habitability will cover greater extent of the earth, widening deserts". 

When it comes to getting CO2 out of the atmosphere, the cost needs to go to the level of proposed emission taxes. I believe currently the suggested level is no more than 30 Euros per tonne, so if we bring down the average cost to this level then it might become viable. But it is true that right now it is prohibitively expensive.

text:
The problem today is, the world is already polarised and opinionated. There are people who believe in the science and the proof that global warming and climate change is an impending disaster or their are those who will never believe that this is true.

The people in the second category are those of the type who would believe in theories like flat earth, anti-vaxxers and any other conspiracy theory and would rather sit on their asses and watch the world burn and die rather than take any action. A US senator brought snow from outside after a snowfall to refute the proofs of global warming. Trump stated that since they had the coldest temperature in few decades in NYC after the bomb cyclone last year, global warming is a hoax and fake. There's nothing that can be done to these people to educate them. They are already opinionated, that they know the truth. They will always believe in that nut job on Facebook who spews conspiracy theories about how global warming is a hoax rather than believe on the peer reviewed journals. All, we can do with them is wait and watch them use up oxygen, release CO2 and die and hope they haven't poisoned their children enough and that they will listen to their science teacher and accept about global warming.

As educated and learned people, what we can do is take action and say that nuclear power is the only option going forward. Solar and wind are good alternatives but they can't meet the requirements throughout the year. Shut down all coal fired power plants and switch to public transport or electric vehicles. If we all just accept nuclear power and move ahead with it, since it doesn't produce any CO2 emissions, we would at least a world for our future generations.

As someone had said: we don't live in a world inherited from our forefathers but a world borrowed from our grandchildren. Peace!

text:
One single problem gets many climate experts to stutter: CO2 and other gases are, gases. The numbers about its quantity do account for their actual concentration.
Simple problem to illustrate the idea:
O2 is O2. CO2 is more than O2. It occupies some more space. Nitrogen, water vapor, and even the minor Helium, all have different weights, volumes and coefficients which end up being how close or far the molecules are under a given pressure, which also happens to alter with temperature.
When you study those, you know that the impact of man made gas emissions that arent just "get the o2 there, stick a C on it and release the CO2", you know that we cant, by virtue of our own lack of capabilities in transforming by hand the elements, make all that impact on nature. We can be handled by the Earth just fine. It is us that cant handle the Earth.

text:
FYI, do a google search for "Prehistoric sea levels".  And look at the graph.  We are at one of the historic lows of all time right now.  The other prehistoric low occurred during the kaloo glaciation...aka the previous ice age.  We are currently in an ice age.  But this is the most important fact about ice ages...they are one of Earth's deadliest extinction events BUT for terrestrial animals they are still; the best.  
Humans have become what we are during one of natures extreme glaciation events.  Meaning that we are actually blessed to be in an ice age.  When all of the glaciers finally melt the ice age will end BUT the sea will be 250 to 300 feet higher.  I really don't know if having calm warm weather from the north pole to the south pole is worth having only 15% of the surface being above water.  I think we are blessed to exist during this current ice age called the Quaternary Glaciation.

text:
NASA and NOAA admit to 'adjusting' temperature readings downwards from before 1980 (and they also adjust current temperatures upward though they are less open about that), and those adjustments smooth out and LOWER the readings to fit a profile that suit the global warming regime. If you ACTUALLY go back and see the unadjusted data, temperatures having yo-yo'd around a the mean (with MASSIVE unbelievable heat spikes in the 30s and a 30yr trend downwards from the late 40s to the late 70s hence the global cooling fears) and the temperature hasn't increased at all since the Civil War era. Christ the hockey stick guy's (Michael Mann) climate model going back in time completely 'smoothed out' the mini ice age of the 16th/17th Century and the much warmer than today temps from about the late 13th C til the early 16th C! CO2 fundamentally does not have a large scale impact on temperature and historically is the EFFECT of warmer, not the cause. If anything it leads to a greening of the planet and increased plant life moderates temperature! I understand that a giant forest fire outside LA has a bigger mental impact then actually looking at dry stats, but honestly the truth is at your fingertips if you actually bother to look. 

Remember, this guy is a PhD in atmospheric physics - if he doesn't agree with the 'consensus' then he won't get published; if he doesn't get published then he has no career; if he has no career then he is clerk at the local grocery store for all the good his degree is worth. It's self-preservation for so many of these scientists...

(As an aside, while I don't see evidence that CO2 is a problem nor that the planet is warming, it would be great to clamp down on pollution and the creation of toxic materials - 10 fingers and toes behind that).

text: The 1930s heat spike was unique to the U.S., which represents less than five percent of the world's land mass, irrelevant when measuring worldwide climate over the course of years. The 40s to the 70s was the peak of our spewing of sulfate aerosols (especially from coal plants), which have been shown to reflect sunlight and cool the atmosphere. The CleanAir Act in 1970 put a curb on sulfate aerosols, and C02 again became the dominant pollutant, triggering renewed warming.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

text:
IF it was unique to the US, why does it also show up in Antarctica? Why does it show up in Africa glaciers? Why does it show up in the river deltas of india? Why does it show up in the sea floor beds cores of the south pacific?

The fact is, there is a 60 year cycle that shows up everywhere. 30 years of warming and 30 years of "cooling". The 1930's was the peak of that cycle and so was the 1990's. IF you had been around in the 1980's you would remember a major argument about who NASA and other groups that are now called alarmist lowered the recorded temperatures of the 1930's and previous decades. text:
No, it is NOT called cherry picking data. Cherry picking is when you LIMIT the data, such as ONLY taking data for 70 years and pretending what you measure did not happen before.

Cherry picking is saying that the artic lost 60% of the ice since the 1970's and blaming it on co2 increasing, totally ignoring the fact that the melt started AT LEAST by 1902. THAT is when we have the first survey of the artic ice. 90% of the ice that was present then has disappeared. The 40% of what is still left, is only 10% of what was there at the turn of the century. That's a quarter of the loss. Which means that more than half the ice disappeared BEFORE co2 was a problem.

Do alarmist notice the fact that co2 did not cause half the loss? No, it would ruin their narrative.

Here is another factor they ignore. 1900's was the bottom of a 60 year cycle, meaning it was the coldest the artic got. Then it warmed up. Then it cooled and the 1970's was the bottom of the next cycle. What we have not after it has recovered slightly, is what the surveys of the 1950's showed.

No, using ALL the data is not cherry picking, but that does not fit your alarmist agenda.

Here is another version of cherry picking. Alarmist use certain areas to try to prove sea levels are rising at alarming rates. Almost every one of those sites are sinking. Some due to removal of water from aquafers below the land, and others due to glacial isostatic adjustment. Do they acknowledge that sinking?

No that would not fit their narrative. They carefully cherry pick their data to fit their narrative.

Then when you do not accept their data unquestioned, you call it cherry picking.

text:
Perhaps I should explain why your argument can not hold water. Centuries ago, they did not have electron microscopes or even basic microscopes. They did not have thermometers, or even instruments of anything we would describe as such. They were not even called scientist, since that term had not been invented yet. What they had was brains, eyes, tongues ears and noses. They also had the sense of touch.

They began to record things, and categories their findings, the correlated them. People saw them as experts. So they began to discuss with each other what they found, and they sent messages back and forth. Eventually magazines were created and the began to tell people about their discoveries. In the beginning most people did not know anything about it, because most people could not read or write, but they did not matter. They had important job that did not require reading. They kept people alive. As time went on, people thought up ways to fake science, and in some cases, they got away with it for a long time.

So these people came up with a set of things to prevent accidental or deliberate corruption of science (although it was not called that yet) In times these were updated again and again as more people thought of new ways to fake science. These things were eventually known as "standard scientific procedures.

Experts in the field still held sway though. If someone came along with a theory that was radical, they would do their best to destroy it. ONLY after they had tried for decades or even centuries were a lot of these accepted. Even the laws of science, as they were called, got questioned all the time and much learning came from exploiting this questioning. For the most part, laws are almost impossible to destroy, but it is possible to modify them if the knowledge comes along that improves the understanding of them.

Then instruments were invented and our learning was improved. Many things that were believed before were questioned because of the new instruments. Some long held beliefs were destroyed completely, replaced by new knowledge, but that replacement did not happen quickly. Every thing had to be tested, questioned, tested again and question more. Over time, many theories were proven to be hoaxes. This happened because people stuck to using standard scientific procedures and those were constantly questioned and updated.

All the while, experts were learning and teaching new people. And they were writing and letting others see their work.

When someone can prove his knowledge to older experts, he becomes and expert. So every expert in any field we have today is expert that has been vetted by other experts and their data has been accepted and questioned and tested and proven.

Then along comes so called climatologist. These people declare that their field is so new that they can only be vetted by each other. People publishing articles about glaciology said that because it was about climatology, they did not need to show it to glaciologist. An astrophysics climatologist could just as easily review it. That astrophysics climatologist proved he was an expert by publishing and article and instead of having it published in astrophysics peer review published it in a magazine that was wide spectrum science, and having it reviewed by a geologist climatologist. That climatologist proved he was an expert by having his work reviewed by a glaciologist climatologist. The same one above. Each one reviewed an area outside his expertise and didn't say a word about glaring holes because he wanted his own work approved.

So no previously vetted expert ever vetted their articles and they were accepted. They were not reviewed by peers because as climatologist, they saw themselves as having no peers outside of climatology.

That is why these people can not be published in science specific peer review journals, because the experts in those fields would tear them apart.

They will not tear each other articles apart because they do not want theirs blocked.

text:
@robert hicks  Google GRIDDED MONTHLY SEA ICE EXTENT AND CONCENTRATION, 1850 ONWARDS, the most comprehensive and up-to-date compilation of historical data, with contributions by The Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute of Russia, the U.S. Navy, the UK Met Office, the Danish Met Institute's Yearbook Maps, and others. Their graph of sea ice extent as measured every September shows a small shift early in the 20th century, followed by a long, flat plateau  and then a sharp drop in the last 30 years. From the study, which was compiled last year, I quote: "There is no point in the past 150 years where sea ice extent is as small as it has been in  recent years. Second, the rate of sea ice retreat in recent years is unprecedented in the historical record." If you wish to argue with all of the world's snow and ice data centers, feel free. 


But more than this, too many who claim to know what's going on utterly ignore Arctic ice THICKNESS and VOLUME, the truest measure of climate warming. 95% of the Arctic's thickest ice is now broken up, according to NASA and other highly credible sources. Watch NASA TIME LAPSE VIDEO OF ARCTIC ICE to see the oldest, thickest ice vanish before your eyes.  Ice extent returns every winter, sometimes in large swaths, sometimes in smaller ones. That ice will be forming for decades to come and is not an accurate measure of warming.


As far as subsidence goes, parts of the western side of Miami Beach are subsiding where mangroves were torn out and replaced with fill. Harold Wanless, a geologist at the University of Miami is quoted as saying that "sinking is a non-issue on the greater portion of Miami Beach." Sea level, he said, is the greater concern. He added that subsidence is temporary and stops after a few decades, and is going to be overwhelmed by sea level rise.


"In Miami Beach, our city surveyor is out there every day, working in the city and he has not observed subsidence or any changes in elevation," says Elizabeth Wheaton, Director of Environment And Sustainability. She says that surveyors are using fixed control points to ensure they're getting an accurate read on rising seas. "There's so much misinformation about what's happening," she says. "The sea levels are rising," despite what people are reading on the Internet. The latest NASA measurements agree.

3. CO2 is NOT a pollutant, we’re all made of CO2, it’s how living things grow
4. CO2 doesn’t effect weather, weather effects CO2 production
5. Humans produce a small fraction (in the single digits percentage wise) of CO2 in the atmosphere

Volcanoes produce more CO2 each year than all of man made CO2 production, animals and bacteria produce even more, and more than that dying vegetation, but the biggest source of CO2 by far is the ocean

This is simple stuff to find out people

text: Veganism isn't going to save the world. Even if it could, it's not going to happen. Global demand for meat products, and every other carbon intensive aspect of life in an industrialized society, will continue to grow. People who are already living in developed nations aren't going to give up their lifestyles, and people in developing nations aren't going to stop trying to catch up. Climate change, water, and food shortages aside, we'll likely begin running out many of our finite resources, such as those used in electronics, including smart and green technology, towards the end of the century. The sad truth is that the world has too many people on it. The best thing anyone can do to mitigate climate change, and most of our other problems, is to not reproduce.

text: You had me until the "Don't eat meat." Livestock have a symbiotic relationship with the land. Chickens, geese, cows, pigs... are not what is causing global warming/climate change. Humans are. If you revisit the graphs of how CO2 emission increased  after the industrial age, you might take into consideration that livestock did not contribute to coal entering the atmosphere, electricity being discovered, and the combustion engine becoming the replacement for the steam engine. If you REALLY think about it. Animal Husbandry has been around since cavemen thought of an easier way to hunt. The graph is pretty level until the Industrial age arrives. A more clever way of eliminating the CO2 from the atmosphere is to stop using things with electricity that are not powered by solar or wind generated power plants. Another clever way is to stop using an automobile and stop purchasing things that are not local to your own community. Meat isn't the problem. Animals have been on the planet just as long as humans.
author: Derek Miller

text: Another issue that needs to be considered with trying to offset emissions is permafrost thawing.  The thawing of the permafrost will produce amounts of carbon that will dwarf our emissions and will not be anything we can control.  That also has to include methane release from the Arctic when the permafrost thaws that is the cap for massive amounts of methane hydrates off the Siberian coast as well as the methane produced by the decomposition of organic matter frozen within the permafrost under anaerobic conditions.   The permafrost is thawing now at the temperature level we are currently at.  It will thaw even faster under higher temperatures which will produce an unstoppable abrupt change in the climate that reinforces itself with no emissions by human activity.

text:
I had written out a lengthy comment to your video without having actually watched it. A mistake I hope no one else here is making, but something tells me many will. I guess the problem is still that many will take the title of this video and many of the news we are getting as "just give up" - and we can't. Not now and not ever. We will need to do whatever is possible in terms of science, implementation, and activism. Money cannot be a factor, shouldn't be if all of our lives and the life of the planet are at stake. Money is a human construct. So why is there even a price on removing carbon from the atmosphere? Who is making that price? And in the light of what is at risk, what is stopping us from demanding that there be none? Who will benefit from all that money and why isn't the planet more important to them? Let's face it, if it wasn't for money and human greed, we wouldn't be in this mess to begin with.

I know that you are a scientist, so you don't deal with the personal aspects of this quite as much in light of the big picture, but as individuals, we can do more than just stop eating meat and taking the bus. I think that for scientists and those who can make it happen, carbon removal without a price tag should be the goal. For the rest of us, protesting and boycotting the corporations that are responsible for most of our CO2 waste - and thus making them change -  is the answer.

Don't just take the bus: Take the bus AND both boycott and protest car and fuel companies. Make it crystal clear to them that without you, the consumer, nothing goes. That they would be poor without you, because money is the only language they understand. 
However, we know the truth: That life is what truly matters, and that everything else is secondary, especially money. 

Single individuals can and have staged entire protests, started entire movements. It is possible and doable, and much, much easier than you think if you put your mind to it. Every single person in this comment section can take down an entire company. Together, we can take down entire industries if we really want to.

text:
@Nhoj737  Fact: Ice is colder than the average ocean temperature.
Fact: Heating any material stores energy in that material.
Fact: The average temperature of a body includes every part of that body. 
Fact: The body called the earth includes the water and the glaciers. Moving one to the other causes the average temperature to increase.

Conclusion: Melting tons of ice into water and raising it to increase in temperature 15°C average for the ocean, means average temperature of the earth goes up. I do not know the temperature of the ice, except it is 0°C or less.

The earth is increasing in temperature about .009°C a year. IF the average increase of water is 18°, that means for every ton of ice that is melted and the water raised to the average temperature of the earth, the increase in temperature of 2000 tons of earth is accounted for. Alaska by itself loses 75 BILLION tons of water. that 7x10^10. Multiply that by 2x10^3 and Alaska accounts for 1.4x10^13 of the earths warming every year. Antarctica accounts for 3 times that much. Greenland almost 5. The arctic 10 x OR MORE. Add the rest of the glaciers and the permafrost and you have a large portion of the increase. Now add that the ocean, 70% of the surface of the earth has warmed 3° (nasa shows that has happen fairly recently) and there is no room for co2 to have cause much if any of the warming.

author: Nhoj737

text:
@Nhoj737  The sun. It warms the land around the ice and the heat is conducted into the ice melting it.

The earth like a heat version of the battery. It stores heat in water. When a battery charges goes down, the chemicals in the batter change. When the earth loses heat, the water freezes. When the battery is recharged, the chemical change again, to ones that can hold the charge. When the earth warms the ice melts.

The sun is giving us more or less then same energy it has for the last 2000 years. About 1500 years ago, something happened that reflected the suns energy away from the earth surface. This meant that when the summer sun tried to melt the ice, there was not enough energy to do so, at least not as much as had laid down the previous winter. This meant the glaciers expanded. The suns energy was the same, it just could not reach the land. Then 350 years ago, the cause (choose which of several possibilities, but the evidence said it was there) of the reflection stopped and the earth received more energy. The ice no longer built up but instead the heat melted more ice than the winter snows could deposit.

At the same time (little ice age), the ocean lost energy to space when water was vaporized and the energy radiated into space. Because what every was reflecting the sun's energy was above the oceans as well, they stopped getting the energy that they needed to replace that lost to the vaporization and they cooled. Then when the cause disappeared, the ocean began to receive more energy and they began to warm. Since both of these are part of the earth, their temperatures is included in that average.

text:
1. "Entire nations will be wiped off the map by rising sea levels by theyear 2000" 
The quote was made by Noel Brown, an official at the UN, and it was an indirect quote as far as I can see. However, you seem to misrepresent the indirect quote because you replace the word "could" with "will," and you leave out "if global warming is not reversed" between the words "levels" and "by," thus implying that (1) there is not stopping it and that (2) such a catastrophic event will occur by the year 2000 rather than sometime later after 2000 if no great action is taken by 2000. As this video demonstrates, climate change is pretty much irreversible, so he's not wrong if he did say that since there is still much time to find out, and as Dr. Hansen said, there has been more goals than actions. That said, Noel Brown is not the best source of information.

2. "Or that one time 10 years ago when NASA scientist James Hansen said that Obama only had 4 years to fix it..."
The quote by Dr. Hansen is misleading. He made it right before Obama's inauguration, so Dr. Hansen was referring to Obama's term in which he can take action, and it wasn't a climate prediction. Dr. Hansen has since been quite critical of Obama because of Obama's lack of great action, and he will talk about it in his upcoming book.

3. "Or that one time in 1972 when they warned us for global cooling (Yes, you read that right, go look it up)"
Who is they? Scientists aren't some infallible monolithic being and they can mean 1 person or 1000 persons, so it's important to specify who. That said, most of the papers published during that time predicted warming. For more information, take a look at this paper: http://ams.confex.com/ams/pdfpapers/131047.pdf

4. "Or what about before that, in the 1950s when there was the global warming scare again?"
Since this was a "scare," it probably isn't very reliable. How about taking a look at the papers published during that time. eg. http://www.rescuethatfrog.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Plass-1956e.pdf

5. "Nevermind the fact that it's been proven beyond a shadow of a doubt that the IPCC is falsifying statistics left and right.... Oh you haven't heard of this? I know, you're reflex is to ask me for links. You lazy shit. And you wonder why people are ill informed. Hilarious."
What I find particularly ironic about this claim that the IPCC tells us that it's modified, how it's modified, and why it is modified, which means you don't understand those reasons, in which case you are probably ill-informed of climate science, you don't know those reasons, in which case you are ill-informed, or you are told that it has been "falsified" and you believe it, in which case you are also ill-informed. And why are you so hostile to sharing your sources? Wouldn't that attitude breed even more ignorance?

6. "But hey, the mainstream media is not in control of a handfull of people and they would never lie to you.... Amirite?"
Who are the five people in control of all mainstream media outlets? In addition, even if they lied, you can check their sources and reveal that lie, in which case they will likely retract that claim since that's journalistic practice. Alternative media is not better, however, and can sometimes be worse.

7. "Let's totally forget that the earth has never in recorded history been this green due to CO2 increases (source: NASA)"
In the NASA press release, they say:
"While rising carbon dioxide concentrations in the air can be beneficial for plants, it is also the chief culprit of climate change. The gas, which traps heat in Earth’s atmosphere, has been increasing since the industrial age due to the burning of oil, gas, coal and wood for energy and is continuing to reach concentrations not seen in at least 500,000 years. The impacts of climate change include global warming, rising sea levels, melting glaciers and sea ice as well as more severe weather events.

The beneficial impacts of carbon dioxide on plants may also be limited, said co-author Dr. Philippe Ciais, associate director of the Laboratory of Climate and Environmental Sciences, Gif-suv-Yvette, France. 'Studies have shown that plants acclimatize, or adjust, to rising carbon dioxide concentration and the fertilization effect diminishes over time.' "

8. "Hmm... I guess thats what that 2.5 kg CO2 bottle is doing hooked up to my heavily planted aquarium which grows so fast I literally have to trim kilo's every month. Nah, with all those predictions and absolutely nothing fishy going on, I'm feeling confident in saying: Well, they may not have known before when they thought they knew it all, but surely they do know now. You can only be wrong so many times, amirite?"
Again, scientists aren't some monolithic being spouting one viewpoint. 1, 2, and 3 are misleading, and 4 is kind of idiotic.

9. "And whatever you do, never look into solar forcing, and how papers are coming out on a daily basis completely disproving the old concensus that 'The sun only varies 0,1% in it's output' "
I'm not sure what you are referring to here. Do you have an example of a paper published today? You don't need to link it; just cite it.

text:
I didn't watch this all the way through, I was anticipating more.  While you are correct that the climate change is locked in, what you fail to mention is that in the year 3000, life as we know it will have been LOOOOOONNNNNGGG gone. 

The Arctic ice might last until 2022.......but, probably not.    Once that ice is gone, it is going to alter the jet stream in strange ways.   While they don't know, or can't say how exactly it's going to react, the best guess is that it's going to shift it's center of rotation to be over Greenland, instead of the North Pole. This will be because at that point, Greenland will become the coldest point of the northern hemisphere, and.....well...heat always,  flows from warm to cold, so, logically, once the Arctic ice is gone, and is warmer than Greenland, the jet stream will shift its center of rotation around Greenland.   Makes sense to me.    This of course will only be during the time that the Arctic is actually warmer than Greenland, which will be for a very short period of time, the first time it goes ice free, but will last longer and longer each year, until it's eventually ice free year round, which will likely be around ten years after the first blue ocean event. 

What that will mean for our crops, is most likely disaster, on a global scale.   No matter where you grow crops, if it's too hot, too cold, too wet, or too dry, that is the end for your crops.   The jet stream is already completely messed up.   Once it shifts its rotation center, the weather is likely to be even more crazy than it already is......to say the least. 

Who knows?   It could even everything out, and make perfect weather everywhere!   They don't know.....that's pretty much impossible to predict.    But, they do know it's going to change things, likely in a largely unfavorable way, and it's going to happen very, very soon. 

It's kind of hard to feed 8 billion people without food.

The Sun's radiation reaching the Earth has been DECREASING* since 1980 while global temperatures have been INCREASING. An inverse correlation.

"Further since 1998 we observe a slight cooling,"
Wrong again Meng, the planet has been warming since 1998 and even most climate change deniers accept that fact.  The four warmest years on record are 2014, 2015, 2016, & 2017.  2018 is on track to come in as #4.  1998 will drop to #6 on the list of warmest years.

Not hardly.  We only have good global temp data since 1880 so looking at the past 40 years is actually a pretty fair time frame.

"There are studies out there showing the very long term (millions of years) fluctuation in temp and CO2."
Yup and since I lecture on this topic I bet that I am far more up to date on this literature than you are.  I know what these CO2 levels were during the Devonian, the Permian and the Carboniferous.  Do you or are you just parroting talking points from talk radio?
For example did you know that based on the Vostok ice core data that average rate of CO2 change for the past half million years is 2 ppm per one thousand years.  Did you know that since 1958 we have data from the Mauna Loa data set that the rate of CO2 change is 2 ppm per year?  A rate that is 1000X the natural rate of change.

Do you think it is possible to drive a car 100,000 km/hr and think that nothing bad is going to happen?

*I beg you not to site Milankovich cycles, solar cycles, solar radiance levels or volcanic activity because all of these are either flat or INVERSELY correlated with the observed INCREASE in global temps.  I get so tired of drubbing those sad moles and even a third grader can see that there are no non-human forcings that can account of the observed rise in temps over that period of time.  Remember too, thermal conditions do NOT have momentum, so simply saying that "We are coming out of an ice age" is equally sophomoric and stupid.

text:
@flahammerhead  We have climate records for hundreds of millions of years of Earth's history. Yes, the climate changes, but never has it changed so much in 200 years. The level of CO2 change we see in the sedimentary rock record takes place over hundreds of thousands to millions of years. The last time CO2 levels were this high was over 3 million years ago.

You're the one who denies all the science. You're the one with an easily debunkable hypothesis. Climate Change is almost universally regarded by scientists as absolute fact, and those who publish evidence against are always shown to be working for industry with an agenda or are otherwise disreputable. Climate research has been going on for 50 years, and predicts the end of the world. You'll be claiming we have an agenda to push, well, what is it? Who's agenda are we pushing for no good reason if none of this is real? 

What the literal fuck are you on? "CO2 is needed for plant growth". No shit Sherlock, you're god damn right. Holy shit, guess more CO2 means more goodness! No, you utterly ignorant fool. We're not trying to push CO2 below 150ppm, why would you claim that? Why would we want to plunge ourselves into an ice age? But 400ppm is too high.

Let's have a test:

Do you accept that a CO2 molecule in the atmosphere absorbs radiation emitted from the earth and radiates it back, thus heating the planet?

Do you accept that with a given amount of CO2 in the atmosphere, there is an equilibrium temperature for the earth?

Do you accept therefore, that with more CO2, especially an increase in levels of over 50% (280 to 400 ppm), would have a clearly noticeable change on this equilibrium temperature?

text:
Ignorance  and self delusion are already irreversible for some it seems. Einstein once said " you dont need a 100 scientists to prove me wrong (on  Relativity). All it takes is just one who can present credible evidence to the contrary!" So to all those who claim "we believe in the science" please present one credible piece of irrefutable evidence that proves beyond a reasonable doubt that there is a direct causation (not a mere correlation) between atmospheric CO2 and climate change.
As an example of irrefutable evidence I cite a number of papers that prove not beyond a reasonable doubt, but beyond any doubt, that increasing CO2 to 600ppm in greenhouse experiments has doubled plant growth. You do realise that CO2 is not a pollutant but fundamentally important to photosynthesis and heaven forbid,  all CARBON BASED LIFEFORMS? 
Then if u dare, please show that the fraction that comes from fossil fuels, is the prime suspect. Hint: forget about actual physical evidence, all you need to do is program another computer model that accounts
 for deforestation, wild fires, urbanization, undersea volcanoes, sunspot activity, polar shifts, earthquakes and continental drift. What chance then of actually making an accurate prediction? Now that will be a first!  https://www.climatecentral.org/news/study-finds-plant-growth-surges-as-co2-levels-rise-16094​

text:
@Almighty Bunny  I didn't read all the comments, so I don't know if you changed your pessimistic view later or the two years since the posting of your comment, so take my comment in that context.

I don't like your pessimistic view on this, I really don't. I am not saying it's wrong, it really seems that our time in the limelight is coming to an end.
But does that really matter? If we are to die out then why not try living as morally and wisely as we can and then let the world decide our fate, whether we deserve to live or die out.

If the human condition has doomed our civilization to die, then I take it the same way I take my own upcoming death, it's gonna happen one way or another sooner or later, the most I can do is to be as wise and good as I can be, and maybe push the people around to be the same, but in the end what they do is not in my control. I will fail,they will fail and we all will fail, sooner or later, but isn't it better than not trying at all?

TLDR; Remember the quote "Death smiles at us all, most we can do is smile back", just apply to the scale of a civilisation, accept the upcoming demise and keep promoting what you think is good and right, to yourself and others.

author: Gonzalo Calvo

text:
OK I will tell you who I am.  I am a Ph.D. scientist who gives climate change lectures to the general public about 30 times a year and I have been doing so for about a decade.  I regularly engage with online climate deniers like you who say "It is the Sun stupid!!" and ask them to provide data to back up their statement.  Specifically I ask for solar data to explain the observed increase in global temps since 1980 and how that corresponds with observed temperature measurements over that same period of time.  I then keep track of how many of them a) try to provide data to support their assertion, b) provide data that actually does support the observed temperature measurements and c) those who prevaricate, dodge, and otherwise do everything they can to avoid being caught in their lie.  After doing this for nearly three years the numbers are:
a) 12
b) 0
c) 72

Thanks for participating in my survey (I share the results with my audiences). Congratulations Mr. Perez*, you have now boosted the number of "c" to 73 and helped to confirm my theory that climate change deniers spend most of their time parroting each other and rarely, if ever, bother to dig into the data to try and defend their positions (which are based on ideology and not science)!

Have a nice life of self denial.

*May I quote you and your responses in my next presentation?

author: zentanith

text:
@zentanith  
“For climate change, there are many scientific organizations that study the climate. These alphabet soup of organizations include NASA, NOAA, JMA, WMO, NSIDC, IPCC, UK Met Office, and others. Click on the names for links to their climate-related sites. There are also climate research organizations associated with universities. These are all legitimate scientific sources.

If you have to dismiss all of these scientific organizations to reach your opinion, then you are by definition denying the science. If you have to believe that all of these organizations, and all of the climate scientists around the world, and all of the hundred thousand published research papers, and physics, are all somehow part of a global, multigenerational conspiracy to defraud the people, then you are, again, a denier by definition. 

So if you deny all the above scientific organizations there are a lot of un-scientific web sites out there that pretend to be science. Many of these are run by lobbyists (e.g.., Climate Depot, run by a libertarian political lobbyist, CFACT), or supported by lobbyists (e.g., JoannaNova, WUWT, both of whom have received funding and otherwise substantial support by lobbying organizations like the Heartland Institute), or are actually paid by lobbyists to write Op-Eds and other blog posts that intentionally misrepresent the science.”
https://thedakepage.blogspot.co.uk/2016/12/how-to-assess-climate-change.html

text:
Walking for short trips and bicycles are good for trips longer than 10 miles. I walked and rode bicycles year round in Minnesota (Lows to -30f) and in Miami Florida. I am NOT superman, it is  only a lifestyle change. 
There are lots of things that will greatly lower CO2 output. 
Stop drinking bottled water. The plastic bottles are very bad.
Put bottles of water in the empty space in fridge and freezer. 
If building a house, have lots of opening windows and turn off the air conditioner.
Use plug-in strips with on-off switch. Some device always consume energy when plugged in.
If you live in the country, look in to goats instead of a lawn mower.

The point is, his defintion is totally wrong. He insist that a theory has 100% fact, but it does not. It may be based on facts, but if one of the fact is proven to be wrong, then the theory is wrong. Facts are things like "water is heavier than air". Theories are based on things such as suppositions. In the case of agw, it is based on the atmosphere having a sensitivity of greater than 2°C. IF the atmospheric sensitivity is less than .5°, then man is not responsible for global warming. Every model based on sensitivity of greater than .5 have been proven wrong because they can not track the temperature changes.

In the 1940's they had started looking for patterns in the climate, and discovered that the British Royal Navy had tracked temperature world wide since the early 1800's. In the more than 100 years of records, they found there was 60 year cycle they could not explain at the time. They also found that every 60 years, the temperatures went up for 30 years, and it was about .6° in the 30 years, then a cooling of about .05° in 30 years.

So they theories that something was causing a normal .09° per decade .9°C per century). So they started looking for what could be causing it. They came up with the idea of glaciers melting. Ice absorbs energy and becomes water, then the water absorbs more energy and increase in temperature. They got the Allied military, who had a lot of aircraft crews needing training and not much to train them on, to take pictures of glaciers so they could get an accurate reading on how much ice there was. They then calculated the loss of ice and the heating of that water. The result was they found the 0.09° that was causing global warming.

This means that the theory of glacial melt causing global warming has 100% fact supporting it. 

Agw as a theory has "facts" that have been disproven to be true. Yet it is still kept.

text:
"how the fuck can you explain all the fires that have been happening " Have you noticed that those fires only happen in California? That's because the other states and other countries use antifire procedures that are prohibited by California law because they "remove the natural beauty of the forest". Instead of the Forest Department being able to do controlled burns to get rid of under bush and dead trees, California governor Brown refused to allow it because it was better to be part of nature. Then when the fires happen, there is no controlling them.

"all those weather extremes all over the world?" Not a single weather extreme is unusual. Hurricanes are SLIGHTLY fewer than before (not statistically significantly), forest fires (outside of California) are smaller and fewer than other decades, droughts are smaller duration and weaker intensity than history shows them to be. Tornadoes are down, esp. the more powerful ones. There are fewer cold snaps than ever, and fewer heat waves.

Obviously you have no clue what caused the Holocene maximum. The planet goes though what is called the Milankovitch cycle. This is where the earth is in the best position of the earth to receive the most energy. That means it is closest to the sun and at the best angle for the earth to absorb energy.

During the Holocene maximum, the southern pole was pointed in the right direction to receive the most heat BUT it was farther away from the sun. So yes, it received less energy than it would now. BUT the over all effect is that we got 3% more energy year round than we do now. In 5000 years, we will get 3% less energy year round than we do now. THAT will put us in a full blown glaciation.

So yes, the Holocene Maximum DID matter.

For one thing, there is not that much land in the southern hemisphere as the north. That means life is not affected as much now as it was then when the north was getting the most energy.

"For instance, there was way more oxygen in the jurassic period" Yes, and a lot more co2 for the plants to grown and thus more food for animals.

What you do not seem to understand is the co2 is NECESSARY for plants and we are so low they are starving. The reason o2 is so low is the plants are not getting the co2 they need.

Yes, animals of the Jurassic period would not survive today, because there is no enough plants for them to survive on, not to mention that since the Himalayan mountains were created, the temperature has been too cold for animals like that.

That is why we are in an ice age. The Himalayans froze because they got so high and Antarctica froze because its over the south pole and the water does not circulate there because of that. This keeps the continent frozen. The frozen ice causes the planet to cool. THAT is what limits the temperature, not co2.

" It's science. Just like climate change." Answer this. IF it is science why do they REFUSE to use antifraud standard scientific procedures?

The first thing you are taught in science (or used to be) is that if you change your system of measurement it will always lead to failure. Here is a simple example. One of my science teachers used baking as an example. He showed us the recipe for a cake, and had us (as a class) bake one. The thing is, while we were measuring it, in the middle he switch the measuring instruments from English to metric. The result was a totally ruined cake. Try it if you do not believe. Try to bake a cake using English measurements for the first half of the ingredients and metric for the last or vice versa.

Michael Mann and other alarmist use proxy data until 1950, then switch to instruments. IF you continue to use the proxies, they ALL show a down turn AFTER 1950. Instruments go the other way. The result is a hockey stick shaped graph. 

Another failed attempt is to show a graph of the sea level and use 3 points to make a curve. It has been proven that there is a 60 year cycle in the sea levels, It isn't much, but its there. IF you use the top of one cycle the bottom of another cycle and the top of a third, you get a curve that looks like it is increasing, but that does not match facts. The last 5 years had a TOTAL increase of 2mm. According to the graph, it should be increasing at a rate of 8 mm per year.

Another failure is to ignore other science. More than half of the suppose sea level increase is due to land sinking. New York, Boston and most other east coast areas are sinking, but those are the areas they use to prove that man is responsible for a disastrous sea level rise.

text:
That might be true of radioactive waste in Europe but not of waste in the US.  Light water nuclear reactors that use solid uranium oxide fuel rods can only use about 0.5% of the uranium in the rods before becoming structurally unsound, this is because a Xenon isotope is one of the products and being a gas, it requires much more volume than it's predecessors and hence form gaps and fissures within the fuel rods.  The plan was to remanufacture these fuel rods back into solid rods for further use and Europe did build these remanufacturing plants but due to anti-nuclear pressure in the States, the Carter administration cancel the US remanufacturing plant.  This means that in the US, the nuclear waste is almost entirely unused uranium and other transuranic isotopes with half lives well in excess of 30,000 years.  These products are less radioactive than the actual byproducts of fission but must be isolated from the environment for well over 30,000 years while the actual byproducts of fission, not only are less voluminous but only need be isolated for about 350 years.  Also, CO2 capture presumed that the CO2 would stay in the reservoirs they are pumped into and there are indications this does not happen.  Microfissures particularly from fracking allows the CO2 to leak back into our environment, this has been measured particularly in ground water and there is a company employing passive seismic to try and map the microfissures.  What carbon remains sequestered are the ones that react with the surrounding minerals forming stable carbonates.  A more reliable carbon sequestration method would be biochar where only the carbon is sequestered  but of course industry does not like the idea of using energy to liberate oxygen from the carbon when their whole point was to liberate energy by allowing oxygen to react with the carbon in the first place.  I would agree that even with cessation of fossil fuel use, climate change would not half and indeed we may have already exceeded the interglacial metastability so the climate may just progress to a warmer state on natural positive feedbacks such as permafrost and clathrate meltings but I would suggest that technical methods of addressing the situation could be more dangerous than climate change itself hence not only are a Deus ex machina technical solution unlikely but quite risky.  I do agree that we have to pursue conservation and a shift to carbon free technologies to at least mitigate the situation which seems to be your intended statement however, I'm not willing to give up meat in my diet, perhaps suitable imitations of meat or bioprinted meat.  We've been able to bioprint a beating mouse heart with a modified inkjet printer (Woods Institute) so shouldn't a bioprinted steak or chicken breast be possible...  

Transportation could technologically be carbon free without replacing a single vehicle.  Fuels suitable to replace gasoline and diesel are obviously available from biologic sources but actual gasoline and diesel could readily be synthesized from syngas, a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide gases and indeed this is done in our refineries to improve the quality of the product produced.  However, just as it takes energy to liberate hydrogen from water, it takes energy to liberate carbon monoxide from carbon dioxide and that energy would have to be from a clean source.  However, the claim to an environmentally friendly transportation through EV's and hydrogen fueled vehicles are just as possible with existing vehicles and fuel delivery infrastructure.  It's just that auto manufacturers could invite more consumer sales with EV's and hydrogen fueled cars while carbon neutral fuel processes would only increase costs for refineries and compete with their core business model of fossil sourced feedstock.  Batteries, and hydrogen are just chemically stored energy just as gasoline and diesel are.  The problem with transportation isn't technology or even existing vehicles, they are social economic problems.  Many carbon neutral concepts simply provide too little profit and/or offset existing business models for corporations to pursue.

Trees are still being cut down at a record pace. The Amazon Jungle, for instance, is disappearing at alarming rates due to repeal of exotic lumber trade and exporting greed (I'm sorry, exporting "capitalism") to countries. It is a precarious position and often means very long work hours to protect oneself just from being fired.
And Oceans? Well, there are still plenty of idiots killing Sharks "for safety". Fishing has become industrialized with all the lobbying power of an oil company and MASSIVE waste of a resource that should be renewable except greed is outpacing it.
Some countries still hunt Whales and Japan (one of those countries) is also hunting a Tuna species to near extinction but storing them frozen until their rarity drives up the Market Price. Insanity, all of it.
Why then, all this madness? Well, it is exremely profitable for a very small few who "control the messaging" to get people to work long hours then purchase glittery or otherwise superficial products to replace the emptiness. This is not "good enough" for the truly greedy - they also export jobs to slave-wage locations to increase profit margins but also to create emptiness in slave-wage locations, Now the simple, independent home farmer has a salary and a need to spend: They have no time to be self-sufficient any longer. So, profits grow there as well for the truly greedy.
Finally, "Hard Goods". It used to mean necessary products built to last. It was true in Communist Russia where  refrigerator would (literally) work for 30 years with little service. Electronic Appliances could and should last a very long time but there is not LARGE profits in that, only mere profit. So they, like the incandescent light bulb are not "built to last" but to "wear out" at a rate acceptable to the buyer and as profitable as possible to the seller.
So? Climate Change. Mass Extinction. We earned it. Rockefellers and others should be tried for the same crimes as any other sociopath, instead, we bought into their messaging.

text:
Anyone that works in this climate-change-field relies on there being a problem. If there was no problem their climate-change-education would have no value because there would be no climate-change-jobs.

I am an engineer and I create fluid models. I know from experience that it is impossible to create a model that could accurately predict the fluid dynamics of the entire atmosphere since it is impossible to create an accurate fluid model of a room-sized simulation.

I would not care normally if people want to waste their careers trying to figure out how to create models that can predict complex systems such as the climate, but these people have become politicized by the left, unfortunately, and now the climate change industry has grown to such an extent that the only thing that would keep it from collapse is if there is an actual climate-crisis.

The other problem is that the entire world's economy is based on cheap, plentiful carbon-based energy. Because of this, the world's population has been allowed to expand greatly. The best case scenario, if we were to force a complete switch to more expensive or impractical fuels (wind/solar), is that first world people would have a sharp decline in purchasing power and quality of life, while those living on the margin in third world countries would largely perish.

This mass extinction of people is being created for political reasons, and is being supported because "if we don't stop climate change.. what about the children!!!". When in fact if we stop using carbon many millions of children in third world countries will die because food prices will increase (because transportation of food will increase in price (because fuel increases in price)). Several million children worldwide already die each year from starvation, and these politics will only serve to increase those numbers.

The best path forward is to diversify our energy, using renewables for peak demand only. If we start to use renewables for baseload energy demand, then this will cause a lot of hardship to regular people around the world.

author: Hallo Thisisnotmyname

text:
"CO2 is not powerful enough to cause climate change." That doesn't even make any sense. If it does have an effect, it's about the magnitude of the change within it and other forcings.
"There is no statistically significant correlation between CO2 and temps in the history of the planet." There is no statistically significant correlation between any forcing alone and temps in the history of the planet. No, not even the sun. There can be isolated periods where there is correlation (like sun and the last few centuries until 1950s and with CO2 from there on), but it doesn't explain everything else.
"The Sun controls the climate." Please show me the correlation between temperatures and solar activity for the past 50 years. Please show me correlation between solar activity and temperatures for the past 500 million years.

text:
So, Roy.
1. Little stories without evidence don't back up the biggest claim in science. That there are desired policy outcomes.
But one thing, what if there really is a problem or even a potential problem? It would be indistinguishable from the current situation where scientists get grant money from the government.
Billion dollar climate modelling efforts? Why he never mentions one by name? Kind of a huge deal, isn't it?
"They become spokepersons for the community, whether community likes it or not" And you send me Richard Lindzen, person who went to the public to spew out an opinion?
2. Why didn't he show the entire conversation in the leaked emails? Why he chose to take a quote from only one email? It's like cherrypicking start and end points in a temperature graph and not paying attention what came before or after. Again, kind of a big deal he strangely lacked details of.

3. He starts with the premise that there is a bias, and explain who would it benefit (although it doesn't make sense, see point below). All he has done is take quotes out of context (as far as we know)  
4. He makes a claim that would apply to every scientific field funded by the government. Only climate is under question? And this is how science has worked for a long time and gotten us to the modern technological society we live. All of a sudden, when something doesn't conform to their world view, it's a conspiracy?
5. The premise doesn't make sense. Desired policy outcomes would mean nothing against the money they have to spend for research which is wrong by deafult. What is the current narrative? Less polluting tech. That's the desired policy outcome? They want more power? They will not get from climate policies, they have to turn for other fields which are not under question.
How in the world does it make sense? 

6. He doesn't show which climate models are running twice as hot. Even if there are some, he didn't mention the ones that are prefectly fine. It's confirmation bias.
7. Rate of change isn't noticable by a human in their lifetimes? That's current rate of change. It's not linear. And it's also irrelevant to his topic. It doesn't highlight a bias.
8. Extreme weather hasn't gotten worse? Citation needed.
9. He uses "science" and "media" interchangeably.
10. Few papers don't mean anything. (Besides Curry is a knows climate misinformer and went straight to the public to tell the she is "ostracised" because she dared to publish some contradictory, but in reality, her research was just flawed and hse didn't accept it.) Few papers don't show anything unless the conclusions are confirmed by others. For example, if one research finds the answer is 3 but everybody else find it's 6 or 7, it doesn't mean 3 is the correct answer. That's confirmation bias... again.
11. Why are the present models (that supposedly warm the Earth twice the rate compared to reality) never mentioned anywhere? And even then, what about all the other models?
12. First he says the climate isn't on public's radar screen (9:10), the public isn't alarmed. That's counter to the entire point he is trying to make in the video.

Now Lindzen, he basically sayd other scientists don't account for other natural forcings and they aren't well understood. This is complete bull. Every scientists talking about climate understands that climate changes due to multible of factors. Lindzen is just telling half the story.
What the "groups" agree on is basically correct, scientists do agree on those point. But they can be misinterpreted by people trying to prove either side. That's why you need to tell the whole story.
No evidence... by which he means those fancy models that recreate 20th century climate almost perfectly?

Yea... I don't really care what tree huggers think. I care what scientists think.
