text:
@John Hicks. “I do not think I am specially smart, but the reality is, I do have a genius level I.Q.”
A genius level IQ is by definition specially smart.  No-one is impressed by this hilariously obvious humblebrag.

Anyone with any self-awareness would be ashamed if they wrote that. 

Now lets go unpick your maths: 
“I read the report that John Cook created and proclaimed that it was 97%. First off 66% were ignored because they had not stated an opinion. Then there was the 3% that disagreed with it being man made at all, leaving 31%. I do not remember the exact percentage right off hand, but 30% said that either man had done something but the amount was indeterminable, it was indeterminable that man had done anything, or that man had done something but it was small. What was left was was written by .3% of the scientist. The interesting things is they had written 4-5% of the total articles about the climate. Such a small number or writers, but they had written an amount that dwarf almost anyone else."

This is the report you refer to: http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/8/2/024024
It would have been a simple thing for you to link to it. You are the one making the claim, so it up to you to provide the evidence. But like the lazy little thinker you are I have to do the legwork for you.

In the abstract of ‘Quantifying the consensus on anthropogenic global warming in the scientific literature’ it says of the 11,944 peer-reviewed scientific papers written between 1991 to 2011:
“We find that 66.4% of abstracts expressed no position on AGW, 32.6% endorsed AGW, 0.7% rejected AGW and 0.3% were uncertain about the cause of global warming. Among abstracts expressing a position on AGW, 97.1% endorsed the consensus position that humans are causing global warming.”

Here we find the first example of innate your dishonesty, John. The 66.4% that you claim were ignored were not ignored. They had ‘no position’ for or against anthropogenic global warming (AGW). You incorrectly assume that the 66% must be against AGW. So you write them off.

However under section 4 of Cook’s report under the heading ‘Discussion’ we can read:
“Of note is the large proportion of abstracts that state no position on AGW. This result is expected in consensus situations where scientists '...generally focus their discussions on questions that are still disputed or unanswered rather than on matters about which everyone agrees'.”

And it goes further:
“This explanation is also consistent with a description of consensus as a 'spiral trajectory' in which 'initially intense contestation generates rapid settlement and induces a spiral of new questions'; the fundamental science of AGW is no longer controversial among the publishing science community and the remaining debate in the field has moved to other topics.”

In short the 66% doesn’t mention AGW because in the scientific community (for which these papers were written) it is already accepted that AGW is real. There is no point in pointing out the glaciers are melting because of human release of CO2 in every single paper on melting glaciers because the people reading these papers already know that.
author: Chris Hartley

text:
@John Hicks “ Then there was the 3% that disagreed with it being man made at all...”
In fact the figure is “0.7% rejected AGW”. Now that is quite a difference.

Then you, John, go on: “What was left was was written by .3% of the scientist [that support AGW as the main cause of climate change]”

Now there is a 0.3% figure in Cook’s abstract but its about those papers that are uncertain of AGW:  “...and 0.3% were uncertain about the cause of global warming.” 

That leaves 32.6% of papers that mentioned AGW endorsing it as the main driver of climate change. Which if you look at Table 3 represents 34.8% of authors.

In addition to this the authors of the papers surveyed were invited to rate their papers by the same criteria that Cook, et al, used. This is to remove any charges of bias that certain ‘non-special geniuses might throw. 14% responded.

This is under 3.2 ‘Endorsement percentages of self-ratings’ and involved 2142 papers from 1189 authors.

Now what happens here is that the percentage of those papers that endorse AGW rises to 62.7%. Those against AGW also rise to a towering 1.8%. So John, its not all bad news for your skeptics :)
This is best seen in Table 5.

So John ‘The problem is that only leaves 4%...’. You are either badly mistaken and a really terrible liar who assumes no-one will fact check your BS.

And where does this (racism?)come from? Well John, you helpfully provide the answer right here: “...of the papers support agw, and that does not give Cook or others the power to demand people give up money to help other countries.”

 And why shouldn’t people in the third world enjoy a better standard of living? Nothing as unsustainable and energy hungry as we have in the West, but not having open sewers in the street or starving to death from famine.

Now this is just a survey. A snapshot of discussion on climate change discussion in the scientific community. And and what matters in any survey is the sample size. The larger the better as a small sample size can be easily weighted one way or another by random chance. If you throw a duice ten times and record the outcomes then you will likely have some numbers that don’t show whilst others will show up more than once. From that you might conclude the dice is weighted.

Under section 4.1 ‘Sources of Uncertainty’ we can read:
“We address the issue of representativeness by selecting the largest sample to date for this type of literature analysis. Nevertheless, 11 944 papers is only a fraction of the climate literature. A Web of Science search for 'climate change' over the same period yields 43 548 papers, while a search for 'climate' yields 128 440 papers.”

If we take that higher figure then the 11,944 sample size represents about 9.3%. Which for a sample size is fantastic.

text:
@Chris Hartley  "Yet you fail to provide a reason for it except to wave your arms ar sunspots." This one is going to take time.

Sunspots are places of high activity on the sun's surface. Magnetism goes crazy around them and they throw out a lot of material that shoots out of the solar system in what is called the solar wind. When it is particularly high, it can cause disruption in the magnetic field surrounding the earth and cause interference in satellite and other electronic systems. It can seriously mess up power lines.

It also blocks out cosmic radiation. This gets its name because it comes from outside our solar system. Every cosmic body, including our sun has its own "fingerprint" of radiation. Some will be high in red for instance, while others are stronger closer to blue. Some of the radiation in the band causes water vapor to form lower than other wise. Our sun is weak in this ban, so most of our clouds form high. Many other start low and climb because the water droplets are smaller.

When the solar wind is weak, the cosmic radiation hits the earth a lot more. This causes the clouds to form lower and stay lower as the droplets are bigger. Low level clouds are more reflective of visible light, and more transparent to infrared. The result is that solar energy is reflected while the black body infrared radiation that the earth releases is able to reach space easier. The result is the earth cools. As it cools more winter ice forms and less is melted during the summer causing glaciers to expands. History and proxies both support that this happened during the little ice age. Between the minimums, the ice began to melt, then expand again when the next minimum hit. Since the middle of the 1600's the glaciers have been mostly retreating. There were two more periods were they slightly expanded but not that much.

When the solar wind is strong, the cosmic radiation is blocked and the the clouds form higher and smaller drops. The result is that they create high level clouds. These clouds absorb more visible sunlight warming the atmosphere. They are also more reflective of infrared, preventing the black body radiation from escaping as fast. This results in a warming earth.

Thus sunspots are the trigger of global warming, even when they fluctuate, because on the average, there is more high level clouds than low. The LONG TERM lack of sunspots triggers a global cooling because of solar wind, cosmic radiation and low level clouds.

"The Maunder Minimum, also known as the "prolonged sunspot minimum", is the name used for the period around 1645 to 1715 during which sunspots became exceedingly rare, as was then noted by solar observers." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maunder_Minimum
There are more about the other minimums if you wish to check them out.

"it was realised that increasing them might well have an effeect on the atmosphere."  MIGHT have an effect. It has never been proven. In fact, it is close to being disproven. The point of matter is how sensitive is the atmosphere to increases in co2.

It has been known since the 1800's that co2 emits infrared. What alarmist do not want you to know is that the increase in co2 causes an increase in infrared leaving the planet. That is what is called a negative feedback loop. They will talk about positive feedback loops as if they were proven, but none of them are showing up. Clouds can also be a positive or negative feedback depending on if they are high or low and alarmist do not acknowledge that fact. They will tell you that all water vapor is a positive feedback. That is how they justify claiming the sensitivity is 2°C or more (how much the atmosphere will warm due to a doubling of co2).

When I was in high school, in the 70's, I was in speech class. Every semester, out teacher would randomly assign topics out of a bag and pick two people at random to debate the topic. At the end of the semester, we would debate that topic and our grade would be based on how well we did. When it was discovered that my topic was global COOLING, man made or natural, AND I was on the natural side of the debate, I was in formed I could pass with only bringing up a single point of question that would put it even slightly in question.

Instead I won the debate. In my research, I found that scientist in the 1940's had begun studying the record of the British Royal Navy. These record contained temperature readings from every part of the world for well over a century at that point. American recording only went back 60 years but it validated the records the British took. Other countries had shorter periods of readings as well that supported them. The result was they discovered there was a 60 year stair step pattern. They called it the temperature oscillation. At that time they could not discover the cause of the pattern, but years later it was discovered that there is a strong correlation between the orbits of Saturn and Jupiter with that cycle. It is not proof, but certainly a possibility.

What got them concerned was the regular increase in temperature that was underlying it. Over the years, there have been several other patterns, such as 24, 12 and 8 year cycles. When these cycles are all taken out, you get a straight line graph of .9°C per century. In 30 years, the 60 year cycle will cause a warming of .6°C, then a drop of .05°C in 30 years. The result is that every 60 years since the records were found, the earth has warmed about .55°C. IF you continue that graph into the future from where they were, you get something that is very close to what the actual readings have shown. IF you continue that until the year 2100, it would only have an increase in the temperature of 1.8°C above 1900 temperatures. The alarmist say we have to keep the temperature no higher than 2° above the 1880 mark.

Notice any connection?

The alarmist also tell us that we have to give them tons of money to keep the temperature from going any higher than that.

The scientist wanted to try to find out what was calling the .9°C per century. Since ww2 had ended the allies had a lot of planes with crews that needed to continue to train, as well as ground crew, including the people that read the pictures  reconnaissance planes took. So they were more than happy to have their crew photograph glaciers and such. Using these and proxies, they were able to discover that the cause of the warming was the melting of the glaciers.

All of this happen at a time when the co2 was only 280-290 ppm.

The earth has continued to warm at .9° since the 1940's, in leaps ever 30 years. Between 1970 and 2000, the climate rose .6°C Since then, it has arguably cooled as much as .05°. It will not start to warm up until 2030, and if the solar minimum does not start then, the warming will begin again.

This is what is meant by real science. Models created in the 1940's long before the ff companies even had any kind of control, are reasonably close to the real temperature, while models are off by as much as 1°C in 17 years.

Altering data to match your predictions is not science, but religion. Demanding everyone accept your decrees or face prison or death is not science, but religion. Consensus is not science. Insulting those that do not accept your logic is not science, but childish prattle based on religion zealotry.

You can not prove agw with repeatable test. You can not prove that shellfish are dying from co2 with proven test results. You can prove they died from lack of o2 due to algae blooms cause by over use of fertilizer and you can do so with repeatable lab test. You can not prove co2 is causing bleaching of reefs with repeatable test results. You can prove that they are the result of water levels falling due to winds caused by El Ninos. You can not prove that the sun is not the cause of the warming because it was the same as it was since the little ice age, because it was also the same as it was in the mwp.

You can not prove that co2 is causing the ice to melt, because it is the ice melting that is causing the warming. THAT is physics and THAT is science. Their claims are nothing but hot air.

"because they do not specifically mention it to you that is evidence that the majority of climate scientists reject that CO2" No, what I have is evidence that she faked the study. All of them do. There is no evidence that they reject or accept BUT the standard scientific procedures is not to make a stand on it unless you know it is one or the other. I do deny that they have proof that they support.

"That is now proof that it didnt happen, but instead that it did." It happen, but it didn't happen? And I need to learn to read?

The point is, the little ice age cooled off the planet and it is getting warmer since. The little ice age was colder than the earth should so when it ended of course the earth warmed and that is why it is warming now. Co2 did not cause the cooling, nor did it cause the warming since.

"Do you have evidence that NASA is holding out " Yes, their reports state that water vapor is a positive feedback. No where do they even discuss the possibility that it is a negative feedback. YET even their experts tell them that it can have a negative feedback. The only way to have a sensitivity of 3 or more is to disregard all negative feedbacks. YET no model that has anything higher than a 1 is even close to the actual measured temperatures.

"And again with the clouds as if they spontaniously just ping up in the sky with no force driving them... " SERIOUSLY? what drives them up is something you might have heard of if you ever took your fingers out of your ears, called the *SUN*. Believe it or not but it has been proven that the sun can cause clouds to "spontaneously just ping up in the sky". It does not require co2 at all.

"The use of proxy methods of measuing past climate is out of necessity as reliable records on the weather only go a few centuries back and become more sparce and cover less of the globe as they do so" Yes, but the proxies did not stop the minute the instruments came out. The fact of the matter is, if you continue to  use the proxies, they greatly diverge from the instruments. This is because they proxies they use do not track temperature but climate. Dendrochronology is the study of data from tree ring growth. Dendrochologist will tell you that those reading can not be used to determine temperature, but Michael Mann did exactly that. He is not a dendrochologist, but pretends he knows more than they do.
"There is much we can learn about the past climate, how freak season-long weather conditions, or periods of climate change have affected tree growth" https://www.environmentalscience.org/dendrochronology-tree-rings-tell-us
Note that this says climate change, not temperature. Yet it was a graph of temperature that Michael Mann created using tree rings and it was thermometer readings he tacked on the end before discarding the proxy data because it went in the wrong direction.

text: @robert hicks  I realize that I'm coming in late to this conversation, but the mental gymnastics you seem willing to entertain, leading you to reject the very thought of AGW and most of all, any inconvenience to yourself is astonishing. That human activity has dumped uncounted tons of carbon into the atmosphere since the advent of the industrial revolution is again indisputable. author: robert hicks

text:
@robert hicks  
I'm going to say your claims about Cooks Paper are BS. Your technique of including the "no position" papers belies the fact that these aren't individual scientists claiming that human influences have no impact on temperatures, but the focus and outcomes of paper abstracts, many of which did not look into the matter. Most papers on climate change generally look into past mechanisms and rarely mention how they relate to the current warming. That doesn't necessarily mean they disagree with the impact human CO2 emissions. In fact many of the scientists that author these papers support the current consensus based on the findings of their research, they just don't mention it in the abstract. As for the rest of your calculations, you just seem to be p-hacking to find the lowest percentage support based on some pretty shaky reasoning.

You also dismiss the fact that Oreskes, Verheggen, Doran and others have found similar levels of agreement as Cook et al. All I've seen deniers do is cherry pick statistics like you did or misinterpret studies looking at other factors. They generally have a pretty poor history of accurately reflecting what scientists actually say in the matter, as Delingpole demonstrates pretty well here.

https://climatefeedback.org/evaluation/breitbart-misrepresents-research-58-scientific-papers-falsely-claim-disprove-human-caused-global-warming-james-delingpole/

Compare his 0 for 29 on accurately describing these papers outcomes with Cook et al, who actually interviewed the authors of the papers used in his research , and you'll see why I don't trust bloggers on the internet for my science.
author: thepoo1234

text:
" Your technique of including the "no position"" The "study" claimed that these papers supported agw, even though they gave no position. There are two ways that a study SHOULD report these as the standard scientific procedures outline. Either they state "out of 4000 paper 97% support agw", or they state "32% of 14000". They did not want to use the 4k because it would highlight how few people were making those claims. They did not want to say 32% because that would destroy the pretense that it was a consensus.

"rarely mention how they relate to the current warming." Exactly. They looked at natural warming, and if they showed how the warming was natural, it proves that the current warming is natural.

"they just don't mention it in the abstract." So why were their papers counted as supporting agw. The report did not state the scientist support, but the papers supported agw.

"you just seem to be p-hacking to find the lowest percentage support based on some pretty shaky reasoning" I do not know what p-hacking is, but the reality is a paper like this should find the lowest percentage support. Scientifically speaking, you do not count things like a report proving media bias towards agw as proof of support for agw. MANY of the ones that did not say which way they were leaning did the same thing. They were trying to be balance and were counted as support because they mentioned man made global warming but did not come out and say they were against it.

"You also dismiss the fact that Oreskes, Verheggen, Doran and others have found similar levels of agreement as Cook " No, I am not dismissing the fact that they faked it just as Cook did. Oreskes stated that she counted you as support if you did not say you were against. That is contrary to standard scientific procedures, and against standard mathematical statistical analysis procedures. Basically, the way she did it, she should have stated she found 3% against it and left it at that. THAT would have been accurate. 

One of the studies asked 12 questions only one, the very last, had anything to do with co2 and that was "is co2 a ghg". The first 11 had nothing to do with it. The first simply asked if people thought the temperature had increased since the 1900, yet her conclusion was about 1950 and beyond. No where did she asked anything to do with 1950.

The second asked if man had CONTRIBUTED (note that this could mean as little as 1%) to climate change (note she did not indicate if it was positive or negative). She asked these of STUDENTS studying building dams, and they knew that they effected the climate around them. She asked students studying agriculture science and they knew that agriculture affects the climate. She asked students studying building cities and they know of heat island effects and micro climates. Most science will effect the climate in some manner. So of course 97% agree.

YET despite her study claiming that these SCIENTIST believed that man made co2 was responsible for the majority of the warming since the 1950's.

Another study did nothing more than say that she did it right.

Nothing in this did it right.

"as Delingpole demonstrates pretty well here." That  has nothing to do with what I was doing because I gave actual information from those studies to prove how they did it wrong.

"you'll see why I don't trust bloggers on the internet for my science." You should not trust ANYONE. You should do the research for yourself then you will see the lies. Cook said he asked a fraction of the authors if they supported agw, a fraction responded and he counted them. THAT still does not prove that 97% of the 14000 papers supported agw.

text:
robert hicks Forget the words climate change for a moment, forget the idea of "man made" and the science of anything. Just two people talking. You ever smelled exhaust from a huge diesel truck in traffic, smells awful right? In most instances if we trapped ourselves in a small space and breathed that black stuff in long enough, we both believe it would kill us! Now just picture the scale of humanity pumping that out on the daily right? A Filipino city clogged by endless rows of motorbikes, a sea-like traffic jam in Los Angeles, the enumerated megalopolis' in China and India, the thousands and thousands of commercial jets in the sky right now as you read this pumping out exhaust, the cruise liners quietly spitting out exhaust while the happy vacationers, perhaps a small few, notice and say to themselves, "well it's just this one ship on a vast sea." My problem is not with a little bit of toxic fumes from my car or yours, a plastic Walmart bag I threw a way tonight. Our contributions individually are virtually insignificant, but I'm asking people who have a problem with this topic to consider the scale and size of humanity's footprint. A billion? Like 7 billion?? Happening all right now. Yes. It's unfathomable to my small pea brain, to understand how we are able to facilitate the consumption needs of this many humans, even for just one day. 
I'm not saying let's change this. I'm not even saying we can. I'm not even asking you to imagine your daily routine and multiply it times 7 billion, because I know I can't. 
I know if I take that diesel truck and sit in a garage with it long enough, I'll eventually die. I can easily imagine that. 
1 tiny problem x 7 billion
author: Nathan Sexton

text:
If you were trapped in a room with an engine running, you would die from lack of o2 long before the co2 killed you and you would be much more likely to die of carbon MONOXIDE than lack of o2.

That's the problem with the cities. It isn't co2, but co, hydrocarbons and particle pollution.

You don't realize it, but trying to put it on my  daily habits backfires. I am likely the only person you will ever talk to that has a negative carbon footprint. More people could do it, but its expensive and everyone wants to say its the other guys responsibility. Look at al gore. Flies around in a huge aircraft, drives a fleet of stretched Humvees, owns multiple homes using huge amounts of energy, and he tells everyone else they have to cut back.

On the other hand, I have a small farm, where I grow a few chicken, have a garden for most of my vegies, have a hybrid solar system and a vertical windmill that drives a air compressor which powers a electric generator so that it works almost all the time, no matter what the wind, and an algae farm to produce diesel for my truck and to run the generator when the wind and sun isn't there. I sell the algae remains to a feedlot for cattle feed and this more than balances the amount of beef I eat.

It would be possible to do this on large scale if you had a community that cared about it, but most don't. They would rather blame other for the failures they perceive, even if those failures do not exist.

text:
"If you were trapped in a room with an engine running, you would die from lack of o2 long before the co2"

That has absolutely nothing to do with global warming where an increase in average temperature disrupts normal climate patterns and increases sea levels. With your argument, I could say that we should get rid of the ozone because it's poisonous to human lungs.

"I am likely the only person you will ever talk to that has a negative carbon footprint."

Good for you. Doesn't change the fact that you're spreading harmfully inaccurate rhetoric about climate change, which is what I'm calling you out for.

"More people could do it, but its expensive and everyone wants to say its the other guys responsibility. Look at al gore."

That's a poor argument. A lot of people hate the exploitative nature of capitalism, but they still participate in it anyways because they have to. A lot of people want to reduce their carbon footprint from meat, but as long as there's an incentive to eat meat, people will take it. As long as there's an incentive to do something, people will take that incentive. The moment it becomes law to stop emitting so much carbon, there will no longer be that incentive. Contrary to your claim, people are not hypocrites for participating in the thing that they dislike.

"It would be possible to do this on large scale if you had a community that cared about it, but most don't."

It would be possible to do this on a large scale if you signed a carbon tax into federal law. Besides, there's already a city that's 100% renewable; haven't you heard the news about Dale Ross and the city of Georgetown?

"Doesn't change the fact that you're spreading harmfully inaccurate rhetoric about climate change, which is what I'm calling you out for." Doesn't change the fact that what I spread is truth, no matter how much you do not want to believe it. Name any part of the global warming theory and I can show you tons of holes in it.

"A lot of people hate the exploitative nature of capitalism" When its the only show in town, that's what you see. Capitalism may be exploitative, and it may be the very worse system, except for every other system that humans have ever tried. But it is there because nothing else is as good.

"as long as there's an incentive to eat meat, people will take it" There is only one "incentive" for eating meat. That is it is good for life. Liberals push vegetarian as a lifestyle because vegetarians are easier to control. Omnivores live longer and are healthier. There is no incentive to be a vegetarian.

" The moment it becomes law to stop emitting so much carbon," it would have to become a law and that is not going to happen unless  you convince people that carbon is a danger and that has been a failure.

"Contrary to your claim, people are not hypocrites for participating in the thing that they dislike." Never said that. What is said was they are hypocrites for doing it and demanding others do not.

"It would be possible to do this on a large scale if you signed a carbon tax into federal law." It would be possible to do if anyone truly believed it was a problem. The carbon tax is nothing more than a way or taking money from the lower and middle income and making the elite richer. It does absolutely nothing to reduce co2.

" Besides, there's already a city that's 100% renewable" Ive heard that bs before. It completely ignores the fact it can not be done beyond the city levels.

Basically, what they did was make an agreement to buy all the electricity for the city from a group of windmill operators that had already built the windmills. During the day, they draw every thing from a large area of windmills and if one area shuts down due to low wind speed, they draw their energy from another. 

Here is the problem. In countries like Denmark, where they use only wind and solar, they had to build so much of them so make sure they always had the electricity that on MOST days, half of them are shut down. Why? Because they have too great a production capability. At night, its worse. Most of the wind is at night, and yet their demands are down. So 70% of their capacity is wasted.

The result, their electric bills are 10+ times what they are in the US. Businesses that are dependent on electricity have gone bankrupt or moved to other countries.

Yes a single city, exps a small one, can go completely on wind, but not the nation.

text:
@robert hicks  Nope.

http://science.sciencemag.org/content/335/6072/1058.abstract

In short:

The current rate of ocean acidification is faster than at any time in the past 300 million years.

The most recent de-glacial transition phase, while similar in temperature and increases in CO2 levels, was “two orders of magnitude slower than current anthropogenic change.”

The period 56 million years ago known as the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum was determined to be the closest future analog. This period of sustained CO2 release was associated with a decline in ocean pH of between 0.25 and 0.45 units. However, current acidification is occurring at almost 10 times this rate.

Historically sustained periods of acidification and CO2 increase — which were similar but not as extreme as the last 1,000 years — have led to the collapse of coral reefs and, in one instance, to the extinction of 96% of marine life.

You hope it doesn't kill us and I hope you are right. But I am not going to rely on 'hope'. I'll listen to the 'science'.

text:
The climate has always been (and is still) changing, all the time.  Mostly effected by the sun, but to a much smaller extent, the increase in cities/populations can and do have some affect.  Steel, stone, concrete and asphalt used in construction for buildings, roads, and other construction, retain heat from the sun’s energy during the day and dissipate that heat during the cooler hours.  

While attending the University of Arizona, during the early 1970’s, many “climatologists, meteorologists, scientists and other weather ‘experts’” were hysterically protesting and demonstrating (while professing) that we were entering another ICE-AGE.  We obviously were not entering an ice-age then, and are not suffering “global warming” now.  These are political hoaxes to attempt to separate your money from your wallet.

Former Vice President Al Gore predicted that within ten years the oceans would rise about twenty feet.  That was ten years ago and so far they have not risen even inch.  Nothing, no, Nada not even a mili-meter!

Let us use some common sense:

Fact 1:  Humans can not change (or make) the weather, we cannot even accurately predict it much less change it. Maybe we can seed a cloud here or there, but we can not stop or change the direction of a tornado or a hurricane or even a thunder storm or cold front or any other weather phenomenon.

Fact 2:  The air we breath (the Earth’s atmosphere) is made-up of about 77% Nitrogen, 22% Oxygen, and less than 1% argon.  That leaves LESS than 1% of ALL OTHER GASSES and airborne materials (such as water vapor, dust, etc).  Carbon Dioxide makes up less than 2/100’s of one percent of Earth’s atmosphere.  Like spitting into the ocean, not enough to make ANY difference no matter how many times we spit.

Fact 3:  Global warming “experts” say that animal (primarily cow) flatulence (FARTS) help to increase the threat of global warming.  Cow flatulence are NOT Carbon Dioxide.  Like most animal flatulence, that gas is a methane gas NOT C02.

If you are one of those people falling for this hoax, I live in Arizona and I do have some beach front property for sale here.  All you have to do is wait for the Pacific Ocean to rise.  Buy it now while it is cheap.

text:
There are 3 possible scenarios in which it is reversible or at least mitigatable, to at least give a bit of a hope. Two of them have been said by you which are increasing the viability of filtering CO2 out (as it still is in the baby steps, and cost/benefit may as well increase favorably the more technological advancement and research is done into it), and the increase in viability of alternate resources decreasing the footprint due to technological advancements of our current energy. 

There is also a third argument which is more of an economic argument tho. Between 60 and 70% of the current greenhouse emissions are done by the so called global south (WRI/CGDEV) which are countries that are still considered in developmental stage. There is one argument that regions need to go through an industrial revolution stage in order to become developed, and once developed they are capable of reducing their carbon footprint by decreasing their dependancy on energy sources that are unfavorable. So according to that reasoning, once other nations become more developed as well, they will decrease their greenhouse emissions as well naturally which will reduce the global emission drastically (without considering improvements in technology per se, just by developing their regions economically). 

It's quite an optimistic argument and goes to the 'humanity will figure it out' reasoning, but thought it was worth mentioning as well.

"....a paper entitled “Circumstances affecting the heat of the sun’s rays,” by Eunice Foote. 
In two brisk pages, Foote’s paper anticipated the revolution in climate science 
by experimentally demonstrating the effects of the sun on certain gases 
and theorizing how those gases would interact with Earth’s atmosphere for the first time. 
In a column of the September 1856 issue of Scientific American titled “Scientific Ladies,” 
Foote is praised for supporting her opinions with “practical experiments.” 
The writers noted: “this we are happy to say has been done by a lady.”

Foote’s research & paper demonstrated the interactions of the sun’s rays 
on different gases through a series of experiments...."

1] Scott Strough's answer to Can we reverse global warming?
Executive summary:
Yes we can reverse Global Warming.
It does not require huge tax increases or expensive untested risky technologies.
It will require a three pronged approach worldwide.
Reduce fossil fuel use by replacing energy needs with as many feasible renewables as current technology allows.
Change Agricultural methods to high yielding regenerative models of production made possible by recent biological & agricultural science advancements.
Large scale ecosystem recovery projects similar to the Loess Plateau project, National Parks like Yellowstone etc. where appropriate and applicable.
2] Project Drawdown
The list is comprised primarily of “no regrets” solutions—actions that make sense to take regardless of their climate impact since they have intrinsic benefits to communities and economies. These initiatives improve lives, create jobs, restore the environment, enhance security, generate resilience, and advance human health.[5]
3] Farming a climate change solution
Farmers have a golden solution to global warming largely missed by climate change pundits, right beneath their feet. The innovative Australian Soil Carbon Accreditation Scheme is showing how incentive payments can be received by landholders for measurable increases in soil carbon that soaks up CO2 from the atmosphere. Financial incentives could help fund soil restoration efforts, which in turn bring the bonus of greater productivity, drought resilience and even rain. The action is deep underground.[6]

text: https://youtu.be/V2KNqluP8M0 The unreliables (incorrectly called “renewables”) are a key part of the problem. The reason why most people don’t care about alarmist ramblings is in fact quite simple: They describe the problem quite clearly, but then they propose an anti-human non-solution in the form of unreliables and other frauds. Well, no surprise that so many people choose to ignore the problem, sadly enough. If all climate change studies included a very clear statement of the obvious — we need to move to an economy based on 100% of nuclear power and we need to do that ASAP —, it would make the whole story much more credible and the environmental protection goals much more feasible, without the stupid anti-human idea of “changing our economy”. The latter is simply infeasible; if you consider 20 richest countries in the world as we know it, their economies are very similar in many ways and abundant energy is a cornerstone in all of them. Alternative economies like North Korea, Cuba or Venezuela do exist, but none of them looks like a sustainable long-term solution. So instead of dreaming of alternative economies, we should be dreaming of reliable, dense, carbon-free, cheap and sustainable power source, independent of weather, climate, season of the year and time of day — nuclear power.

text: Arguably there is not really one, as long as the average temperature allows liquid water to exist of course. You see the current species and the planet system as a whole have evolved over millenia to be suited to the climate they experience, if that climate is to change then some species will evolve and other will go extinct but that is entirely normal. The issue with today's global warming is that it is incredibly fast and a lot of species may not be able to make it. Think of trees that reproduce very slowly and "move" (as a population) at a slow pace, and with them the whole ecosystems that they sustain are put at risk. In fact all past mass-extinction events have been caused by rapid climate change (and I stress rapid), which of course always had an underlying cause (like a big meteor or a dramatic increase in volcanic activity), but the ultimate killer was climate.
author: Quentin Jutard

text: Quentin Jutard Quentin Jutard Will the plant and animals species that evolve from man made climate change be of a benefit or detriment to human populations?  Will humans, as in the past as evidenced in our current population bloom, and past evidence of catastrophes,  be capable of overcoming the diverse changes of climate around the globe.
author: Pistol76Pete

text:
Well anticipating what "new" species may appear would be a very difficult task, I don't know if any specialist did try that though. Also although evolution might be sped up by rapid climate change it is a very slow process and humans are also subject to it. In fact humans might have significantly changed as well by the time a significant number of new species will have appeared, all this to say it is not really relevant to ask the question in the sense of evolution.The species we will coexist with will nonetheless not be the same, but this will happen through another process. Species that already exist will become more prominent as others are plummeting in numbers, for example jellyfish are (for now) benefiting from climate change so they become more abundant, but they did not evolve for this they simply are already better fitted to the changes occuring. In the near future we can expect in some oceans to observe greater ratios of jellyfish to other species. 
Now is this to the benefit or detriment of humans ? In our example it seems that it is a problem as jellyfish are not commonly consumed by humans. But the impact of a greater population of jellyfish on the local environment is more difficult to estimate, it could destroy it as much as it could stabilize it, or have no effect (well I actually don't know if some research was done on this subject).  In general in the near future it seems to be more of a nuisance, for example tiger mosquitos (able to transmit a lot of infections between humans) have started to appear in Europe, while bees (highly important to a lot of ecosystems) have been on the decline (well this is not just a consequence of climate change but also of the overuse of pesticides and the removal of nests), and vegetation vanishing will facilitate mud flows from floodings. These are few examples but overall it seems to be very bad.
Your second question is much harder to answer, optimists will keep saying you to "believe in our capacity of innovation" but this would be blind faith. A recent study that has been quite widely shared estimates that past 2°C above pre-industrial levels we will enter runaway warming, which means that even if we no longer emit carbon dioxyde, temperature will keep rising to what is estimated as 3 to 4°C above pre-industrial levels. They added that they estimated our chances of being coordinated enough to avoid this to 5%, so without drastic changes in politics we should expect a +3-4°C scenario as most likely (in 2100) and with it the environmental catastrophes that it will bring. Will we survive as a species ? This depends on many other factors than temperature, for example if we keep on poisoning soils, making them infertile without proper fertilizer, we can expect it will be more difficult to keep on feeding everyone. We can already give estimations of how much climate change will cost in terms of damages and human lives, but total human extinction may happen in so many different scenarii that are are all so complex that giving an estimation of the probability of such events would be pure speculations.

I hope I have given you some answers, I am sorry that this ended up so long but I really would hate to give you false understanding of something, hence the detours. But I am glad I could be helpfull  !

author: Ander Lillemaa

text: Look, what I meant by that, is: If you want to show that gravity exists because things with a big mass exert a force on other stuff, you need to conduct a series of experiments: First you need to show that all things fall to the ground, so you need to prove that every time you let sth go, it will fall. Then, you need to take that same experiment into space to show that because there is nothing that has a strong enough gravitational pull, things won't fall down. So, if you want to show that climate change is anthropogenic, you need to show that climate is changing on our planet (which we have shown), and then you have to show that climate on earth without the human factor would change differently or not at all. And this is the impossible part, since we don't have a second earth where EVERYTHING is the same except for us humans. This is why our simulations will always be vague predictions based on assumptions.
author: Thomas Mann

text:
That's another topic, but you don't need a second Earth. This is more simple than predicting a century into the future and even more accurate because in this case, you already have all the data you need. For example, 20th century and onward has more data about individual forcings and climate conditions than any other time period. If your model can recreate those climate conditions (modern models are tested that way), then it's probably on the right track.
for example
https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/1520-0442%282004%29017%3C3721%3ACONAAF%3E2.0.CO%3B2
author: Ander Lillemaa

text:
Well, technically you dont need a second earth, it would be sufficient to know everything about our planet and about every climate factor specifically and how they all come together, so we'd know how changing one factor (i.e. humans) would change the whole. Therein lies the problem:  This is actually what we're trying to do. We are getting this interdependency, where to get where we want to get we would already have to know the outcome. This means that since we don't know everything about all the climate factors, everything we do is based on assumptions and this doesn't make for very good science. You are talking about data, yet data only shows us the whole picture (with the human factor). Data can not tell us how we are to interpret it, so any talk of "without humans, the world would look like this" is an educated guess at best.

Compare this to quantum physics: First, you start with an observation in the macro spectrum that you don't really understand. You make the assumption it has to do with small particles, so you look for it in the quantum world. Once you find it, you develop a formula that predicts whatever you saw in the first place. This formula is then tested whether a) it can truly predict what you say it can, in every other situation, and b) whether it is compatible with the already established formulas.
Now, apply that to climatology: You have the observation, and the assumption and the formula. But the rest is lacking, and this would be the most important part.

text:
Hey I have a question about the "not eat meat" thing.

So I've got a degree in Environmental Science, and sometimes I feel like I'm streched across 20 different topics. One area I've been trying to understand more of is agriculture.

In my time reading about it, I've came across "Restorative Grazing". I'm probably going to butcher this, but what it claims is that grasslands have been grazed by hoofed animals (ungulates), especially ruminants, for millions of years. Since humans have came along though, we've decimated wild populations of ruminant ungulates- like American bison and Wisents, for example. Now we have cattle and sheep to graze these lands instead.

Now this is important, because grasslands can sequester carbon. This is helped by ungulates- they trample grass so it decomposes into the soil, and their wastes provide nutrients for the grasses to regrow. Some people who research this say that this method could sequester enough carbon to have a HUGE impact on carbon levels. 

If you haven't heard of this, and you want a better description, there's a TED talk by Alan Savory- he seems to be the founder of this. 

If you have, do you have an opinion on it? Do you think it will work? Have you heard other scientists talk about it working or being completely false? I'm just looking for some guidance, as I everyone I ask is going to have an opinion, but you seemed like a person who would have an informed opinion- which is actually worth something to me. 

Also, to go back to the spread 10 different topics way, what's your opinion on nuclear energy? Energy is another topic I've been trying to learn about, and it seems like nuclear is low carbon with massive amounts of energy. Should it be part of the solution for climate change, or are only renewables going to work for this?

Thanks!

author: Attilio Russo

text:
+ Attilio Russo
No, livestock does not account for 15% of GHG's. Fermentation, which is how livestock pollute, accounts for roughly half of all METHANE emissions; however, methane accounts for the aforementioned15% of all GHG's, with C02 being the primary GHG. Since they only produce half of the methane, livestock would roughly contribute around 7% of total GHG's, which is less than half of transportation GHG's, which is around 17%. Furthermore, beef cows produce almost all of this methane, with poultry and pigs producing a minuscule amount. Agriculture as a whole, including forestry, accounts for over a quarter of all GHG's. As you said, the primary issue is deforestation, just not meat producing livestock.

text:
This video piece is full of nonsense and alarmist in its predictions. Climate has always changed and there are extremes occurances in weather. This phenomenon is not new. The term "climate change" is the new substitute for "global warming". Although CO2 is conisered a greenhouse gas but water vapour has 40 times the warming potential and there is significantly more water vapour in the atmosphere than carbon dioxide. CO2 is a natural gas and plants need CO2 to grow and live.

Plate tectonics explains the changes in sea levels. Continental shelves are moving with respect to each other. There is movement in the land mass and consequently changes in the measured sea level, which incidently has been rising linearly for the last 100 years. 

Computer models are just systems that try to predict future outcomes and these predictions have proved to be false. Weather forecasting is not accurate beyond 5 days or so. So models that try to predict outcomes over hundreds of years is just hokum.

The apparent rise in average global temperature which is about 0.8 K in the last 150 years or so is from a low pre-industrial period when there was a mini ice age. There is a lot of geological evidence that shows the earth's surface temperature being higher with low CO2 concentrations and vice versa. In short there's no correlation between changes to C02 concentrations and changes to temperature.

This video piece is just promoting pseudo-science. So don't worry folks about CO2 emissions rising but rather worry about the rise in social conflict engineered by demagogues.

author: Jørn Pettersen

text:
Most of what you are saying is true, however you come to the wrong conclusion:
- Indeed water is far more effective at trapping heat on the planet, but has the concentration of water increase in the last 200 years at a very rapid pace? No, however CO2 has. The excess gives rise to new problems, not the natural abundance. 
- Plate tectonics indeed do explain rise in sea-levels, but only over millions of years. The effect seen in 200 years can thus not be explained by plate tectonics.
- There is a big difference between weather models and climate models. Weather is indeed very hard to predict over a long period of time (due to chaos), however climate is interested in the longer term effects such as yearly oscillation swings (due to summer and winter) and seasonal effects. We know these models work well since we used these on data from a long time ago and if we stop them at our current data they give the correct conclusions. This is the first test that is done to check if the model work. After many more tests we can eventually use the model if all tests were successful. That is why computer models are useful.
- We can measure the effects of CO2 on the heat-trapping in the laboratory and clearly see these effects. Also even if there were times were the C02 concentration was lower and the temperature higher this still is no argument against the trapping of heat by C02, it just shows that there is more than one factor involved. Now over the last 200 years we have seen little change in all other known factors, however the C02 concentration has doubled.

Lastly I would like to emphasize again that it is al about the time intervals. The big problem is not the rise nor the net increase in temperature. It is the fact that this all is happening in a very small time window of +- 200 years.
author: Simon De Kock

text:
You're advancing a strawman argument. I said that climate has changed always. I also said that the apparent rise in average surface temperature since the start of the industrial revolution is referenced against a lower average temperature when the earth was going through a mini ice age. 

There is no correlation between CO2 concentration and global temperature. In the period between 1950 and 1975 the average temperature was decrteasing whilst CO2 levels still continued to rise. Examiniation of geological records has provided evidence of periods when the CO2 levels were high (around 3000 ppm) with corresponding low average temperatures and vice versa.

The models used to predict climate change outcomes are based on one ones used to predict weather. Weather referes to atmopheric condition over a short time whereas climate is looking at atmospheric conditions over a long period.

I suggest you refrain from ad hominem attacks at this only undermines your credibility.
author: John Mitchinson

Land mass with heavy cloud cover is much warmer than land mass with a clear sky.

So what that CO2 levels have risen to about 410 ppm. Pterodactyls were flying in the late jurasic period when the atmosphere had concentrations of about 3,000 ppm. 

Rather than worrying about CO2 levels arising out of human activity we should be looking at spending our precious time on combating social upheaval owing to the rising global population.

text:
(Responding to the first comment, aka the one replying to my earlier one) There was an ice age around 1860. However, if you look at the global temerature overtime from before the ice age, you'll see that it goes a lot higher than before the ice age. Why would an ice age cause tempertures to go much higher than before, and in such a short amount of time?

Ever heard of an 'anomly'? If one part of a data is out, that does not mean there's no correlation. It means either it was random or it's a weak correlation, but still a correlation. Anyways, we can say for certain that, at least since 1970, there is a positive correlation between the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere and the global average temperature. If you're disputing that, then you don't know how graphs work.

This isn't to do with language. Do you think that people set up a model to track something far into the future and used the word 'weather' to refer to it over a short time? No. Let's not argue with language because it'll get us nowhere. They meant to track them into the future, why would they use something that doesn't work into the future?

Actually, what I said wasn't ad hominem. I didn't attack anything about your character. I was referring to 'cognative dissonanse', which I hoped would be explained by the last sentence in brackets. But, basically, when people find evidence that contradicts what they already belive, it causes a fight or flight response. So, people tend to ignore contrasting evidence and only listen to what supports their belifes. I'm not immune to it and you aren't either. I try my best to avoid it where I can, though. And I hope in this instance you can find your way over it too.

The mini ice age in the late medieval period lasted for about 150 years or so. This means temperatures were higher with low CO2 levels prior to onset of the ice age and post. 

In the mid 1970s scientist at the time were predicting global cooling because the preceding 15 years or so the world experienced a drop in average temperatures.

The world is not going to end with rising temperatures and so don't worry. Get yourself an ice cream and enjoy the sunshine whilst it lasts.

text:
10% increase in plant biomass since the 80's only due to Co2, another 4% due to the warmer climate. It's one of the main limiting factors in plant growth, the other being nitrogen and water which indirectly also benefit from increased levels of Co2. Nitrogen due to the symbiotic relationship between plants and nitrogen fixating bacteria, more plants also mean more of those bacteria, and water due to the increased water use efficiency, less water needed for the same growth due to plants being able to close their carbon intaking, but also water losing mouths longer. 
The current heat wave is an anomaly, I hear the alarmists mocking sceptics for pointing out to a cold winter and go like oh see there's no global warming. This is the same except reverse, talk about the long term trends please. Alarmists and pointing to droughts go hand in hand even if there's an increase in rainfall when the weather is warmer, droughts have been DECREASING in the 20th century. If the dust bowl happened now the media would be all over it how it would be evidence for global warming and a worsening climate. 
And when talking about the long term trends I have no convidence in the IPCC ever being right due to how wrong they have been in the past and just assuming there's a massive positive feedback loop between the warming effect of Co2 and other factors. They assume there's a net positive feedback loop although logically there'd be a net negative feedback due to the climate not having gone crazy in the past. Never mind the glossing over of major positive news of Co2 fertilization being beneficial, they hide it as a sidenote because it doesn't fit their narritive of the earth going to shit

text:
Climate change has been happening since the Earth first had a climate. I can hear by your Left biased science that you probably went to school since Tony Bliar basically destroyed the British education system, leaving us with generations of people who have not been taught how to think, and do not understand the science related to climate, or much else. You have found a new religion, great, now learn something.
No, I am not trained as a climate scientist, but neither ore you, nor most of the people who will troll my comment, and most of the scientists listed by the IPCC are either not climate specialists, or not qualified. Many have asked for their names to be removed from the list.
I was taught to think, study the data, and then come to a conclusion, unlike Millennials. The Climate Change alarmists have come to a conclusion because of Al Gore (not a climate scientist) and have spent the last 30 years trying to prove it by massaging the data to fit the false narrative. The Hockey Stick graph had two mini-ice ages removed because they would drag the average temperature over the past thousand years downwards, and prove that there has been no warming.
The data shows that the rise in CO2 FOLLOWS the alleged rise in temperature, it does not cause it. The data is easy enough to find, even the IPCC does not hide it.
Sun spot levels indicate a link between the number of sun spots and how hot the Earth gets.
The Earth has been globally hotter than today twice during the past 2,000 years, when the Romans were in the UK, and during the Medieval period. No industrialisation during either period. No excessive and unnecessary green taxation either.
CO2 levels are currently not far off the lowest they have ever been on the planet.
The absurd 97% of scientists came from a survey sent out by an American cartoonist (NOT a climate scientist, not even a scientist) with deliberately vague questions which gave vague answers very open to interpretation.
Besides that, there is the absurd premise that you know what 100% of scientists believe.
If we were able to reduce the level of CO2 the people most affected would be agrarian societies (look it up). Plants need CO2, we need plants, therefore, the less CO2, the less plants. It would eventually affect the Climate Change fanatics but only when it's too late, and crop yields fall below what the Human Race needs to survive. Farmers pump CO2 into greenhouses to increase yields, basic science. For those who insist CO2 is harmful to humans, it is still barely more than a trace gas in our atmosphere and increasing it ten-fold would have little effect on us, but would greatly increase crop yield for poor agrarian societies.
I am surprised, and saddened, that people are still following Al Gore's lies and not thinking for themselves.

text:
SmellyPotatoes Mc
You people are being simple minded. Yes, co2 is a greenhouse gas. Yes greenhouse gases trap heat. Yes man's emissions add co2 to the atmosphere. No, that is not warming the planet. Let's start with the basics. The SUN warms the planet NOT co2. You must grasp the concept to continue. At night, unless a warm front moves in, it will ALWAYS cool down because the sun is NOT shining. It really is that simple. Since you are being simple minded please keep that in mind as I continue. The sun warms the planet NOT co2. 

The earth's climate is predominantly homeostatic in that positive and negative feedback loops keep the earth's temperature in balance. I will discuss two of these positive and negative feedback loops below to explain how they help keep the earth's temperature in balance but first know this too. According to NOAA (not my figures, theirs) the earth has warmed 0.7 - 0.9 degrees since coming out of the last glacial period 1901 to present. Considering we were in a glacial period and we are not in one now that is pretty damn stable if you ask me. Right? Less than 1 degree change is stable in anybodies book! 

The two positive and negative feedback loops I will discuss are the carbon cycle and albedo. 

The carbon cycle: 

The oceans, lakes, rivers streams, etc  are by far the largest carbon sinks on earth. Carbon sinks store co2. i.e. they trap co2 from the atmosphere. As it warms (due to the solubility of gases in water) these bodies of water release more of their co2 into the atmosphere aka gasing. notice, the warming comes first, then the gasing occurs. Is it any wonder that it is warmer and there is more co2 in the atmosphere? No! Warming causes gasing. The co2 levels in the atmosphere must always increase as we warm. 

Albedo:

Albedo is the property of reflecting sunlight back into space. It is the opposite of a greenhouse gas. It prevents heat from reaching the earth from the sun. Clouds have by far the greatest albedo effect on the earth. They reflect sunlight before it can reach earth and warm it and be trapped by greenhouse gases. Got it? 

Now, as it waRMS AN INTERESTING NEGATIVE FEEDBACK LOOP KICKS IN. As the earth warms more water evaporates resulting in more moisture in the air. This moister forms clouds. Warming leads to cloud formations. The warmer it is the more clouds there are due to the evaporation of water. As these clouds form more sunlight is blocked and viola! The earth begins to cool. Less sunlight means cooler weather just as night is cooler than day. Another interesting feedback loop kicks in. More clouds and rain means more co2 is washed out of the atmosphere (aka weathering). And since the earth is cooler more of that co2 will remain "trapped" aka stored in the oceans rivers lakes streams ponds etc. Viola! Less co2 means less heat id trapped and cooling continues on and on BUT these feedback loops are so effective it means overall temperature variations over the period in excess of a hundred years is a mere 0.7 to 0.9 degrees even though we are coming out of an ice age! That is freaking stable! You see? The SUN drives the climate NOT co2! There is more but if you cannot grasp this you are hopeless.  Man additions of co2 have only served to green the earth. Greening has occurred in the amount of the continental united states in the past 50 years or so. Plants are also co2 store houses that scrub co2 from the atmosphere. This all used to be 5th grade science. they are LYING to you! co2 is plant fucking food! The earth's climate is extremely stable and can handle periods of volcanic activity with no problem.  You people are being duped! get out of your information ghetto and look at real science. They are LIARS! They want your money and they want control of the earth. This shit is purely political. Not science!
author: Crystal Giddens

text:
"They just cannot accept that humans can change the world." That is another lie told by alarmist. In order to convince people that sceptics are not smart enough they lie and say stupid things like this.The reality is we know we are changing the world, just we are using science to look at the reality of it.

Dams are changing rushing river into lakes and stopping floods. Most of the time this is good, but there are times when it isnt. Take for instance river deltas. When you stop flooding, you stop the river from putting new material on top of old. The result is that the mud below gradually gets squeezed out causing the land to subside. The result is that cities built on these are getting flooded by the sea.

Agriculture is turning deserts into farm land. This changes the climate around them.

Building cities causes heat islands and the micro climates that spring up around them as a result. This changes the climate as a whole as well. Building roads also changes the climate.

Building islands changes the ocean currents. This in change changes the atmospheric currents.

We have changed the environment in multiple ways, BUT there is no evidence that we have altered the global temperature much. The evidence says that the atmospheric sensitivity to changes in co2 is actually pretty low, if not zero. All the alarms require it to be something like 4°C per doubling of co2, but all the models that use that, are off by almost half a degree in 17 years. A  model based on the absorption of energy by water melted from glaciers is off by .1°C in 70 years. That model totally ignored co2, saying that the atmospheric sensitivity was zero.

No, it is not the ones you call deniers that deny science, but alarmist.

The problem with this is that there is also another factor. Certain cosmic radiation can cause the clouds to form sooner. This is what happen during the little ice age.

text:
​ @Lady Flibblesworth  It's hilarious reading these comments by sofa scientists who somehow think their "scientific" opinion holds as much merit as a relevant expert with a phD. Funnily enough,  you can't just "look it up" and understand it Barry the Baker; it takes years worth of understanding in atmospheric physics and chemistry etc. Who should we believe? The above 85% consenus by climatologists or some dumb fuck who has a Google Degree and worked out CO2 is "plant food".

@Crystal Giddens
I'm hazarding a guess that you are not a scientist - correct me if I'm wrong.

Please have some very basic understanding of CO2 fixation in LIR before even approaching the complexity of climate science. If you don't understand pre-university photosynthesis it really casts doubt on your ability to understand free-radical substitution, ODS mechanisms and radiative forcing etc. If it's 5th grade you should be aware that stomatal closure occurs among plants when exposed to an excess of CO2 to reduce water vapour loss right? ;) 

No one is denying the sun is responsible for heating. It's simply accepted and considered within this argument; the Melankovitch cycle is already well documented and so have the impacts of sunspots - mathematically we tend to treat solar input as a constant (Gsc) due to the huge amount of data we can access/are currently monitoring. That is why solar forcing may not be seen explicitly accounted for within an abstract; solar variance is marginal and at most Gsc would be minorly manipulated depending upon the circumstances of a specific study. 

That is why we assess the impact of other variables against the fact we know solar variance is minimal/predominantly constant; the basic assumption being if solar input doesn't change but global temperatures increase there must be other factors responsible. 

Your tripe about the albedo effect is also fairly irrelevant - by your logic we would already be experiencing a global average of negative radiative forcing due to cloud reflection and our increased global temperatures. However, clouds do not have total global coverage! Even if that was to be the case, not all clouds exact the same strength of albedo effect; the action of albedo by some clouds is miniscule (0) to (for e.g. as with some stratocumulus) up to 0.8. It is also fairly impossible to assume a constant value for average cloud albedo considering we cannot predict the exact composition of cloud type globally to the same degree of accuracy as Gsc for example, especially as many factors (droplet size etc) effect albedo strength. 

You also seem to fail to understand that additional greenhouse warming has an accessory effect to "natural warming"; no one is claming CO2 is purely responsible for warming, however it's coalesence in the upper troposphere and translation of KE to other gaseous molecules in the troposphere is scientifically accepted, and responsible for tropospheric warming. It also addresses your mistake in being unable to separate the distinction between tropospheric warming and stratospheric cooling. For example KE translation in the stratosphere will result in cooling from the deexcitation of CO2 that has absorbed IR. But the important point is that the most relevant (to heating) CO2 coalesces in the upper troposphere; the same KE translation mechanism doesn't occur - instead emitted radiation is absorbed by closer, and warmer CO2 at a higher pressure and that heat is trapped.  This occurs ever more likely at higher tropospheric CO2 quantities, in simple terms in accordance to Kinetic Theory (admittedly, it is more complicated than that).

CO2's physical properties exact warming and cooling at different atmospheric levels; a simple fact you should be aware of. Your statement about atmopheric escape in relation to CO2 is also irrelevant. CO2 does not "leave the atmosphere" it is too heavy to undergo Jean's escape, and due to a lot of complicated processes I don't have the time to explain CO2 is typically sequestered. But that does not mean CO2 levels are not a concern as sequestering CAN happen; it's a concern because we are releasing atmopheric CO2 at a much greater rate than is naturally or artificially (carbon capture etc.) sequestered. That is a statistical fact due to the increased concentrations of CO2 recorded. 

And this is just ONE factor that can impact global flucutation. I'm not even taking into account the different mechanisms for different greenhouse gases and the implications of o-zone depletion or the effects upon weathering patterns and their consequences

"Pure science" you will find from the consensus of 12,000 climatology journals from peer-reviewed publishers, and from individuals like Dr. Simon Clarke who possess specialist knowledge of the subject. The fact that no scientific international or national bodies openly disagree with the AR5 published by the IPCC should not be ignored.

text:
"The data shows that the rise in CO2 FOLLOWS the alleged rise in temperature, it does not cause it"

It is true that temps can rise prior to Co2 level rise. It has happened in the past. Scientists are well aware of this. It's brought on by the Milankovich cycles. A change in the cycles can increase the amount of sunlight hitting the earth. Which causes initial melting of ice and snow cover. Which then leads to thawing of the land and oceans, releasing Co2 and Methane. Which then causes more warming and a positive forcing/feedback on the global climate. However, more than one thing can be true. Co2 a greenhouse gases. They absorbs long wave radiation(heat) from the sun. So what is happening recently, Co2 levels have increased since the start of the industrial revolution and now temperatures are rising with it. This is the Anthropogenic aspect of recent climate change!

https://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/carbon-dioxide/
https://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/global-temperature/

"Sun spot levels indicate a link between the number of sun spots and how hot the Earth gets"

The sun's total solar irradiance(TSI) changes very little over the course of years, decades or millennia(fractions of a %). And right now, the sun's TSI has been in consistent decline. This, combined with our current stage in the Milankovich cycles suggests that our temps should be cooling. But they're not!

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_cycle
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milankovitch_cycles#Present_and_future_conditions

"Plants need CO2"

Plants also need water, nitrogen and sunlight. And plants, and the larger biosphere, can only absorb so much Co2. So adding too much will do nothing more for them.

"For those who insist CO2 is harmful to humans, it is still barely more than a trace gas in our atmosphere"

Co2 is harmful in large levels. You wouldn't lock yourself in your garage with your car running...or put a bag over your head and think nothing bad would happen would you? Also, Co2 doesn't have to be a large part of our atmosphere to have an affect.

"I am surprised, and saddened, that people are still following Al Gore's lies and not thinking for themselves"

Al Gore is not a scientist. Please tell me what scientists or followers of the scientific method believe everything Al Gore said.

author: Bill Fox

text:
"It seems to be that water vapour is a far larger problem than CO2"

Water vapor is a stronger ghg but is not a primary driver of climate. It responds to climate drivers. Cold air holds less water vapor, while hot air holds more. So the atmosphere would have to warm first in order for water vapor to increase. Not only that, but water vapor does not sit in the atmosphere for long periods of time like Co2 does. And the atmosphere can only hold so much water.

"You have also proved your total lack of scientific knowledge"

What have i gotten wrong so far? Co2 is a component of vehicle exhaust as is breathing. How is that a straw man? If you want to have a scientific discussion, then i suggest you back up your claims with peer reviewed evidence. That's how the scientific method works!

Case in point: "Before that, we had been warned for decades of an impending ice age if we didn't stop burning fossil fuels" Source?

And Climate change is not a religion. It's an outcome of science. And science is most definitely NOT religion!

text: And, the stoichiometry of the combustion of hydrocarbons  yields, by mass, 17% H2O and 83% CO2. The H2O is by far the strongest greenhouse gas in this reaction and increases the Earth's temperature. Granted, it will leave the atmosphere quicker but don't ignore it's IMMEDIATE contribution to warming and its constant generation. A runaway cooling trend is far more likely than a runaway heating trend. Witness the Ice Age. All it takes is a large emission of volcanic ash in the northern hemisphere to kick it off, leading to a snow dusting of land masses greatly affecting the surface albedo and the greenhouse reduction of water vapor by cooling. We see this in small telltale signs today in the historic temperature recordings of city temperatures in some Januarys.

text:
In order to reverse the climate change you have to reverse the economic parameters that have driven this development. The current parameters are: exhausting natural resources and polluting the environment is profitable (the companies that make the profits don't pay for the natural resource itself, and don't pay for the environemental damage, at least not the full price of it). The new parameters should be: recreating natural resources and cleaning the environment should be profitable, exhausting natural resources and polluting it penalizable to the extend of the real cost. 

The fundamental problem in our capitalist society is that the costs of nature are ZERO. For example an oil company does not pay anything for the crude oil, the only costs are for a) the geological research, b) drilling and extracting c) refining and distributing/transportation, which lead to the cost price of oil, and when sold, to the market value based on supply/demand.
Also the amount of Co2 released into the atmosphere and other polutants and environenemental damage that is done to the planet, are not paid for.

Things we should make profitable:
- Turning deserts into forests.
- Cleaning rivers, seas and oceans from plastics.
- Green, renewable energy.
- Ecological restoration.

text: The title of your video is entirely misleading - climate change is ongoing and has been since water first landed on our hulk of rock; there is nothing to reverse, it simply changes (clue's in the title). I won't get into the emotionally charged debate about the extent to which humans are contributing to CO2, but I will point out that the start of the video was showing how wonderfully clever people have worked out how to extract CO2 from the air and create an energy dense fuel? So off I go to read the paper, and, hmmmmmm. Am I missing the bleeding obvious here? Does nature not do a fantastic job of extracting CO2 from the air in the form of photosynthesising organisms such as plants, including trees, which can lock away carbon for hundreds, or even thousands of years? Can these same trees be used for fuel? That's quite a reinvention of a very old wheel. And what is the immediate cost to the environment of this proposed facility? We're already dealing with mountains of toxic waste created as a by-product of the rush to 'renewable' energy, not to mention a huge increase in the carbon footprint needed to mine materials, move it, processing and so on. If some people took their heads out of their technological backsides we might start getting to grips with problems properly, and realise that not every problem demands a technical solution.

text:
"data clearly shows CO2 was much higher yet no humans existed" Humans aren't the only things that can increase CO2 concentrations.
"actually in an abnormal cooling period compared to historical data" You'd only get this cooling if you gloss over millions of years and thereon you'd have an arbitrary trendline which would be literally meaningless.
"CO2 at those levels has little to do if anything with temperature changes" Funny, no other forcing (even the sun) would have any correlation with temperature changes over those time periods. Put forcings together... different story.
""scientists" to make these dire predictions" Define dire.
"can't even predict weather from year to year little alone over decades of time." It becomes easier because you get rid of short term fluctuations, the amount of necessary variables drops drastically.
"go look up the data including the Mesozoic period and explain the total contradictory facts to what these scientists are saying." You mean having an arbitrary trendline? It's meaningless because climate change only when something forces it to change. How does looking at climate change 200 million years ago help us know what causes climate to change now? It doesn't.
"here's plenty of charts out there that make this easy to see." They are always misinterpreted.
"it's just not human caused." What is it caused by?
" because the world is just doing what it has and will continue to do for millions upon millions of years." meaningless
