Since my posts got removed I'll shorten it up by dealing with one of your more strange questions. 
How does looking at climate change 200 million years ago help us know what causes climate to change now? Because CO2,  temperatures and the condition of the planet are known during that period. We can easily determine if significant C02 changes effected temperatures. Scientists have gathered such information like how the Earth was formed, what animals and plant life lived, the suns activity and the state of the planet in that period. Unless you believe all the books on this are just a wild guess.
BTW, I would ask you to review the paper by Ernest-Georg Beck which shows no significant change in ppm since industry started. The data used in the current models excludes deviations beyond 10% of the average along with other data based on arbitrary reasons. This would obviously change the slopes in the model.

text:
Ander Lillemaa
If they looked at climate as a whole then the "CO2", crisis that they keep blabbering about is completely irrelevant. It doesn't make any logical sense to say CO2 was the cause when if you haven't noticed, The industrial age where we at most would "effect", the earth with CO2 was thousands and thousands of years AFTER the Ice age and global high temperatures. That's like saying I blame my dog for cat scratches on the couch that was left after having a cat. It's stupid. You can't put blame on something that wasn't around.

Looking at the Ice age and looking at the hot recorded temperatures in Roman literature and blaming all of that on rising CO2 levels caused by the industrial age isn't, "looking at the issue as a whole". Its called find something to blame it on. Anyone with any intellect can pull up the earth's temperature history and see that it's always BEEN in fluctuation. BEFORE we dug up dead plants AKA CO2 for fuel.

Ok, PART 1 of this comment, here’s what the paper about the carbon emissions reabsorption mechanism says:
“CONTEXT AND SCALE:
This design reflects roughly 100 person-years of development by Carbon Engineering.

[...]

INTRODUCTION:
Estimates of the cost of DAC vary widely. Cost estimates based on simple scaling relationships yield results from 50 to 1 000 $/t CO2.

[...]

DISCUSSION (Comparison with prior estimates)
Our cost range is 94–232 $/t-CO2 captured, and if we use the financial and gas price assumptions of the APS (CRF = 12% and 6 $/GJ), then our costs would be 107–249 $/t-CO2 for the A and B variants in Table 2. [...] The APS study and a subsequent paper assumed use of hundreds of vertically oriented counterflow packed towers using a design common to post-combustion CCS. This design requires 190 kWhr/t-CO2 of energy and has a capital intensity of $1,304 $/t-CO2-year.

[...]

(Prospects for technology development and cost reduction)
It is difficult to estimate the cost of a technology prior to its widespread deployment. CE has spent several tens of millions of dollars developing DAC technology, yet our performance and cost estimates still carry substantial uncertainty. [...] The process described here should therefore be seen as a low-risk starting point rather than a fully optimized least-cost design.
Many small process changes will incrementally improve performance relative to the baseline described here.”

PART 2, don’t you think that THAT’s the cost for A PROTOTYPE operating ? We’re humans, we can build a lot more than that and a lot better than what they’ve theoretically imagined, expected and estimated.

Again, that’s an estimate, we still don’t know the real cost, and innovation’ll make nothing else than lower that cost.

text:
I've come to accept that climate change probably will drive us to extinction. I'm not happy about it (in fact most of my life I've been terrified of it), but we're careening towards it and we seem to hardly care at all. The average person is forced to contribute to the problem on a daily basis just to do their jobs, live in their homes and feed themselves and their families. We can't change human nature; this is who we are and what we've chosen to do with the world we've been given. And that's okay, earth has had a long history and there has never been any reason to think we're any better off than all the other species that have gone extinct over that time. If we cook the planet until we can no longer survive on it, oh well; we'll go extinct and life will carry on as it has following numerous extinction events like the one we're causing.

Personally, I hope we can figure out how to colonize other planets, not for our own sake but for the sake of the rest of life on earth. We're the only species that has ever been able to go to space and it's doubtful there will ever be another one after us, and without that ability life on earth is doomed to go out with the sun. We're the only species that can make it possible for life to survive earth's inevitable demise. Imagine if we managed to figure that out, we could seed life all over the universe and it could go on until the end of time itself. That would be the only achievement I can think of that would justify our existence in spite of every awful thing people have done to the world and to each other.

text: This is spectacularly incorrect. CO2 and global temperature have been proven to have an *analytical*, never mind a statistical, link since the early 20th century.
author: Simon Clark

text: Then how is it that the two have been in constant flux at different rates of increase and decrease throughout the eras to the present day. We're talking as far back as the Precambrian era all the way to today. There have been times where CO2 has been very low but the temperatures were very high like near the end of the Paleozoic era and the reverse has been true before near the end of the Precambrian and just after the start of the cenozoic. The two intersecting isn't unheard of but it's already proven in the mid 2000s that one has nothing to do with the other as any sort of a cause and effect scenario. There's just no correlation to be had.

author: Ander Lillemaa

text:
then why is it NEVER on the same wavelength as temperatures in regards to the constant flux that the two are in? In one era one's high and the other low in the next the reverse is true and they intersect in between. The alarmists only focus on the more recent part of the cycle, say the last few millennia. If you go further back over the millions of years rather than thousands you'll see that one does not correlate with the other at all. If one forced the other then there would be correlation, something that is shown to clearly not be the case.

If humanity had any hand in global temperatures at all, it's minuscule at best.
author: Jormungand13324

text: Because CO2 isn't the only thing influencing the climate (the paper makes a point that sun + CO2 has very good correlation) and the "skeptics" misunderstand that nobody is saying it is. Then why are people saying CO2 is the cause of the modern warming period? Because it's the main reason for the time period in question. 1000 years ago, the reason for temperature change was different. A million years ago it was different still.
author: Ander Lillemaa

text:
And what about other factors? Earth wobbling axis, for example? We're going nowhere on the CO2 point so let's look for other factors. The earth wobbles on its axis and there are gradual changes in the shape of Earth's orbit from elliptical to circular. The change in tilt happens along a 40k year cycle on average going between 22.1 and 24.5 degrees. Given the current tilt, we appear to be in the middle of that cycle and it even wobbles in the process. As the tilt increases the seasons can get more severe, the question is, is the tilt currently increasing in this cycle or decreasing?

And there's the 90k-100k year cycle where the earth's orbit around the sun changes, where are we in that cycle, because that can also affect climate?

Sources for the cycles and wobbling axis; https://climate.nasa.gov/news/2428/study-solves-two-mysteries-about-wobbling-earth/
https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/Milankovitch/milankovitch_2.php
author: Jormungand13324

text:
They are factored in, that why they are used to explain some of the changes that have been happening in climate in history. For example, Milankovitch cycles (the same thing you were talking about) are used to explain the ice age "cycles"
Sure other factors, like greenhouse gases and albedo, are counted as well but changes in Earth's position are thought to be the main culprit of these specific changes.
author: Ander Lillemaa

text: However the question remains, is the tilt increasing or decreasing? If the tilt's decreasing, we'll see more moderate seasons as the centuries and millennia go on. But if it's increasing, the seasons will only become more severe as time goes on. And don't forget that decades ago the climate change crowd was going on about "global cooling" and the prospect of an imminent ice age. Then it went to global warming and "the ice caps will be gone very soon" and now it's climate change.  So you'll have to forgive the skepticism regarding the possibility of human involvement because of the politics behind the science. Or rather the proposed solution which revolves around politics.

text: great video.  for me this information is great news.  I find the fact that we could spend 3 trillion a year to REDUCE CATASTROPHIC climate change to be very good.  I fully think we are going to reach 100% renewable energy system on the economics alone.  we should not be screaming about negative emissions from the mountain top, but we should selectively to people who are depressed about climate change.  A small portion of the population is very depressed about climate change.  If we could better mobilize these people to do a few simple things then we could really accelerate stopping our emissions.  Not eating meat is right on.  it feels like a small difference but its not.  Even if you only cut out meat a few meals a weeks and occasionally buy meat substitutes that is making a huge difference because you are helping to bring down the cost of meat substitutes.  the price of meat substitutes is falling fast and their quality is improving.  Eventually they will taste very similar to meat and be substantially cheaper.  so you cannot just think about the emissions that you directly reduce by eathing less meat.  your purchases now, will help make a future where meat substitutes and lab grown meat are actually mainstream primarily based on cost.  The same is true with EVs.  There are 2 billion cars on the road and only 4 million are EVs.  seems sad, but no it is not.  Those 4 million EVs being sold has helped the cost of batteries fall tremendously.  buying a EV, especially a Tesla is probably the best thing you can do for the environment.  Tesla plans for the future are completely different than what most people think.  They aim to make an self-driving electric car that can last for 1 million miles.  an average person would take a lifetime to drive a million miles, but not a self-driving taxi.  a self-driving taxi systems could reduce the number of cars we need by a factor 7-15.  so for example, instead of needing to making 15 million news cars a year.  we might only have to make 1-2 millions if we all gave up owning a car.  we could also saves thousands of dollars every year.  as we buy EVs are also lowering the cost of batteries, which is the last piece of the puzzle for getting to 100% renewable energy.  so if you decide to buy an EV now you are helping to fund that sustainable future.  do not think about the direct emissions you prevent.  Think about how you are helping to make the technology cheaper.  trust me I am a writer for cleantechnica, and I have watched the prices of wind, solar, batteries, and EVs fall consistently year after year.  early adopters are making a massive differnce.  all these technologies still have a lot of room for improvement and cost declines.  do not let trump get you down.  The problem is still solvable and whatever little bit you can do is helpful.  decades from now we will probably begin negative emissions operations.  The money will not matter when we see our cities start to flood more regularly.  we will prevent civilization from collapsing.  Ten year ago, I would have thought human civilization as we know it was done for, but I have seen the cost of solar decline by 80% in the last decade.  Batteries have declined even further from that.  one other great opportunity you will have soon is to invest in green bonds.  most green bonds are being sold to large investors but they are starting to sell them in 1,000 increments.  you earn a few percent and you help fund renwable energy.  Stay positive and do what you can.

text:
The Vostok ice core samples show that changes in the earth's climate directly affect the atmospheric CO2 levels with a gap of about 800 years as the oceans respond to the global temperature change. Why do warmists always fudge that fact and give the impression that it is CO2 affecting temperature when it is actually the other way around with temperature leading the CO2 levels? Warm water expels CO2 while colder water absorbs it. Got it? Why is this fact so thoroughly hidden from the public? And why is the little ice, the Medieval warm period, the Roman warm period, and the mid-twentieth century cold period ignored while the discredited "hockey stick" graph is still considered gospel? It's a con and all the grifters belong in jail. 

Personally, I would like to see the good professors serving lengthy sentences in re-education farm camps getting lots of fresh air and exercise as they plow the good earth with wooden tools in their bare feet...especially Drs. Michael Mann and Cliff Jones.

text: There is nothing that can be done. Period. Reason being a majority of the warming trend has to do with higher than normal amounts of solar radiation hitting the ocean creating more cloud cover trapping more heat and causing the ocean to release more co2. The Earth's core is all outta whack and the protective shell around the earth isn't working as it should. Not too long ago people were seeing Aurora Borealis as far south as the Ozark here in the US which is in northern frickin Arkansas which is crazy in and of itself. Churning in the earth's liquid outer core results in the dynamo that generates and maintains the the earth's magnetic field which helps protect us from harmful solar wind - when that protective shielding gets upset it can't block out as much of that radiation which is causing the oceans to rise in temperature.  The core has been sloshing about at an unstable rate resulting in more volcanic eruptions, earthquakes of greater magnitude and frequency and a measurable change in geyser activity (not to mention some of the other weird shit like buckling roads, 65-70 foot deep chasms opening up in numerous areas in the world over night in some places.) Yeah, so your main culprit for all this is right under your feet. The more research you do, the more it will become obvious - it seems completely disingenuous to give false hope that humanity can solve this issue that it's not even fully responsible for to begin with. That said, we should still cut back on fossil fuels and work at using renewable energy finding a way to harness the power from these more powerful storms might be a really good way to start cause they're only going to get worse no matter what humanity does. I hate the politicization of the whole global warming trend. It is not within humanity's control and it never was.

text:
"You keep projecting things on me that I didn't say or imply." I didn't say you did. Don't take it personally.
Yes, although you oversimplyfy it to the point it becomes dubious to even suggest using models. The models can recreate 20th century climate fairly accurately. You lack a component which is scenarios of how forcings will change. For example, you have no idea how much CO2 we will be emitting in 10 years. 
About models http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2016/05/comparing-models-to-the-satellite-datasets/
Note that this is quite old and 2016 and 17 were much hotter than 15.
"I never said peer reviewed papers said these things" Irrelevant. Science isn't confirmed in a popularity contest between popular news articles. You didn't say it is, it's a rhetorical point, don't get upset.

"there is no way to tell" Why don't you ask them how they did it? It would be more constructive than playing a blaming game.
"they are making everyone skeptical of the science of climate change"
Because I've seen enough crazy to notice that all of the arguments "pointing out the propaganda" are born in falsehood. There is always this "yes, but..." moment if they aren't wrong from the get go. For example, take the argument "scientists predicted ice age in the 70s" which we know they didn't. How many people are seeding doubt by false information. How many saw the global warming swindle movie and didn't bother to question anything? How many people looked at the climategate hype and didn't bother to actually read the emails? How many people walked away from actual science because of misinformation from the people who claimed to be standing up for the truth?
Who or what is actually seeding the doubt? I claim it's the ones who think they uncovered the big lie, not UN climate policies.

text:
Questions for you to (not) answer. 
1. Why hasn't the temperature got up in the last 21 years?
2. If you say it has gone up some microscopic amount, how come it didn't come close to keeping pace with the CO2 parts per million?
3. Why are many temperature sensors located in heat islands, exaggerating any kind of heat increases you claim might have happened?
4. Why has the ice increased so much on Antarctica and in the Arctic? Follow up question, Al Gore said by now the oceans would have risen 100 feet. Why haven't they?
5. Why is it snowing in South Africa for the first time in 150 years?
6. Why do the patterns of flood, drought and cold resemble weather patterns from the last Ice Age?
7. At what point will you flip, claiming CO2 has caused the Ice Age?
8. Why is it that the earth has experienced CO2 levels as high as 7000 ppm compared to the levels of today, a measly 400 ppm, Without factories and gasoline engines?
9. Al Gore famously predicted with the coming global warming/ climate change there would be an increase in hurricanes and tornadoes. How come neither of those have come true?
10. We were told polar bears would become extinct, yet there are more polar bears today than ever!
11. The United States only has a few dozen icebreakers while Russia will have close to 100 soon. While the United States ignored the reality of increased ice in the north, Russia knew that in order to take advantage of the resources, they would need icebreakers. 

 So, you will either ignore these questions, delete them or ban me. Which one?

text:
1. They have.
2. Because most of the carbon has been absorbed into the oceans.
3. Because that's where the people are. And these biases are accounted for in global averages using surface observations.
4. Ice has substantially melted in the Arctic summer on summer. The interior of the east Antarctic has seen some localised ice gain, but the net change is negative.
5. For the same reason that the UK had an extremely cold winter this year - changes in global temperature and precipitation patterns due to increased energy in the atmosphere.
6. I've never seen this in the literature, but it likely is due to boundary conditions (i.e. uniform radiative forcing on a spherical domain)
7. When peer-reviewed science supports this. So no time soon, as consensus is overwhelming.
8. Natural volcanism and ecological processes over millions of years. The current quantity of CO2 isn't alarming, it's unprecedented rate of change that is.
9. Tropical storm frequency in the north Atlantic has increased from approximately 11 to 16 per year.
10. This is a lie. Polar bear numbers are decreasing in 17 of 19 distinct populations in the Arctic, with a definite net global negative.
11. Icebreakers are useful in an environment where there is ice and open water, not just ice alone. An increase in icebreakers represents a clearing of the Arctic in summer.


Questions answered. I'm clearly not going to change your mind, but I want you to know that there are answers to your questions and that we can have a sensible, educational discourse about this.

text:
Lots of ridiculous crap has passed the peer review process, I hope you won't be shocked to find out that doesn't make it correct or gospel truth. The term "peer reviewed" is given much creedence by people who don't comprehend what the peer review process entails, much less the politics and sins of omission that have become common place factors in how and why research is conducted in the first place. 

Needless to say, review does not imply agreement, widespread support, or bestow some enchantment of omnifiscient credibility on an idea or article.  The people reviewing an article are often not nearly as well versed in the subject they are reviewing as the author of the paper, for instance.  

The debate between Dr. Spencer and Dr. Denning is a balanced and respectful discussion that goes into great detail about the specific characteristics of CO2, how it is measured, where it is found in the atmosphere, and the forcing effects it is capable of, all of these things are important ideas that your video doesn't address.

The problem we have these days is that global data sets are run through a computer model. these models then fudge (I.e make up) the temperature data in the areas (of which there are many) of the globe that do not have stations. these areas with no stations become hotspots. and the whole dataset is then degrees warmer globally than actuality. The models  are not what the satellite data and others are telling us. 

I can't change your mind. But we are in a grand solar minimum. so when your area gets colder and you believe it must just be your area and not globally you can think what you want. 

The global warming almost worked in the 90s and not even but maybe slightly in the 2000s when the Sun was on a cyclical warm period, but since 2013 it's been dropping away into a Grand solar minimum. So the future will put to bed any talk of this global warming. 

The annoying thing, is when the Sun goes into hybination, we see changes in weather patterns. eruptions, which will all now conveniently be placed in the climate change basket so everyone can still believe it's us that's done this without having to admit they were duped because they don't understand.

So CO2 increase follows temperature increase naturally (oversimplification, but lets say that it does). And that extra CO2 is creating more temperature increse which forces CO2 to increase. The loop continues.
So if you increase CO2 artificially first, temperature will still increase. What did you hope to gain with this argument?

"we can't have record long cold winters and hottest years on record. that's not how averages work"
Beside the fact that most of these reports are local and compared to global (which isn't how averages work), it's entirely possible even on global stage. Longer warmer summer? I notice you have some footage from Grouse Mountain above Vancouver, Canada.
No doubt it is because of the wind turbine they installed for the mountain resort.
I can see that thing from my house and I hate it, or rather I hate them for using it as part of a scam.
You see the only time it turns is when tourists are up in it ($50 per person to go up into an observation bubble).
The turbine is almost never turning, even on windy days.
They don't use it to generate electricity, there is no battery storage on site, and I believe they use electricity to spin it for the tourists.
This has bothered me so much that my complaining about it upsets my partner.  I intend to set up equipment to prove I am right.
The electricity it produces is vastly more expensive than our grid energy due to the high maintenance costs of running the turbine.
Not only is our consumer electricity only 7 cents per kWh but as a tourist destination they get tax breaks on electricity from the gov't.
To make matters even worse we mostly have hydroelectric renewable energy here and yet they still install an expensive wind turbine as a scam.
I honestly wish someone would expose them for this deception that they have foisted onto the taxpayer.

text:
IF a lot of people would do as you said, like stop eating meat, it would decrease some of the emissions. BUTT since only a very small percentage is willing to do that the meat industry will stay the same way as it is now. 
Public transport is already a mess in most places and often an impertinence to the customer. Especially during rush hour. (a few exceptions exist). 
There would have to be massive changes in society and infrastructure but seeing how most people (even those with supposedly higher education) don't give two fucks about the energy they are wasting or the waste they are producing or where it will end up after they thoughtlessly through it away I don't see any change coming. 
Overall it's just more convenient (and more importantly) economically more feasible to go for the cheap, dirty factory meat then to go to the butcher. A lot of people simply can't afford quality (and organic) products and thus have to go for this option and this trend is going to worsen. 
The inability (or unwillingness) of companies and governments alike to restrict their emissions and produce in a more sustainable way is another nail in the coffin. Everyone knows about the problems of climate change, waste etc. etc. but very few people with very limited capabilites are actually trying to do sth. The major players just don't move. The companies want to protect their revenues, nations want to protect their economical power and the average citizen doesn't give a fuck where his BigMac came from or under which conditions the cow grew up or how many different cow-carcasses are mangled up in this single patty nor does he care where the packaging end up after he threw it away or how much Co2 was produced in the whole process. 

I really would like to be an optimist about that whole thing, that mankind will live sustainable at some point, but my everyday experience and recent political developments are speaking a clear language: Life as we know it is fucked. 
When I was talking to my parents about those issues they replied: Noone else does it, why should we make it harder for ourselves? Why should we miss out on the fun things of life? Why should we pay triple the price for organic food then we would pay for conventional produce? 
And you know what? they are right imo. Very few people care, nothing will change, so why should i burden myself with it? I had it. You might say that way of thinking is the whole problem. I tried to live "more sustainable" but all those little things that probably most people do just drove me insane. The consumerism, leaving windows half open in winter while the heating is on full power (and then leaving the house for the whole day), the complete disregard how much garbage people are producing and often open disregard for the direct surroundings (just throwing shit out in the open like cigarette butts, packaging etc.) The People won't change. 

Well. This escalated in a pretty salty post... sorry for that ^^ 
Thx if you endured it till the end

text:
Ander, during the Great Ice Storm of 1998, people in southeast Canada just about bought the bullet when the electrical grid fell apart. Only one part of the grid remained. If it had gone out, metropolitan SE Canada would've died.

And when you have far colder oceans, rain become deadly scarce. And you have to know that agriculture is heavily dependent upon rain -- even in the places that use river water for irrigation. Rivers don't flow unless there's rain. And during the last glacial period, so little rain fell that human population couldn't get above about 100,000. Let's see, 7,500,000,000 minus 100,000 = 7,499,900,000 people dead. It might not get that low, if enough infrastructure doesn't crap out. But when people panic, wars start. And during wars, people die.

text: Predicting future scenarios with current technology is, for me, a fundamentally flawed approach which is highly susceptible to being inaccurate. Yes, using the most optimistic values with what we've got now may yield a disappointing result, but this fails to account for the advances in technology that we make during this time. Drawing a disappointing conclusion for the state of affairs 1000 years from now because it 'seems to be impossible' is ignoring how radically different our lives are likely to be in the future; in 50 or 100 years time, let alone 1000. 1000 years ago we may have thought that it wasn't possible that there could exist no God, or that the world was round, or that we would be able to communicate with a huge community of people in all corners of the world in seconds about a moving, talking picture. And yet, here we are. I appreciate the point you're making in the video, but speculating so far ahead is so extremely unlikely to be anything  near a reasonable degree of accuracy, and we should simply focus on what we can learn from the past, what we have now, and the near future. Maybe, in a few hundred years, we won't even live on Earth. Maybe we won't even see the end of the century. In 1000 years? A wholly unpredictable, and non-verifiable time scale.

text:
Genuine question: does not eating meat offset the emissions from air travel, i.e. UK to Germany and Portugal?

Also, as a recovering vegetarian and vegan (one year of each consecutively), make sure you get regular blood tests with a knowledgeable doctor; even with b12 supplementation my health (physical and mental) suffered. My ancestry is Northern European so for many generations my ancestors would have eaten a very protein/fat rich diet, and I strongly suspect that had something to do with it.

Despite many claims to the contrary, meat can, and in many, if not most cases, form the basis for an optimal human diet. In relation to the environmental cost, buy local or hunt (not easy in the UK, i know). 

P.s Before anyone says, I've read Barnard, McDougall, Ornish, China Study and have listened to and respect Rich Roll et al, however, even when I tracked calories and macros/micros (too make sure I ate enough), the veg lifestyle didn't work for me.

text:
Climate change is not due to CO2, your pseudoscientific fear mongering earns you a thumbs down. Climate change is a cyclical process and just because there appears to be a correlation between two factors does not mean that correlation is causation. Yes the globe warmed up in the 20th century, it did the same  during the Medieval warm period, but in either case it had nothing to do with increasing atmospheric CO2 and everything to do with solar cycles. 

To put it into perspective, one out of every 2500 atoms in our atmosphere is CO2 and out of those 1/2500 atoms, humans produced 1-4 out of hundred(1-4/100), so human produced CO2 on a global scale is insignificant and to suggest it is causing unprecedented warming is absurd. Water vapour is responsible for the vast majority of the greenhouse effect.
Following the Medieval Warm Period came a grand solar minimum aka, the dark ages, at the same time there was a massive cooling that took place in Europe that caused 30% loss of life to starvation due to crop loss and then another 30% loss of life to disease. This is the real threat facing humanity and we can see it in world wide local news reports of crop losses everywhere due to freezing temps, flooding and hail.  Yet mainstream national news media do not say a word. Hmmm, I wonder why?

Antarctic ice extent is up so is the Arctic ice volumes, if you were to check the satellite data for yourself that is what you find, but if all you do is listen to mainstream media, you will hear about melting ice and its already too late. 

Global mean temperature is down  by 0.56*C over the past two years when more than 6000+ cold record temperatures were broken. But according to the NASA & NOAA it is warming. Oh yeah, that's because they input warm temperatures where there is no monitor to fulfill their narrative. Recent paper discusses how all the temperature data sets are so out of agreement due to data manipulation. 

Man-made global warming  is a con on a global scale to introduce a tax on every aspect of your life. It is about wealth distribution, taking from the poor to give to the rich. Al Gore the swindler makes $50,000,000.00 a year selling carbon credits and these carbon credits have not done anything to change carbon output. 

What are you doing to ensure your food security as we head into what could be another little ice age much like that which gripped Europe between 1300-1800s?

text:
"We can't just give up"?
You say that like it'll make a difference. lol
Not to rain on your parade but our fate is already sealed. And it won't take 1000 years for it to play out, not even 100 or 50 for that matter. No, the permafrost thaw, driven by positive reinforcing feedback loops will release the hundreds of gigatons of methane it has locked away for millenia. Forget the illusory 30X figure, methane has more than 100X the green house potency of CO2 when first released. This puts global co2 levels of  +6%  not so much in the realms of  possibility as probability. 
The arbitrary Cop21 2% limit of pre industrial levels of co2 is a product of compromise, a number pulled out of the air (or from the arse) not by a scientist or a climatologist but by an economist who thought it was a number that could be agreed to. I wasn't driven by science but its ability to create consensus among the world's nations. 
To conclude, the time to act was 30 years ago, it doesn't matter what we do anymore. Even if we ceased ALL economic activity immediately, we'd still be doomed. We've managed to achieve the perverse situation where the particulate material our society spews into the atmosphere is in fact shielding us from the fullest effects of global warming. Put simply, if we stop polluting we're dead, if we keep polluting we're dead too. 
So, you can rearrange the deck chairs on the Titanic any way you like but it won't make a lick of difference. Instead, cultivate friendships, be good to your loved ones, do the important things now while there's time. Enjoy what time you have left because when it ends you'll wish you had, instead of squandering it fighting an already lost war.

text:
Ander Lillemaa

Thanks for commenting.  First off, I am not a "climate change skeptic", I fully appreciate climate change as a part of the cyclical nature of this planet. If I am skeptical of anything it is the anthropogenic global warming narrative among others coming from the UN. Mixing the two is being disingenuous.

The proof is in the historical record as well as the fact all the predictions based on these models that use CO2 as climate driver have failed miserably. Historically, CO2 has at times been much higher than now though temperatures were not. Also, if one looks at the historical record one can see a cyclical 1000+/- year cycle of extreme warming followed by extreme cooling. Roman warm period, Medieval warm period, modern warm period(20th century). Before we ignore the cyclical patterns there needs to be some proof beyond hyperbolic propaganda that claims a correlation between two events - increased warming of the Modern Warm Period and human produced CO2. Correlation is not causation and these two things have not been proven to have a causal relationship.

Ozone is not CO2 and as such using it as an analogy does not really prove anything. You need to prove that small insignificant amounts of CO2 can produce such temperature changes, something which no-one has done to date. 

"There is a difference between greenhouse effect and changing that effect." ~ What is the difference?  You claim there is a difference but do not define what that difference is. And until you prove that small insignificant amounts of CO2 can do what you claim your point here is meaningless. And what causes an atmosphere to warm? Answer is pressure. Compress a gas and it will warm. Certainly the sun has some input in this as well, but not as much as the standard theory believes. It should also be noted that as sea temp increases the oceans release CO2 and when they cool they absorb CO2. The oceans are the regulator of atmospheric CO2 and contain 50 times more than the atmosphere.

The dark age refers to the latter medieval age post the grand solar minimum and has nought to do with the warm medieval period when populations increased due to an abundance of food. And the reason it was the dark ages was due to the constant cloud cover coupled with high levels of ash and particulate(both of these effects were caused by an increase in cosmic rays something that is occurring now) in the atmosphere and not due to the lack of enlightenment. if you read historical texts from this period, priests, doctors and other educated persons write about how dark it always was, though they did not understand the cause.

I did not manipulate the numbers as you just did. I said gl0bal mean temp(GMT) was down 0.56*C over TWO years not one. And as for the alleged warming, one cannot ascertain whether that is true considering they input numbers for large areas that have no temperature monitors. As well a recent paper discussed that all the various data sets for temperature do not correlate as they once did largely due to data manipulation. What I am observing in local news reports around the world is longer colder winters. England alleges last winter there took 48000 lives.

Arctic and Antarctic Ice is up which shows a reverse of a trend and time will tell if it is.  And of course during a warming period that is a part of a natural cycle ice will melt, but that warming period is over, temperatures paused for a few years and are now on the downswing, ergo 6000+ cold temperature records being broken in the past TWO years. A recent paper published spoke too of how it is likely volcanoes below the ice causing melting in Antarctica and not atmospheric temperature. More importantly, what about the lies by mainstream media who claim things such as this past February when they allege the Arctic is melting away as temperatures rose 45*C in a day and using words like "tropical" to describe the effect. I checked the satellite temperature for the Arctic and yes it rose 45*C, it went from -52*C to -7*C which is hardly warm enough to melt ice nor be thought of as tropical. It is this constant lying to support the AGW narrative that should wake people up to the  fact that if that narrative were true they would not have to lie about it. Not only lyng but bullying as well. There have been a number of climatologists that have stepped forth to say that their jobs were threatened if they did not jump on board the global warming shiip. Dr Judith Curry, once a lead author for the IPCC now speaks out vociferously regarding the weak and questionable science of global warming. Dr Tim Ball is a paleoclimatologist and he too is defending himself from a lawsuit for speaking out against the global warming narrative. 

I am sure you know of the "hockey stick chart" by Dr Phil Jones, who, when asked for the raw data refused on the premise that he had been working for many years on this and did not want someone else to come along and destroy it.  Well, if his results were true he shouldn't fear someone destroying his work. The success of science is built upon reproducibility. If other scientists cannot reproduce your work it comes into question, if they can reproduce your results, you become known for that discovery. The fact that Phil Jones refused to share his data is suggestive that his results were dishonestly achieved and when you add into the fact, climategate, the release of their emails showing they did manipulate data for which he was found by the Uk Information Commissioner to be guilty of crimes but due to a technocality(time restriction) he could not be charged really makes that graph highly suspicious and easily dismissed. 

Yes Gore makes $50,000,000.00/yr selling carbon credits. What do you expect from these elitist capitalists? Do you really think he cares about you or me? I find the gullibility and naivety of the masses towards these self-serving capitalistic wealth hoarders remarkable. The AGW narrative is means by the UN(which has always sought its own source of funding) to convince governments to tax every aspect of your life. And if I am correct about the potential for a mini ice age with longer harsher winters, then people will need to burn more carbon just to keep warm to survive the winters. 

As for your last comment, I am not sure what you are trying to say. Would you please clarify?

If you ignore the scientific claims and just look analytically at how AGW is being played out it lacks truth. Truth does not require hyperbolic propaganda nor does it require lies, bullying or shaming.  

Did you know that many planets within the solar system are also experiencing climate change?  If all the planets are going through climatic changes then it logically suggests that there is one source for these changes ~ the sun.

PEACE

text:
I just want to point out a few things:

As the video points out, the cost of CO2 removal may very well drop, so the premise that global warming is essentially irreversible "on human timescales" is questionable. Air capture will not need to come down in cost by three orders of magnitude, or even two. 1/100 of the estimate in the paper would be really cheap--$30 billion/yr is a really small part of global energy spending, which I think is around $8 trillion/yr.

Nuclear waste decay, and CO2 uptake by geological processes, do not compare well. Nuclear waste has a sharp drop, with a very long, low tail; that's much less true for CO2. IMO it'd be better to not even make the comparison, but find something else.

Also: By the logic in the narration, climate change has always been irreversible, ever since CO2 began to rise. There is no particular point where it became irreversible. The title suggests that climate change has passed some point of no return, beyond which even a cessation of emissions would not stop the process. And there are such claims being made (though I certainly don't agree with them), but if that is the point, it should be made explicitly, and this video never does that.

text:
The technology to replace all electrical generation with solar exists today.  All we have to do is put serveral thousand square miles of mirrors, in orbit at a 10,000 miles, to light up solar arrays 24/7 (just reflection, not concentration - no harm to aircraft or birds).   

This will require significantly more solar panels than we have today (but only 1/4 what would be required to collect enough energy during day time - and mirrors eliminate the need for storage, which we don't have).  The solar arrays have to be in areas with minimal cloud cover.  

There is a significant up front cost (but at least an order of magnitude less the $3T for the CO2 removal machine).  The annual maintenance would be much lower.

To reduce transportation CO2, use solar to charge electric vehicles.  We won't zero out CO2, but reducing it to less than 20% of current gives us a starting point.  

As said in the video, we still need remove 50% the existing CO2.  That can be done by those machines, or even trees, grown, then stacked up (with a note - in case of ice age, set fire).

text:
Oh dear, not climate models again. According to the 2001 IPCC report, "climate is a coupled, non-linear chaotic system and therefore the long term prediction of future climate states is NOT possible". This is why all climate modeling has  been so wildly inaccurate over time. All 107 have been failures to predict future climate conditions. The reason is two-fold. The first thing wrong is that they have not reduced the climate sensitivity on the GCMs, adhering to AGW orthodoxy. We now know that sensitivity might be less than 25% of what was once believed.  

The second problem is even more difficult. They simply haven't enough actual measured data to simulate such a huge dynamic system as our planet. More than 90% of the temperature readings over land are artificial, rather than measured data. Over the oceans (72% of the earth's surface) the amount of real data is infinitesimal. All the rest of the input for the models is interpolated material ... not real data. Science relies on data ... real, factual observations, not estimates of estimates of extrapolations.

In other words Susan Solomon's models are rubbish because they use even less actual data than the Global Circulation Models which operate so poorly at present. Her models run faster because they rely on even less information. These new "models" are nothing short of fear mongering ... but Solomon, et al will never have to account for their failure because it's projected centuries beyond their life span. But if we believe and act on such poorly conceived "science" the cost to us, here and now will be devastating. Carbon capture is not only wildly expensive, it's among the most idiotic "solutions" to a non existent problem there is.

text:
No, Ander Lillemaa, those were107 separate GCMs all with different data and criteria. Each has had hundreds of runs in which the runs are averaged to get a result. They all run hot after a very short time and provide no useful forecasting or back casting to check them. The temperatures on the models are on track for no more than a week or so before they start to diverge from measured data.

This is exactly what was predicted would happen by the science authorities at the IPCC back in 2001.Climate is simply too complex and chaotic to be modeled. We have satellite data but that is not used in general  circulation models. The model described in this video, predicting conditions 1000 years into the future is just madness.

text:
Oh Dear, Ander Lillemaa ... NASA, GISS produces global circulation models as does the CRU at East Anglia University. You can also find comparisons of them at the University of Huntsville Atlanta. text:
Simon Clark ... Great video, but unfortunately you committed one massively glaring and comically ironic logic fail while making your argument that "climate change is already irreversible" (impossible to reverse). According to you, the inspiration for this video was an article describing a newly invented method for removing carbon from the atmosphere and converting it into energy-dense fuel, which you then implied was a futile invention, due to your belief that "climate change is already irreversible." 

Then, you go on to quote a report's 1000-year projections for atmospheric carbon density in an "even if we were to stop emitting carbon today" scenario, BUT you fail to consider or include a hypothetical projection for an "if we started REMOVING carbon from the atmosphere" scenario.  

You then leaned on that projection (which again, does not factor in the possibility of carbon removal at all) to conclude that "climate change is already irreversible," yet reaching that conclusion requires complete disregard for the possibility of REDUCING ATMOSPHERIC CARBON DENSITY, which ironically, is the EXACT PURPOSE OF THE INVENTION THAT INSPIRED THIS VIDEO. 

In other words, you reveal news about a newly invented method of removing carbon from the atmosphere, and then immediately disregard the potential impact of such technology when making your 1000-year projection for carbon levels in the 31st century. In laymen terms, you said: "Here's a really cool invention that removes carbon from the atmosphere, but let me tell you why it won't work by completely ignoring the fact that it exists as a possible solution."

text:
For the record, there is "assist in an agenda" only because "skeptics" think so. It's entirely explainable with "there actually is a problem and other factors haven't played as big of a role in recent climate change"
The fact that the raw data is publicly available means the rounding would be meaningless argument if they actually do that.
We can measure the solar output from the Earth, we don't have to go to Mars to do that. It doesn't explain the warming trend we see, in fact, solar activity is working directly against temperature rise on Earth. A good representation here https://www.skepticalscience.com/graphics.php?g=5
About exaggerating CO2 effect https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=17mKIKGEF5E
The amount of CO2 compared to anything else is meaningless. Beside water vapor (condensable greenhouse gas which means it only acts as an amplifier), CO2 is the biggest (non-condensable) one. Concentrations don't mean the effects are just as small. Ozone is 0.000007% of the atmosphere and it protects us from harmful solar radiation. Nobody claims ozone isn't doing anything.

Something has to cause that change. The cause matters. The there have been worse or better times in the past doesn't matter one bit. Not every change was good for organisms.
And why wouldn't this research, which claimed climate scientists were being dishonest, be dishonest itself? What makes it believable?

How does my analogy say that natural variables are irrelevant? Nothing of the sort. The computer models include the biggest spectrum of variables known. I wouldn't take the word of anyone who doesn't actually show me the model. Where do you take that volcanoes for example aren't factored in?
How much do volcanoes actually produce in a year? How much do humans emit? Please show me the numbers.

Nobody predicts doom. Not in the scientific community anyway. Media can hype up stories but if people don't check the research itself, it's their fault, not the scientist's.

text: I am in no way saying that human pollution is not a bad thing. As a matter of fact I gave up driving big four door trucks and switched to a 4 cylinder VW Jetta that gets 40 mpg, I also chose to buy a Tiny House and have called 500 square feet home for the past 2 years because I do believe limiting your carbon foot print is a good thing. The problem I have with being told as a citizen it is my fault that the earth is warming, is simply the fact I have done my part to make changes, where is the change from government and industry? We have the technology to stop producing gasoline powered vehicles. We have the technology to do away with coal. I am tired of people telling me that I should be taxed based on some model when every government a major corporation in the world is the one to blame. People only consume that which is available for consumption. That being said, it is the same people telling us that its our fault and that the situation is incredibly dire but do nothing about their own practices. text:
I wonder if it would possible in the future and as a possible solution to the power grid's duck curve; 

To use home solar energy to produce fuel for your car. 

In case you don't know, the duck curve is becoming a problem for power companies as more solar gets installed in homes. In power engineering there is typical "power flow" and as you expect the power flows from generators to homes. Now the power flow is reversing, where homes are becoming generators, and this is a problem. This will cause power companies nearly shut down their generators to prevent over generation in mid day when solar output is maximum. 

Lines may become overloaded because distrubution lines were designed to go from a power source to a power consumer; not power source to power source to consumer like the internet would act. Like line voltages are rated based on the amount of customers its designed to feed. Power=IV and the I (current) is what makes the line hot. So power companies up the voltage to deliver the same power (the trade off is that the line is more dangerous and requires more isolation at high voltage). The further away you get from generation the voltage level goes down as there should be less load. But if you're a generator, then you'll increase load on the line which was not designed to take that load.

If your solar panels are producing fuel, then your solar installation is not injecting power into the line. And the power generation will become more efficient as the power company doesnt have to rapidly turn on and off the generators over the day.

text:
Besides the ridiculous cost of trying to do this, the amount of Co2 that we could remove, is negligible.   I read a report recently, that said we could be looking at very soon, having the possibility of removing up to 950 tons of Co2 per year.   Not Gigatons, or billions of tons........just tons.  lol.

I don't think that is really going to do anything to offset the effects of the other approximately 31 gigatons tons, that we're dumping into the atmosphere, per year. 

Now.....I agree with a lot of what you say, but, you're also using some pretty conservative science in your presentation. (Understatement of the year right there.) 

  First off, there is no surviving into the next few centuries.   Let's just scratch that one right off the bat.   Humanity, and all the rest of life on Earth, will be gone by the end of THIS century.  I'm not sure where exactly you're getting your figures that take you out that far, but, no scientist that I know of is even considering the notion of life going beyond the end of this century. 

How do I figure this?   Well, OK, you, yourself, seem to understand that there really isn't any hope of negative emissions having any impact on keeping carbon levels down, or removing it from the atmosphere, right?   I mean, you say that it is unlikely that we're ever going to reach substantial negative emissions.  Those are your exact words.   

So, knowing this, I find it impossible to understand how you can even consider such a foolish notion that we're going to last a few centuries into the future.  

Do you know what the Paris Climate Agreement is?   I'm betting you do......or, at least, you've heard of it.   But.....do you know what it ACTUALLY entails?   Do you know why the Politicians were so excited, and celebrated the signing of it so much?

It is because, they were told an entirely different story about what we need to do, to keep the temperature below 2 C warming, than what the actual scientists said we need to do.   The IPCC scientists said that we need to get GLOBAL Co2 emissions to ZERO, by 2035, to even have a PRAYER of keeping the temp below 2C warmer. 

The Politicians we told an entirely different story.   They were basically told.....nah....we don't really need to do much of anything.   We need to MAYBE drop the emissions a tiny little bit for a few years, and then we can go right on with business as usual, because of........drum roll........negative emission technology!!!    YAY!!!   So, they all signed the very non-binding, non-committal to anything agreement, and held hands and cheered!! 

We're not going to get global Co2 emissions to zero by 2035.  We're not going to have any negative emission technology in place by 2035.  

When you use the correct timeline for what is considered, "pre-industrial", which is 1750, you will find that we're already at 1.6, to 1.8 degrees warmer.   Right now....today.  

1.5 C, is already in the rear-view mirror.   2 C, is literally right around the corner.  We're most likely going to be there by 2020.   There's too much other information to get into in this conversation.  This is already getting long.  2 C in and of itself is a joke. (the notion of staying below it)  That figure was set by an economist, not a climate scientist.   And then, they try to keep us in the dark, by constantly moving the goalposts around.  You hear all kinds of different numbers about where we're at as far as temperature rise etc......it all depends on the start date.   Well....the majority of scientists use 1750.    Somebody suddenly picked 1850 out of a hat at one point, and that is why you'll hear that we're only at about 1 degree warmer, or maybe 1.1. 

The Arctic could go "ice free", this summer.  It probably won't happen, but it could.   But, even if it doesn't happen this year, it is most likely GOING to, by 2020.  

The US Naval Academy predicted it would be ice free in 2016, +/- 3 years.   We've dodged the minus 3 years, it's not looking like we're going to dodge the +3 years.  

When that happens, we'll be lucky if we have 10 years to live from that point.   The global temperature will skyrocket, the jetstream will be essentially non-existent, and you'll have either extreme drought conditions, or extreme flooding conditions, depending on which side of it you're on.   The feedback loops that are already taking place right now, will accelerate exponentially. 

Keep in mind that my 10 year figure is my own.  And I'm being very liberal there.  Some scientists say that we'll have around 5 years to live, after the Arctic goes ice free.   

All I'm really saying is.....you're kinda right, but, you're pretty far behind the 8 ball bud.

author: Jim

text:
A good question! We often talk about CO2 absorbing light, so you might expect that by removing CO2 the sun will become brighter in the sky. However substances don't absorb all light equally, and CO2 specifically absorbs infra-red wavelengths. So this is light which lies outside our visible spectrum, meaning you can't see it with your eyes. If you could see infra-red though, the sun wouldn't look brighter if we removed a bunch of CO2 from the atmosphere, as the sun's light is actually mostly in the visible and ultraviolet parts of the spectrum (so light we can see and stuff which has wavelengths shorter than blue light). Instead, the Earth would look brighter, as the Earth emits light in the infra-red (which, remember, we can't see).
So to answer your question, no the sun wouldn't look brighter in the sky if we removed a load of CO2 because it absorbs wavelengths of light which we can't see, and which the sun doesn't emit. I hope that helped!

text:
Good video, but with one flaw/omission in the economic analysis: a ton of CO2 can be converted into roughly 100 gallons of gasoline, which at the current price of $3/gal would pay for the CO2 capture process quite easily. 

Of course, each of those gallons will also require about 33 kwh of energy for the conversion process, which would add another dollar or two to the price of gas, depending on what sources were used and how they were financed. But there are some new solar PV installations today delivering power at $0.03/kwh, so if the cost of CO2 capture can be done economically at $100/ton, then yes, it is not hard at all to make a business case for doing this today for a profit. 

Of course, even that won't solve the problem, it will only slow down the train wreck. However, in combination with other strategies like permaculture, electrification of transportation, and renewable energy, there may yet be some hope of making significant CO2 reductions by the end of the century.

text:
A few general comments regarding the economic "costs" of implementing CO2 reducing technologies:
1. The idea that anthropogenic climate change is driven by an abstract notion of "money (profit seeking behaviour)", and, that the same abstract notion of money is simultaneously de-incentivising action to curb negative climate change effects, is shocking. Economic considerations in the realm of climate change is akin to religious fundamentalism, whereby actions are taken in accordance to dogma rather than logical thinking.
2. Globally, central banks have created some $US 13Trillion since the 2008 financial crisis until late 2017 in order to pump up stock markets (of which the majority has resulted in gains for corporate leaders, with little to no recovery for the working class). The claim that we simply 'cannot' fund a $US 3Trillion dollar project to reduce CO2 emissions is absurd. The fact that financial institutions can literally create $13Trillion to prop up their corroding system, while actively undermining or showing indifference to real issues that will have devastating effects for all of posterity, is the biggest crime of the century. Shame on anyone that claims economic considerations as legitimate barriers to technological and societal changes necessary to avoid civilization-destroying climate change.

text:
https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases

NOX and Methane are ~15% of GHG combined. Of those, animal agriculture is about 5% and 35% respectively. Growing crops contributes about 75% of the NOX emissions, with all vehicular transport being 5%. Coal mining is about 8% of Methane, and natural gas and petroleum systems account for 31%.

81% of GHG is CO2, and ~75% of that is electricity, transport and industry.

I think it's pretty clear where we should be concentrating. 75% of 81% is a way bigger problem than 75% of 6%. Exchanging fossil fuels for renewables will not only eliminate that 75% of CO2, but also the 39% of Methane from coal and gas/petroleum, and ~10% of the NOX from transport and stationary combustion (assuming the latter is generally power generation).

So in both cases, energy and transport VASTLY outweigh the emissions from the animal agriculture sector. What I didn't realise is how bad the NOX emissions are from agriculture generally, and this is legitimately something that we could do better, but it definitely does not help to stop eating meat.

Having said that, I think we should all eat less meat, and better quality produced with better standards. I pay a premium (20-30% I guess) at a butcher that sources responsibly, they can tell me where all the meat comes from and I can check on those producers. As a bonus, it's FRICKIN' DELICIOUS!! I will never go back to supermarket meat, I just eat a little less than I used to.

Also when you talk about how we can remove carbon from the atmosphere, no one ever mentions protection of land resources and restoration of degraded lands. Plants, especially large trees, sequester carbon in the soil very efficiently and for free. They also provide wildlife habitat, improve water quality, prevent flooding and erosion all for free. The only thing we need to do is protect them and not destroy them.

text:
3 trillion is very much doable if there is a will. It's 3-4% of the world's economy. Without having looked at the actual technology I won't guess whether that cost is likely to increase or decrease with scale, or if it's even possible to implement it at sufficient scale but 3 trillion is affordable. As to what can be done:
1: Don't reproduce, but if you must no more than once.
2: don't eat meat
3: foment peaceful revolution, because meaningful change will never happen while the world is organised solely to maximise return on  investment. 
4: buy less stuff, regardless of whether it's marketed as greener stuff. Fix more existing stuff rather than replace.

Public transport is largely pointless virtue signalling. If public transport were the most efficient system we would not have evolved with private legs. Not even plankton fully rely on public transport. Public transport is a niche solution for the small proportion of desired journeys that are predictable and clustered and can never be more than that. Rather than riding alone on trains in order to feel smug we should plan our economies and our personal lives to minimise journeys.

text: Absolute crap. There is no such thing as irreversible climate change it is an oxymoron. Climate has changed with Milankovitch cycles over 100,000 years precession over 26,000 years .Quaternary glaciation, has seen more or less extensive glaciation on 40,000 and later, 100,000 year cycles. Inter glacial warming on 6000 - 9000 -12000  year cycles. Most of the changes in the global climate over the period of the instrumental record seem to have their origins in the North Atlantic Oceanic change.  The climate response to long-term solar activity variations (from 10s to 1000s years) manifests itself in different climatic parameters, such as temperature, precipitation and atmospheric and oceanic circulation. 68-80% of Co2 last only 20-200 years in atmosphere before being absorbed by the Oceans. The colder the water the more Co2 it holds and vice versa. Co2 has varied from 250-3000 ppm over the Earths history. None of the models to date have been remotely accurate

text:
Equating co2 to nuclear waste is disingenuous. 
Does global warming cause drought? There's a case for the reverse. 

Is there a perfect temperature for the earth? 

Would the world be better at 100ppm or 500ppm co2? Is 500ppm that high compared to previous levels? 

Is it true that many plants benefit from much higher co2 levels? Is the planet becoming greener? 

Is there an ideal atmospheric quantity of co2? 

Is co2 singled out to simplify climate models? 

What are the benefits of global warming? 

Are predictions exaggerated at all, and have they been in the past? 

Why are 2000 year old forests revealed by retreating glacial ice? 

Is the holocene heading into a glacial soon? Are we currently in an ice age? 

There's much more to this story, and many more questions. Not everyone who questions the simple explanation is anti-science.

text:
Caty, I have heard your manufactured nonsense a thousand times before, and it is still false.
To say that temperatures are declining is an outright lie. Yes, May this year was the fourth warmest ever recorded, but the trend is what is important and that is rising and will continue to rise as more CO₂ is released.
As for CO₂ - the system is codependent, higher temps cause more outgassing from the oceans which cause higher temps etc until a new equilibrium is found - this happens over thousands of years, not in one or two generations as is the case now.
There is no question, that it is our CO₂ and other greenhouse gases that are the cause of the temperature rise today in this epoch. Isotopic analysis of the proportion of C12, C13 and decline of C14 confirms that fossil fuels are the cause, and that to have any hope of keeping a planet worth living on it must remain in the ground, and ways must be found to get it back out of the atmosphere and back into the ground so it can't continue to overheat our home and cause all kinds of mayhem from species extinctions, refugees from droughts, sea level rise, storms and food and water shortages.
We face a bleak future if something is not done ASAP, and your unwillingness to acknowledge the problem is part of the problem.

text:
There is not, and never has been a "pause". This only came about because the 1998 El Nino caused a spike so big that it created an optical illusion with subsequent years that could be misinterpreted as a pause. It is purely a function of human cognition and exploited by those determined not to accept the awful truth.
Natural climatic variation is superimposed on GHG forcing and can look like a pause, but the trend is going inexorably up.
author: Andy Lee Robinson

text:
There is no uncertainty whatsoever whether CO₂ causes global warming. It does and it is.
Neither is there any uncertainty whatsoever that this warming is entirely human caused through the burning of fossil fuels, deforestation and agricultural emissions.
There is only some uncertainty on how bad and how expensive the consequences will be.

Whether food or information - you are what you consume, and you are consuming and regurgitating junk.
You really should avoid fossil fuel funded climate denial sites.

AGW is supported by the three Cs:
● Coherence - a theory that coherently explains the multiple observed lines of empirical Evidence™ across multiple aspects of the climate system.
● Consilience - the predicted and projected changes being confirmed across multiple scientific disciplines observing the multiple aspects of the climate system.
● Consensus - agreement amongst scientific researchers from many different academic disciplines that the first two Cs are correct, and that no alternate theory can adequately explain this.

author: Jake K.

text:
You have the shoe on the wrong foot, Jake K. The burden of proof lies with those who believe that CO2 does rise the Earth's temperature more than a tiny fraction of the total amount. So far that has not happened. If you want to know why that is, read Richard Lindzen or Judith Curry. The issue is a thing called climate sensitivity.

No one with any knowledge of the subject is saying that CO2 hasn't some effect in warming the planet, but that effect is very small and occurs most powerfully with the 1st 100 or so parts per million. From there on its ability to trap long wave radiation diminishes logarithmically. This is well known. Also, below around 150 ppm there is too little CO2 to support plant growth. Before CO2 started to rise, at around 270 ppm it was dangerously  low to support abundant plant growth. Now, at ~400 ppm the plants are much happier.
author: RORY FORBES

text:
Andy Lee Robinson Hi Andy, I've had a look through the material you provided and have a couple of things I'd like to point out to you. I'll deal with each link in a separate post.

With regard to the surface radiative forcing of CO2 experiments:
Firstly, the experiment determined that CO2 forcing is only 68% of what was expected from AGW climate models. Using the IPCC formula one calculates that the radiative forcing of CO2, based on the measured increase in CO2 concentration, should have been 0.29W/m2. Instead it was measured as 0.2W/m2. So that's the first problem.

Secondly the experiment found that CO2 forcing accounts for only 10% of radiative forcing. Is it possible that water vapour is responsible for most DLWR and not CO2? At the very least, this experiment confirms what many have accepted long ago, that CO2 is responsible for only a tenth of DLWR radiation.

The experiment does show an increase in DLWR forcing however, so let's explore a possible cause. As you will note, the experiment period started during a la Nina cycle and ended during an el Nino cycle. This accounted for a half a degree increase in tropospheric temperatures during the experiment period. Since warmer air results in more DLWR, could the increase in tropospheric temperature have caused the increase in DLWR?

"But the greenhouse feedback mechanism will eventually result in more water vapour which will cause a further increase in DLWR!" I hear you protest. Well let's go to the temperature records to find out. It might interest you to note that in Alaska during the 2000 to 2010 there was no increase in surface temperatures. And in fact during the 2010 to 2011 period immediately following the experiment, mean temperatures in Alaska fell by around 4 degrees, resulting in the coldest temperature recorded in 94 years. So in fact it looks like this experiment proves that the greenhouse feedback mechanism is a thing of fantasy.
author: Caty Marvelous

text:
Andy Lee Robinson Let's move on to the Continental-scale temperature variability study. I find it quite laughable that they have the hubris to reach the conclusion that they did. It is impossible to draw conclusions from the paucity of data presented. There is absolutely no data for the whole African continent! In fact they even state in their abstract that "At multi-decadal to centennial scales, temperature variability shows distinctly different regional patterns, with more similarity within each hemisphere than between them." So do you not think it unwise to draw conclusions from such a small sample size, considering the amount of variability across the globe?

In addition, I find it suspicious that the period of 1400 years is used. What would one determine if one extended the period to say 2000 years (as the title incorrectly states that it does), what would we observe? Perhaps we would note a warming period similar to what we have recently experienced? I think you know we would.

text:
Dear  Simon Clark while I commend you for your video,  you spent an entire 10 minutes doing exactly what every other informed observer does, discussing the symptom of climate change, while ignoring the cause. Indeed you didn't even mention it by its name.

We humans dump the equivalent of 292,000 volcanoes worth of Co2 into the natural carbon cycle every 12 months. Rising at roughly 3% a year. We do this to service an economic system that demands perpetual growth. That system is called capitalism, the cause behind the symptom of rapid climate change.

Economics:
Capitalism doubles in size over just 30 years requiring a doubling of energy and many materials needed to feed it. It must grow or it collapses due to its own systemic contradictions.  Its need for energy cannot be tapered, modified, changed, it has remained consistent in that growth for 450 years.

Indeed so voracious is this system that we have consumed most of the easily available oil and gas reserves which have forced us to frack. People often say yey or ney to fracking but rarely do they ask why w are fracking to begin with and even more rarely is the occasions when someone bothers to tell them:
https://armyofall.wordpress.com/fracking-coal-you-are-asking-the-wrong-questions/

Renewable energy, insufficient pixey dust:
After 40 years of installing renewable energy we are at around 15% of total global power generation via renewables. This is pitiful.  Its even worse when we consider energy = only 30% of our carbon emissions overall.

We should have had a solar panel on every roof and a wind turbine on every chimney in the UK and beyond by now, produced for the cost of labour and materials only, via regional workers co-operatives. Instead what we have is a handful of for profit capitalist corporations installing renewables at a snails pace to what is required on behalf of another handful of massive energy corporations, in order to ensure the energy corporations maintain their market share forcing us to BUY our energy from them perpetually regardless of the source. 

Only the wealthy can afford to purchase their own energy Independence. Given 65% of the UK earns less than £28K a year I don't expect their homes to be covered any time soon.

The Future:
There was also absolutely no point talking about the year 3000, it takes a roughly -5oC avg drop to take us to an ice age, we are on course for +3.5oC rise minimum by 2100, it does not take a wild imagination to understand the ramifications of that. Certain crops don't do too well under such scenarios. Neither do people under sustained +50oC (roughly a billion along the equatorial line) and neither does the East antarctic ice shelf. 

Sea Level rise:
I am sure you saw this study:
https://www.newscientist.com/article/2171563-alarm-as-ice-loss-from-antarctica-triples-in-the-past-five-years/

In this they state sea level rise of 3 meters by 2100, 

"In particular, a 2016 computer modelling study concluded that Antarctica alone could lose enough ice by 2100 to raise sea level by 2 metres. This means overall sea level could rise by more than 3m by 2100"

That in of itself is a bloody disaster, but  they are missing a factor that will likely add yet another meter by 2100 according to current research being conducted. Greenland Ice sheet algae bloom due to warmer temperatures plus rampant Cryoconite formation, both of which decrease albedo increasing surface melt, none of this is factored into current forecasts according to the scientists conducting the research.

Carbon removal.
The idea of removing carbon from the air and turning it back into fuel is older than dust, papers on the subject go back decades. In 2016 Carbon Engineering Ltd put up 8 million dollars of the company for investors to buy, they only sold 3 million dollars worth. Now they have announced this bit of fantasy I am sure they will sell the remaining 5 million without issue.

Taking the average cost per ton removed it would only cost $6.4 trillion to remove just one years worth of human emissions at todays rates, a bargain, I can just hear world leaders scribbling out the cheques as I type. And I didn't even mention the global infrastructure required for it to be possible. But then neither did the Washington post.

Its called blowing smoke up your arse via media. Elon Musk does it all the time.

The End:
So, to summarise, if you are going to talk about climate change, start making people aware of the system that is driving it, and make damned sure you tell them the truth, that capitalism, an anti democratic and unstable economic system is incompatible with solving rapid climate change, the problem it has created.

And if you don't believe me, here is Professor Kevin Anderson to take you through it in 9 minutes:
https://youtu.be/EprNPlSe6co

And here is our current temperatures outstripping our worst case scenarios, governments have been making policy based on our models, not on reality. Because then they would  be forced to understand capitalism has to go for our species survival, along with many other species we barely care about but certainly need. 3 minutes:
https://youtu.be/-T-_Os7A4_A

Idiotic! The climate has and will always change, and carbon dioxide has almost nothing to do with it. There have been countless sharp increases in temperature and sharp decreases in temperature, and they all have "reversed" each other. What does "reversing" climate even mean? The cold period that "reversed" the Roman Warm Period was "reversed" into the Medieval Warm Period, which was "reversed" into the Little Ice Age, which was "reversed" in our modern warm period, which is now beginning to "reverse" into cooling as another grand solar minimum is underway. This goes on continually. Eventually, the Holocene will give way to another Ice Age glaciation sooner than you think. 

Instead of wasting resources on this stupid carbon dioxide nonsense, we should be preparing to maintain civilization when the climate again turns cold. Warm climate is beneficial to human civilization. Stop the fear mongering.

text:
Nicely done.   Jim Hansen has analysed the recent paper you quote, on CO2 drawdown, and he concludes that the cost is grossly under-calculated, effectively meaning that the costs are much too prohibitive for national economies to consider budgeting for or implementing.  

Our annual human output of  of CO2 is about 30 gigatons which is over and above the  natural cycle of 750 gigatons circulating each year.  

The oceans absorb about 40% of this additional CO2 thus increasing ocean acidification in the process. The other 60% remains in the atmosphere, continually building up each year and remaining in the atmosphere for millennia​.  The industrial age has raised the level of atmospheric CO2 from 280 ppm to 410 ppm in 150 odd years.   This would normally take 5000-20000 years given evidence of the normal historical natural cycles. 

The scale of CO2 removal needed is thus gigantic and is beyond human ingenuity as yet.  Furthermore if there is, for some reason, a reduction in the ability of the oceans to absorb CO2 then atmospheric levels will increase more rapidly.   The already deteriorating biosphere/biodiversity that sustains the human habitat cannot adapt to such rapid change.   

Therefore it's just a matter of time before the planet becomes devoid of most lifeforms, like a desert - without even factoring in sea level rise and more extreme weather events generating a completely unstable climate.
