text:
Alrighty  then.
Here goes.
I will explain how it is that Global Warming is irreversible and just how much time we really have,
Global Warming is as we know cause by excess greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. The Earth is always cooling or warming at any given time. That is natural.
Normally it takes thousands of years for global average temperatures to change just 1 degree Celsius.
Through the burning of fossil fuels we have already raised global average temperatures 1.9 C from the 1750-1800 average. 0.9 C of that has happened in the past 5 years. It's not that the Earth is warming that is so worrisome. It's the SPEED in which it is warming that is alarming. Between February 2015 and February 2016, global average temperature grew 0.56 C degrees. That's half a degree in just 1 year.
There are some important facts to know here. We need to know just what sort of warming the Earth is getting from current greenhouse gases. Thankfully scientists already know this. The Earth if it had no greenhouse gases would be too cold to support life. The water at the equator would be frozen solid and the atmosphere would be too cold to even have weather.
The earth is warmed by greenhouse gases by 31.6 degrees Celsius and this warming allows life to exist.
However, having too much of a good thing can be a bad thing.
Look up "W5: What Happens When The Permafrost Thaws?" In the video report that was released November 11th 2017, the scientist states that there is roughly twice the amount of greenhouse gases in the permafrost as there currently is in our atmosphere.
You already know how much warming our current greenhouse gas levels do. Try to imagine what it would be like if it was tripled. Not a pretty sight is it?
Now look up "20% of the permafrost will thaw by 2040". Look for the VOX report. It has a link to the actual scientific papers that was published. 
You read it right. 20% will thaw by 2040 just 22 years away. A 20% thaw will raise global average temperatures by roughly 13 degrees Celsius. Nobody will survive that. During the PETM (Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum) which happened 55.5 million years ago, the Earth warmed up 8 degrees more than current temperatures. The equatorial regions were unlivable and polar regions were tropical zones. That event wiped out 75% of all life and took hundreds of thousands years to unfold. 
We will see a minimum of 13 degrees C within the next 22 years.
The only reason 25% of life survived the PETM was because it had time to adapt, migrate and evolve. That won't happen within 22 years.

Also take out water vapor because it's a condensable greenhouse gas which relies entirely on temperature (it acts as an amplifier, you must increase temperature first) and you have that CO2, 0,04% of the atmosphere, as the biggest non-condensable greenhouse gas.
The sun has been cooling on average for 4 decades so there must be something else that increases the temperature on Earth. (wonder where all you get this "grand solar minimum" thing, hint hint)
The CO2 historically followed temperature because it acted as an amplifier due to positive feedback, like water vapor. Something increased temperature first then CO2 acted as an amplifier for that warming period. Unlike water vapor, you can directly add CO2 into the atmosphere without rising the temperature first and that is happening now, making the entire "it follows temperature" argument pointless.
The carbon is not accumulative like a pile of somesort, it's a carbon cycle and what nature emits, nature absorbs. We emit, but we don't absorb. That's the reason even the smallest percentages matter.

text: Your link isn't working for me, but if you're making the point about the absorbing power of other GHGs being much stronger then you're absolutely correct. However these other gases (CH4, NOx) don't persist in the atmosphere anywhere as long as CO2 - see e.g. http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/ch2s2-10-2.html#table-2-14. If that was the table you were referring to then where you may be getting mixed up is comparing GHGs and CFCs, which are important to stratospheric chemistry but not as important to net global radiative properties. The other thing to remember is that the sheer quantities of substances are very different - there's much more CO2 in the atmosphere than CFCs or other, more potent and shorter-lived, GHGs.

text:
You say "lets be super optimistic" and assume CO2 emissions remain constant. Until the year 3000? That's an incredibly pessimistic assumption. Either solar or nuclear power (with nuclear taken to include fusion) is likely to displace fossil fuels within the next century or so. This agrees with the sources used in you video, which show CO2 emissions peaking this century, and the whole idea of CO2 removal presupposes an abundant supply of clean energy. So we are not talking about constantly having to offset billions of tonnes of emissions every year; we are talking about having around 900 years (if the year 3000 is you deadline) to clean up a few centuries worth of carbon, the bulk of which probably comes just from the period of about 1950 to 2050. 
Also the world economy is likely to be considerably larger in the 22nd through 30th centuries as productivity rises and countries that were left behind by the industrial revolution rapidly catch back up with the West; if we assume a population of 10 billion people with the same per capita income as the present day US, that gives a gross world product of nearly $600 trillion per year, about 6 times the current amount.
And as you mention, the cost of removing carbon could well be reduced further in the future.
In your video you calculate a cost equivalent to about 3% of GWP, and while it may be difficult and arguably not worth it, it's not, in fact, "simply not possible" to give up 3% of your income. With the above points taken into account, the cost is more likely to be well under 1%.

text: Because it's not that simple - there are both positive and negative feedback loops. For example more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more photosynthesis from plants -> less CO2. But then at the same time more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more water vapour absorbing thermal wavelengths of radiation -> warmer planet. There are feedback loops all over the place, hence the need for complicated models!
author: Simon Clark

text:
Holy shit a reply from the man himself!!
If there are both positive and negative feedback loops - that only means they would either cancel each other out, or they average out into one positive feedback loop, or a negative one. 
If it's positive or negative, the Earth would've been screwed from the get go regardless of humans.
Therefore, when there's no human input, the Earth's CO2 levels must be self correcting , i.e. when CO2 levels are too high, the negative feedback loops have more punch, and when CO2 is too low, the positive feedback loops win over. Only this scenario would create an equilibrium allowing CO2 levels to remain stable over time, any other scenario would have CO2 levels spiral exponentially to either 0 or infinity due to effects of chaos.

And if that's the case, then while an additional human input of CO2 will produce a temporary rise in temperature, eventually we will again find a natural equilibrium, because although we've increased the CO2 levels, because we've done that, the net negative feedback loops will become more pronounced, while the net positive feedback loops will diminish, and (as long as human CO2 input is constant), they'll be a point where the loops once again reach equilibrium.

I can make an analogy with air resistance vs gravity. As you know, falling objects have air resistance, and the faster the velocity, the more air resistance. Therefore this is an example of a negative feedback loop, because if a falling object momentarily goes faster than the terminal velocity where air resistance and gravity are in equilibrium, then the object slows back down to terminal velocity. Likewise, if the object momentarily goes slower than the terminal velocity, gravity win over the air resistance, creating a positive feedback loop, and making the object speed back to terminal velocity. Any other universe where the object didn't have a positive feedback loop when going to slow AND a negative feedback loop when going to fast, would inevitably result in the object either coming to a complete stop or speeding up indefinitely. 

Now in this analogy, human input of CO2 is equivalent to reducing the object's surface area. By doing so, you'll have decreased the force of air resistance, making the object fall faster/have a higher terminal velocity. But the same positive/negative feedback loops apply, so although the object will temporarily fall faster, it will inevitably reach a new terminal velocity again, where the feedback loops cancel out and it's all ok.

Is this correct?

text:
Joel Sarchet ... human emissions of CO2 pale in comparison to natural CO2. The human contribution is approximately 3% of the total ... and CO2 contributes to less than 5% of the total greenhouse effect.

We are already IN and ice age, but are enjoying a temporary respite of the extreme cold because of what's known as an inter-glacial warm period. Ours is called the Holocene Inter-glacial and it has already cooled several degrees since the Holocene Optimum. The warming we are currently experiencing is likely a natural (and recurring) consequence of a large number of factors. 

The little Ice Age was the coolest period in around 8000 years. We have warmed since it ended approx. 200 years ago. This warming is entirely consistent with natural variation. It's cooling we need to fear, not warming. The present inter-glacial is already longer than the average for such events. CO2 isn't going to alter the inevitable cooling in the least.
author: RORY FORBES

text:
Volcanoes emit about 1% that of what humans do. The other three factors are the ocean, soil and fauna. The ocean is currently a net sink of CO2, so it cannot contribute to the rise of atmospheric CO2. The soil contains vast amounts of carbon, but is stored in there for as long as climate is stable and tends to be released only in case of warming (which is a positive feedback on warming). For the plants, well maybe you can explain to me what exactly has changed in the last 100 years that supposedly started them releasing CO2 instead of absorbing it? Maybe deforestation and soil eroding agriculture?
In the last 800,000 years, the longest period we can measure with ice cores, the CO2 content of the atmosphere was never even close to that of today. 300ppm would already be considered unusual in this period.

Everything points very clearly to the fact that CO2 rise is anthropogenic.

author: RORY FORBES

text:
The radiative transfer models such as MODTRAN by the US Airforce show that the no-feedback warming caused by a doubling of CO2 (for example from pre-industrial 280 ppm to 560 ppm) causes about 1°C of warming. If you assume that the relative instead of the absolute humidity of the air stays constant during the increase of temperature, that increases further. All the other feedbacks due to albedo changes from for example retreating ice, changes in cloud coverage etc. are not at play in that estimation, so it is most likely a lower limit for an estimate of the climate sensitivity of CO2.

When determining the total energy budget of incoming, reflected and outgoing radiation, CO2 contributes about roughly 25% to total greenhouse warming: http://www.geo.utexas.edu/courses/387H/PAPERS/kiehl.pdf
author: Alex

text:
Here is a temperature curve posted verbatim from a climate sceptics blog (and one which is on the higher end of quality, actually has some interesting posts): https://wattsupwiththat.com/2016/09/29/earths-obliquity-and-temperature-over-the-last-20000-years/
Nowhere can you see "several degrees" of cooling, the graph ends at a little over 0.5°C below the peak. But while creating the graph, they seem to have made a mistake, since the original paper from which the data is from only goes back to 1950, which is then defined as B.P., unlike the shown 2000CE in the graph. So there is another 68 years of warming missing. The graph also shows pretty clearly the correlation of temperature with the solar insolation in the northern hemisphere. This is also why the current warming is so remarkable, since it should be getting cooler (in the long run at least) and why the causes of warming clearly must be different.

author: Alex

text:
We are currently in an ice age called the Quaternary glaciation. Ice ages last millions of years, while interglacial periods within them only last around 15,000. The glacial periods (what you incorrectly know as ice ages) last around 100,000. We are currently at the end of the Holocene interglacial and within that, we are currently at the end of a solar maximum called the Modern Maximum which started around the industrial revolution.

Glacial periods are caused by increased cloud cover which blocks out the sun. Increased cloud cover is ultimately caused by lower solar activity: solar minimums. Ever heard of the little ice age of 1600? The next one is due about 30 years from now and it will be much colder. And that's only a solar minimum, the full impact of the glacial period will cause far more extinction than we as humans could ever hope to accomplish. 

This is what an ice age looks like (an interglacial period of an ice age anyway). During normal times, Earth averages about 2,000 ppm of co2 without any problems, in fact, life seems to thrive in these conditions. If co2 were to drop below 150 ppm, all life on Earth would go extinct as photosynthetic organisms die off. During the Precambrian supereon, co2 was as high as 9,000 ppm and no runaway greenhouse effect, and no scorching Earth. We are much closer to being low on co2 than we are to having an excess of it. Humans are, if anything, helping life on Earth by returning the co2 that was trapped in the fossilized corpses of marine microorganisms, what we call "fossil fuel."
author: Tristun Alekzander

text:
The cloud theory was brought up and tested at CERN, in the CLOUD experiment using a particle accelerator and a Gas Chamber to simulate different parts of the atmosphere. You can find a paper on the results here: http://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2016/10/26/science.aaf2649
I'll quote the relevant part here: "We tested the effect of changes in the GCR ionization rate that occur between solar maximum and minimum (supplementary materials, section 13; Ref. (17)). Over the solar cycle, the global mean change in CCN at cloud base altitude (915 hPa, usually around 850 m above the surface) is only 0.1% (Fig. 4B) with local changes of no more than 1%. This is expected from the experimentally derived sub-linear dependence of the inorganic nucleation rate on ionization rate (supplementary materials, section 8) and consistent with previous assessments (49, 50)."
GCR = galactic cosmic rays, CCN = cloud condensation nuclei.

Or in other words, neglible.
author: Alex

text:
There is no such thing as a normal CO2 level. Over the last 500 million years, CO2 in the atmosphere has, on average, been in decline. But if you look a bit closer, the effects and differences at different times were dramatic.
If you take the earliest times, the CO2 at that time was indeed very high. But the sun played a huge role in why it was not as hot: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_luminosity
During that time, solar luminosity was several percent lower than today. That may not sound a lot, but the usual solar cycles we see today are on the order of one-tenth of a percent change in luminosity and that already shows a well observable effect.

Later on during the Eocene was one of the hottest periods of the last 500 million years. It peaked during the PETM, with a synchronous peak in CO2. After that, CO2 and Temperature both declined, until the ice caps started forming at the end of the Eocene. Meanwhile, the sun is still increasing in intensity, which already hints that it can not be the cause of the long term cooling, but that instead greenhouse gases being the cause is much more likely.
author: Alex

text:
And the last part of CO2 being a boon for plant life: Yes, in controlled environments like a glasshouse laboratory increasing CO2 can lead to increased plant growth. In the outside world however water and temperature variability have a much greater effect than CO2 levels. And drastically changing temperatures is never good, both warmer and colder, as plants and animals need time to adapt and migrate. The current levels of warming (the rate of change) are simply too high for adaption. That is the problem we are facing.
It might be true that somewhat higher temperatures are not that terrible in the very very long run (hundreds of thousands to millions of years), if the change happened slowly enough. It will have a negative effect on the lower latitudes, but a possible positive effect on the higher latitudes in terms of bioproductivity. Given that the amount of landmass in the lower latitudes is much greater, that is not a great trade. But we are talking about warming measured in decades to centuries. This will inevitably cause mass extinction of species. The PETM I mentioned in my other post was an extinction event.
It will also be costly to humans, as we will have to adapt to a continuously changing climate, where people and infrastructure will need to migrate on a massive scale.
author: Alex

text:
Overall the argument structure for you deniers is always the same.
1. "Global warming is fake"
2. "Global warming is/was real, but climate always changes. It is caused by the sun/orbit, not by CO2. It will cool down again."
3. "Global warming is caused by CO2, but the CO2 increase is not caused by humans but instead by volcanoes/the ocean/the biosphere. CO2 levels are have always fluctuated and the ice core data is fake. The influence of humans is insignificant."
4. "Global warming is real and humans cause it but it is actually a good thing. The warmer temperatures and higher temperature are great for plants!"
What we will hear in the next decade:
5. "Global warming is real and bad, but it's too late anyway and we can't do anything anymore. We need to use fossil fuels as energy to combat the effects of climate change. Besides, everything is great here in [insert northern latitude country]."

It would be more believable if you had a core of arguments that don't contradict themselves and is hard to refute. In case you didn't notice, the fact that temperatures in the past have varied a lot and the statement that CO2 has a low climate sensitivity are direct contradictions. No other climate variable varied without predictable patterns as much as CO2.

author: Alex

text:
Alex
I appreciate your thoroughness. To whatever extent GCR's influence temperature, in combination with lower solar activity and a weaker magnetosphere, they are the only explanation to explain past warming and cooling periods (skip to the end if you are lazy or don't have much time for this debate, I did write quite a bit).

https://stevengoddard.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/screenhunter_363-mar-06-19-17.jpg?w=640&h=268 Here is solar activity correlating with the Maunder Minimum or the "little ice age" as well as our current warming period called the Modern Maximum. I'm sure you already know that temperature affects co2 just as much or more than co2 affects temperature.

Also, that study doesn't seem to be looking at the correlation between increased cloud cover and temperature, but how much GCRs produce clouds in our magnetospheres current state, which is a good argument but doesn't directly refute anything. But, I'm willing to concede that it may not be the primary cause of climate change, but if it's not, then what is? Co2 follows solar activity and temperature (except when humans release it) so we know that it is also not the primary cause.

I didn't say there were "normal co2 levels." I said during "normal times" as in non-ice age times, co2 was upwards of 2,000 ppm. I appreciate your knowledge of the overall decline in co2 over the last 500 million years. If Co2 levels drop below 150 ppm, virtually all life on Earth will go extinct and Earth will probably go back into another snowball earth state.

The Sun's luminosity has only increased by about 3% over the last 500 million years, though 3% is a lot with anything in the context of climate, its fluctuating minima and maxima have a much larger impact on climate variation. Despite the fact that solar luminosity is higher than it has ever been, Earth is currently near all-time low temperatures, probably because of the low co2 (and the low co2 could actually be caused by increased solar activity as co2 will evaporate into space at higher temperatures). You could just as easily argue that solar activity has had an even greater contribution to our current warming trend than we thought due to its increased luminosity. We know that 150 mya, co2 was upwards of 2,000 ppm while solar luminosity was less than 1% lower than today. It is extremely unlikely that 400, or even 1,000 ppm will cause runaway greenhouse effect. In addition, Earth is also gradually increasing in its distance from the sun so the 3% could have little to no effect on temperature. 

Of course, rapid changes in climate will cause extinction. We still have many animals alive today that made their adaptations and escaped extinction from the last glacial period. They will die because they have evolved to very cold temperatures, and have adapted to places where no other organisms can live because it is too cold. During "normal times," places like Canada and Siberia revert to rainforest, so the loss of specialized animals is totally overcompensated for in the massive increase of biomass that warm temperatures bring.

 My basic argument is this: AGW is real, but it is exaggerated for political purposes. CO2 does indeed affect temperature, but considering we are right around the corner from a solar minimum (which should be even colder than the Maunder minimum), and after that an approaching glacial period, we may delaying an even more devastating climatic change. The current warming trend is a combination of anthropogenic CO2 and solar activity (as well as many other factors). The 100 or so ppm of co2 we have added turned a normal solar maximum temperature rise, into one just a tiny bit faster and warmer than normal. Its rate is unprecedented in only the last 23,000 years, and its magnitude is unprecedented in only the last 2,000. This 13,000-year long interglacial will soon give way to a 100,000-year long glacial period. Warm temperatures are the last thing you should be worried about. 

It would be less time-consuming for us to focus on the argument of, "how does 400 ppm and a negligible increase of solar luminosity cause runaway greenhouse effect that overrides recurring glacial periods?"

author: Oskar Zdrojewski

text:
@Joel

I've noticed you've drawn some very bad answers.     Volcanic lava and ash is of significant mass but the actual long term gas added by volcanoes is considerably less than the man made CO2 added to the air.    Alex says 1%.   That's probably about right.

Rory Forbes is a fox news educated nitwit.   Yes, human emissions pale in comparison to nature, but nature is part of the Carbon cycle, it's very balanced.    Nature adds and removes about a trillion tons of CO2 from the atmosphere every year - in balance.    Human fossil fuel use adds about 30 billion tons every year and that's not in balance.   About half, or a little less than half goes into the ocean as a result of the increased concentration in the air, but as the oceans warm, that may stop.    We're adding CO2 to a well balanced carbon cycle, pushing it out of balance.   That's why CO2 is increasing, from 280 PPM 200 years ago to nearly 410 PPM today.    Volcanoes are largely irrelevant and they actually have a cooling effect.    We'd need a once in a million year volcano for this conversation to actually be relevant and if that happens, we'll have other problems to deal with. 

As for what the beginning of an ice age looks like, the beginning of anything can be hard to spot, but what we know of Milankovich cycles, ice ages begin when northern hemisphere/arctic summers get colder.   Colder summers melt the snow more slowly and that allows the snow cover to build up.    As the snow builds, the ground grows lighter in color which reflects more sunlight which helps the Earth get a little cooler.   Over time and if enough ice builds, the oceans start to cool as well from the colder air and as the oceans cool, CO2 is absorbed and the Earth cools even more and if this continues, you have an ice age - until the Earth's orbit returns and Northern Hemisphere summers start to warm up and the entire process reverses.

Glacial periods are caused by increased cloud cover which blocks out the sun   That's not true.

Increased cloud cover is ultimately caused by lower solar activity:  Solar minimums   That's not true.

If CO2 were to drop below 150 PPM all life on Earth would go extinct - yes, I'm familiar with that one. Besides, if we're around, we know what to do if CO2 drops to dangerously low levels - we'd drive cars.   Problem solved.    If only every problem was as easy to solve as the 150 PPM CO2 problem - go for a drive.    Problem fixed.

During the precambrian supereon, CO2 was as high as 9000 ppm and no runaway greenhouse effect - sure, but oceans were 100 feet higher (see above) and during the precambrian, the sun was colder.   It's called the faint young sun paradox, though it's not really a paradox because it's logical, but more CO2 but colder sun = they balance each other out to an extent.   Also the younger earth, probably more volcanic, more SO2 - SO2 reflects sunlight, it's a global coolant.    That's the problem with the "but hundreds of millions of years ago CO2 was higher" - uh, yes, and the sun was smaller and didn't shine as brightly.    Our sun grows hotter over time.   About 1% every 100 million years.  

You're a good parrot but a shitty scientist, Tristan.    You don't know all the facts.

text:
@Diamonds

Good question.

An average tree absorbs about 50 pounds of CO2 per year.   (ballpark, different trees absorb different amounts, I use 50 cause it's a nice round number.  This article says 48.  http://www.arborenvironmentalalliance.com/carbon-tree-facts.asp

So, 40 trees absorb 1 ton.   40 billion trees absorb about 1 billion tons, so 10 billion trees, about 1/4 of that.

Human output of CO2 is over 30 billion tons per year, and a faction of that gets absorbed in the ocean, about 10 or 15.    So what we need to off-set just to break even, never mind bringing 410 PPM down a bit, would be about  15 x 40 billion trees or 600 billion trees.    If every nation with as much area as Pakistan planted 10 billion trees, it would go a long way.   It probably wouldn't solve the problem entirely but it would help.

Articles say Pakistan has already planted 1 billion trees, and the new prime minister wants to plant 10 billion (not sure if that includes the 1 already planted or not).   The trees have to be cared for.  They don't do much good if they're planted but they die 2 years later.   I don't know how ambitious 10 billion trees is.    It would go a long way to offset Pakistan's footprint.   We need many more trees than that to offset the world's footprint.

text:
Wow am I tired of hearing the whole "CO2 was way higher hundreds of millions of years ago, and life was still around" as a defense of rapidly increasing CO2 levels today. I'm far more concerned with the survival of the human species than I am life as a whole. Humans weren't around hundreds of millions of years ago. Humans didn't evolve in that climate. None of the plant or animal species humanity relies on evolved in that climate. I have absolutely no reason to think we or any of those species would survive if the climate rapidly turned into what it was like hundreds of millions of years ago.

So yeah, this climate change probably won't kill off all life on Earth, but it could pretty easily kill off all the life I really care about. Isn't that kind of the more important detail?
author: Erik Dumas

text:
I hope the deniers answer your points Erik.    I'd love to hear what they say.

That said, to be fair, it's probably not going to kill all humans.   High enough sea level rise would be an apocalyptic level change, but it (probably) wouldn't kill everyone.     It's very hard to get a good measurement of how bad and how fast.   The smart play is (somewhat obviously), to address negative outcomes, not deny them.      I could say more, but I'll keep this one short.

Still, I hope to hear from some of those deniers on your points.

text:
SushiFairy no one has a direct monopoly on the solar industry. There are major differences between the tiny solar cell on a cheap calculator and those suitable for powering a home. This, the electronics needed to convert between the DC produced by the panels to AC for home use, requiring licensed installers, and the number of good quality panels required increases the price of a solar conversion. When compared to buying cheap poor quality PV cells and chucking them in calculators that are manufactured in the thousands you can see the why there is a price disparity. 

As to the age of the technology, the manufacturing processes to make economical, reasonably environmentally friendly, and powerful enough solar cells is rather new and is still not that efficient.

text: @SushiFairy: Cost don't matter. Pretending solar panels are somehow the magical solution to pollution is one of the biggest lies ever told. The effectiveness of solar panels, or rather the lack thereof is a huge problem. Manufacturing more efficient panels is basically impossible, because of the whole way the reception of energy works. You can't shrink it all down indefinitely expecting a higher efficiency. And then I haven't even spoken about how you actually need to track the sun for optimal angles, which in turn costs energy. Don't get me wrong, yes, you will get energy from solar power panels. But it is absolutely not the magical solution. If a solar power panel breaks, it is also hardly biodegradable lol, so you're still stuck with waste there anyway. It's a total non-solution. A similar story goes for the whole electric cars hype, which for the record still relies upon energy production elsewhere, including the same wasteful and polluting power plants. In reality it replaces one problem for another.
author: PHeMoX

text:
PHeMoX, wrong.

The energy cost of manufacture of solar panels is offset within the year. I have seen a deal (admittedly subsidised through STCs) for 5-6kW of solar and an LG Chem 6.4kWh battery under $10k installed. Would not take very long to pay that off at all, about half the warranty period maybe where I live.

There are some efficiencies coming through the technology chain, not sure where it's at but there is one effort that looks promising which effectively has multiple cells for different wavelengths of light.

As for EV's, even when built using coal, and powered with the average grid, and the cost of making the battery, they still produce less pollutants over just a few years (3-4 depending where you live, lower if you have solar). And they're only getting greener as the grid gets greener.

The great thing is though that they can be produced and run with no emissions. ICE vehicles simply cannot.

author: Geary Heine

text:
SushiFairy in some places you can buy a 100 watt solar panel for $100 dollars. That is way cheaper than it used to be. You should  know that every home is not the same. We have 95 watts in solar panels and yet we have eight 12 volt 100 amp hour batteries. After replacing our bulbs with LED bulbs, changing to gas cooking and low amp refrigerators, switching from four 1,500 watt desktop computers to 120 watt laptops, canning so we do not need large refrigerators and freezer, using out cell phones, tablets and netbooks, instead of our laptops, getting a 40 inch 120 watt TV and a 24 inch 12 volt DC TV, a couple portable DVD players that run on 12 volts DC, using the Air Conditioner only when we need it and a few other things. Our Utilities bill went from $600 a month to about $120 a month. That $480 a month is almost $5,000 a year.

We live in Florida so we get a lot of sun. We also have an electric water heater and a gas water heater. It cost to do all these things, but we save almost $500 a month. That is over $5,000 a year. Yes, we have 95 watts in solar panels. They are 15 watt panels and we have six of them. When the last hurricane hit Florida, the city power was out for weeks. We still had lights, internet, fans, charging for our tables, cell phones and net books. We gave up out four 1,500 watt desktop gaming computers for gaming laptops that use 120 watts each. We just charge them as we need to. Start small and upgrade over time. It took us almost a year to have our system with the eight batteries. More batteries are important, because the solar panes do not run anything. The batteries run everything, but the solar panels only charge the batteries. Less panels just means longer charging times.
author: Fla-bushcraft Prepper

text: Fla-bushcraft Prepper, holy crap your usage must be miniscule to be able to run off 95w of solar, or do you import from the grid overnight on cheap rates?
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text:
Matthew Jenkinson
 Batteries run everything in a Solar System, the solar panels only recharge the batteries, you clearly do not know how Solar Systems work. I have eight 100 amp hour batteries. The batteries run our lights and charge our cell phones, tablets and laptops. The solar panels run nothing. They only recharge the batteries. Anyone who has studied solar systems and installs them, knows this. I have a 3,500 watt inverter. It will surge to 5,000 watts. This means i need minimum 5 deep cycle batteries, or I may fry my inverter. So, I have 8 batteries. The 8 batteries allow up to 8,000 watts of draw.  If I had 8 X 100 Watt Solar Panels (*,000 Watts or 8KW) and 2 batteries, I would fry my system. It would be constantly going down and my two batteries would not even last a couple months. The solar panels are Solar Chargers. The Charge Controller limits how much the panels will charge, so I do not over charge my batteries.

I have a 12 volt DC system. The solar panels put out 18 volts sometimes. The charge controller steps it down to a 13.2-14.5 volt current. The charge controller take the solar panels energy and uses it to charge the batteries, or to keep them charged. We do not run the fans 24 hours a day. We do not run the laptops, tablets or net books 24 hours a day. Only our cell phones are on all day. Well sometimes we charge them in the car going down the road, or charge them at work, so even they are not on the solar bank all the time.

The batteries only need to be recharged the amount that is taken. It I run the 1,200 watt microwave for 2 minutes to heat a hot dog and chili, the solar will replace that long before the sun goes down. It is about knowing how to calculate your uses and having more than enough batteries to do it. Then the proper solar array to replace what you use on average. We also have a 1,600/2,000 watt generator and a 3,500/5,000 watt generator. We rarely use them.

Yes, I have a battery charge running of my house power, but it is a variable charger that does 1.5 amps to keep the bank topped off, or up to 8 amps to ramp up the charging, but when it is topped out at 8 amps, it is only drawing about 200 watts. I only use it when I need to, which may be once a month for a day or so. Keep in mind that most of the time it is not even running at 8 amps. It supplements the solar panels if needed. The batteries run things. The Solar charges the batteries.

My battery cables, the copper wire is about as thick as an adult mans thumb. The solar panels wires are tiny as a #2 pencil lead. Not a #2 pencil, but the lead inside the pencil. How is that going to run a microwave oven, toaster, waffle iron, hair dryer, 40 inch TV or most of the other things inside a home? Size the Battery Bank first, then the solar panels next and then the appropriate charge controller. We use cables one size heavier than needed, so we never stress the system. It is always best to use thicker wires than needed. Have multiple inverters. Do not use a 3,500 watt inverter to run a 24 inch TV. Use a 450 watt or 700 watt inverter. 
Our inverters
3,500 watt
2,000 watt
750 watt
450 watt
250 watt
125 watt

Some things that are AC power, people run on DC power and do not even use an inverter. The reason is  that if it uses 120 volts AC and it has no computer type technology inside it, like a basic toaster, toaster oven, hair dryer, drill, skill saw and such. It only wants the 120 volts. People will series their batteries and 10 batteries that are 12 volt in series will give 120 volts. You can see people run these things on DC, from their battery bank. Usually only in emergency situations, but it can be done.

Kid; "Now I know."  

G.I. Joe: "And knowing is half the battle."
author: Fla-bushcraft Prepper

text:
Fla-bushcraft Prepper I understand how solar systems work, generally, but a 100w solar panel will only generate 1kWh in a day at best (100w X 10hrs of sun).

Now I'm sure it can be done, but that would be pretty impressive to run a standard house on. We're fairly efficient, and we use around 15kWh a day for a 3 person household in the burbs.
author: Matthew Jenkinson

text: Matthew, I did not say I was running a standard house. I said our lights are LED. I said we use gas, solar and main power. You do know that if you are running 6 volt LED lights, 3 volt LED and 5 volt LED lights on a 12 volt system, you can run them for days, before the battery bank even drops 1/10th of 1%. Our light bill was $600 and then we made changes. I said we gave up our 1,500 watt desktop computers. I said we added a gas water heater, though we mainly use the electric heater. It is a small ten gallon 120 volt heater. We only turn it on at 2 am and it goes back off at 4 am. Our AC unit is a 220 volt 35,000 btu AC. We only run it during sleep hours and just started using it two weeks ago. We may use it to about September 10th. The times we do not use it, we use 6 volt or 9 volt DC fans. We have a 1 amp freezer, 1.2 amp refrigerator and a 2.4 amp refrigerator. We only use them when we need them.
author: Fla-bushcraft Prepper

text:
Tuho
Look at the 450,000 Year Earth Temperature Graph
The earth is fixing to go into a 50,000 year cooling cycle
The Oceans have had no increase in the average sea rise in about 250 years.
The last major ocean  rise was at the time of the so called Mini ice age.
It only rises about 1 inch every ten years and that has been slowing over the last 18 years.
Some Islands have grown in recent decades. The only places that show Ocean Rise are actually sinking, it is not the ocean rising.
I live in Florida and own a sailboat. The ocean levels here are the same as they have been most of my life.
My marina dock sinks a little every year from storms and waves, but the boat ramp is the same. 
Their is a line painted for low tide and high tide. They repaint the lines every few years. They are painted over the same lines and the high tides and low tides hit those lines. Only high tides at full moon or after a major storm like Hurricane Irma make the tie higher, but within a few weeks the tide are back on those lines.

That is Science Fact.

Try looking into the     East Canada has Snow 6 foot on the ground      topic
Has not happened in 50 years. Also the north East USA and East Canada have hit or broken cold records in the last year. Records dating back to 1924 in some places. In 1924 was when the volcano in Hawaii was active like this one, but this one is worse than that one. In 1924, it was a Solar Minimum and right now it is a Solar Minimum. Some scientist say it is a Grand Solar Minimum starting. This means 50,000 years of cooling. This means the oceans will start getting lower sometimes over the next 1,000 to 5,000 years.

text: Jose - Climate change is not PERMANENTLY irreversible, and every positive thing we do to help is, well, better! We are on track to kill a few billion people with climate change within a hundred years and when that threat is really felt then people will begin to really get serious about it. That will lead to better solutions. Think "air conditioning the world" scale solutions. If we can go to the moon, we can make big tools to fix big problems - once we really decide to do so.

author: Keeman

text:
Ken Sea level rise will increase as the Earth warms. For the last 8000 years the Earth has been steadily cooled from the inter-glacial period as we were entering another ice age. Before the peak inter-glacial temperature 10-8 thousand years ago the temperature was increasing at a rate ten times less than it currently is, and the rate of sea level rise was much higher because of the warming that melted the Northern Ice Sheets. At around this temperature increase the sea level would rise as much as 7.5 meters in 160 years. Now double the rate and the temperature of the inter-glacial peak. 

The harmful effects of a warming climate is not only an increase in sea level rise. This changes the natural environment with floods, inconsistent climate patterns, invasive species and temperature reconstructing ecosystems and destroying plants and animals natural habitats, and ocean acidity eliminating shell fish from the ocean. There are more uncertain effects such as what might be released underneath the permafrost, releasing pressure from the ice sheets creating volcanic activity, fresh water and higher temperatures disrupting ocean circulation. There are more, but this is all that comes to mind right now.

What disturbs me when I read what you have to say Ken, is that you don't know anything and yet you seem to take a position from authority. Assuming what you think might be the answer is not questioning everything. Your method of understanding is not science. You could care less about the real answer.
author: Josef K

text:
I've been looking at the data. That would account for the 'position of authority' stance that you are observing. I've done my homework. My claim is that anyone that still clings to the AGW hypothesis hasn't done theirs. The data doesn't lie.

That gets emphasized if you look at the underlying science put out by UN IPCC which attributes low confidence that the extreme weather events you are attributing to AGW are in fact due to AGW.

Here is a summary of the science written by 3 professors from first class universities... and its at odds with your claims:

1. The climate is always changing; changes like those of the past half-century are common in the geologic record, driven by powerful natural phenomena
2. Human influences on the climate are a small (1%) perturbation to natural
 energy flows
3. It is not possible to tell how much of the modest recent warming can be
ascribed to human influences
4. There have been no detrimental changes observed in the most salient
 climate variables and today’s projections of future changes are highly

" Isolating and predicting the effects of such a physically small influence in a chaotic, noisy system where we have limited observations is not an easy task. "

  CO2 (energy) has been added to the carbon cycle by 30 gigatons every year. The concentrations of energy in the atmosphere have increased by a third since the pre-industrial era. The extra CO2 is cumulative because the natural carbon exchange cannot absorb the additional CO2. The effects of the increased CO2 cause global warming, which causes climate change. 

 "It is not possible to tell how much of the modest recent warming can be ascribed to human influences"

  There can never been enough evidence to fill in all of the gaps. There comes a point when you have to accept the scientific truth through a considerable amount of evidence. Fossil carbon concentrations have increased and the warming is attributed to the greenhouse effect due to less heat escaping into space and more heat returning to Earth. The long list of observations are consistent with AGW. 

"projections of future changes are highly uncertain"

text:
I should mention I received a reply from Simon Clark himself on another comment thread here. Since he's the go to man, figured I should repost his reply and mine for honesty's sake.

Simon Clark
Because it's not that simple - there are both positive and negative feedback loops. For example more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more photosynthesis from plants -> less CO2. But then at the same time more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more water vapour absorbing thermal wavelengths of radiation -> warmer planet. There are feedback loops all over the place, hence the need for complicated models!

Zacharie Etienne
Holy shit a reply from the man himself!!
If there are both positive and negative feedback loops - that only means they would either cancel each other out, or they average out into one positive feedback loop, or a negative one. 
If it's positive or negative, the Earth would've been screwed from the get go regardless of humans.
Therefore, when there's no human input, the Earth's CO2 levels must be self correcting , i.e. when CO2 levels are too high, the negative feedback loops have more punch, and when CO2 is too low, the positive feedback loops win over. Only this scenario would create an equilibrium allowing CO2 levels to remain stable over time, any other scenario would have CO2 levels spiral exponentially to either 0 or infinity due to effects of chaos.

And if that's the case, then while an additional human input of CO2 will produce a temporary rise in temperature, eventually we will again find a natural equilibrium, because although we've increased the CO2 levels, because we've done that, the net negative feedback loops will become more pronounced, while the net positive feedback loops will diminish, and (as long as human CO2 input is constant), they'll be a point where the loops once again reach equilibrium.

I can make an analogy with air resistance vs gravity. As you know, falling objects have air resistance, and the faster the velocity, the more air resistance. Therefore this is an example of a negative feedback loop, because if a falling object momentarily goes faster than the terminal velocity where air resistance and gravity are in equilibrium, then the object slows back down to terminal velocity. Likewise, if the object momentarily goes slower than the terminal velocity, gravity win over the air resistance, creating a positive feedback loop, and making the object speed back to terminal velocity. Any other universe where the object didn't have a positive feedback loop when going to slow AND a negative feedback loop when going to fast, would inevitably result in the object either coming to a complete stop or speeding up indefinitely. 

Now in this analogy, human input of CO2 is equivalent to reducing the object's surface area. By doing so, you'll have decreased the force of air resistance, making the object fall faster/have a higher terminal velocity. But the same positive/negative feedback loops apply, so although the object will temporarily fall faster, it will inevitably reach a new terminal velocity again, where the feedback loops cancel out and it's all ok.

https://judithcurry.com/2016/07/20/sea-level-rise-acceleration-and-the-closure-problem/

Ignore her words, look for the chart.   You'll see that sea level largely plateaued nearly 8000 years ago.   The argument that "We're still coming out of an ice age" is wrong.   In fact, the Earth has gotten colder over the last few thousand years, until the recent warming spike that is.

Over the last 40 years glacial melt has increased.   This is a fact.  Very carefully measured by satellite.   The rate is still slow, but it's the warming in combination with the increase that's scary.   A significant increase may follow.   Nobody can say with accuracy when.   Unlike air temperature which is a fairly straight forward equation, glacial melt is nearly impossible to predict.    All we know is that the melt rate is increasing.    Your claim that "We're still coming out of an ice age" is ignorant and untrue.   We've been out of the ice age for 10,000 years.   The ice took another 2000 years to continue to melt after the ice age ended.    We're between ice ages now, with an unnatural warming spike.   The outcome of that spike on glaciers could be dangerous.    It probably will be.   It's just hard to say when.

author: Robert Bernal

text:
@Robert Bernal

I appreciate intelligent discussion, even from people I disagree with.

When you say I think he's saying that sea level rise will be about twice what the normal rise is  it's already twice the "normal rise".  The danger is that it will go a lot higher than twice and there's geological evidence to back that up.   Coastal cities are already flooding more than in the past and it's expected to get worse.

Nobody can say when sea level rise will begin to happen rapidly.   Right now it's happening twice as fast, but still very slowly.     

As for there's not much e can do about it  there's not much we can do about rising temperatures over the next 50 years.   That's a given.    Because we can't get a good estimate on the timing of rapid sea level rise, it's ignorant to say there's not much we can do about it.   It may be within the time-frame that we can address and solve before it's a serious problem.   It may not, but to say "there's nothing we can do about it" is ignorant. 

As for the video, your taking the 330 PPM in the year 3000 out of context.   He's saying that's based on models with current numbers.   He discusses the method of CO2 removal and the cost and even says "maybe the cost will go down".    

You don't know what technology will be available in the year 3000.    Will we have solved climate change by then.    Probably, but even if new technology does solve it by the year 3000, that won't make his statement at 3:58 false, because that's based on current projections.

FInally, I'm not sure what math you did, but unless you cryogenically freeze plants when they are full grown, they will release the CO2 back into the atmosphere when they decay/are eaten.   We'd need about 2 Sahara deserts full of trees to address our current man made CO2 problem.   Those forests would need to be permanent.    That's a LOT of trees and a lot of water.   Maybe we'll get there, but we're a long ways away from that now.

text:
@Robert 

Do you really not know the difference between a guess based on  political partisanship  (We'll solve the problem in 20 years) and a mathematical analysis based on a tree that absorbs 50 lbs of CO2 per year against the increased CO2 from 280 to 410 PPM.     Just to bring things to zero, not reduce the already existing increase but just to bring it to zero,  30 billion tons (metric) is 66 trillion pounds.   

50 lbs per tree = 1.32 trillion trees to balance out our CO2 output.   Now, maybe the oceans will continue aborbing, so I usually round down to 1 trillion - it's a ballpark estimate, but that's what we need to address our current CO2 footprint, about a trillion trees - which we need to allow to grow to full size because they're only useful when they are growing.

That's 15 trees for every man, woman and child on Earth.    Do you think we have room for that?

Half a continent worth of desert is about right.  It's mathematical analysis.    If you think that doing that and providing fresh water to do it is easy, I'd like to sell you the Brooklyn bridge.

Mathematical analysis is different than guessing.  It's different than doom and gloom.  

Now, I'm not against nuclear reactors, but unless you build a fleet of electric cars so that everybody has one, all Nuclear will do is replace coal and that's a fraction of the problem, not problem solved.   Nuclear has a range of issues, like - NOBODY WANTS TO LIVE NEAR ONE.   It's called the nimby problem.    Also, do we want to build nuclear power plants in 3rd world countries where terrorists can get their hands on nuclear waste.   You present it as if it's simple.  It's far from simple.    Spent Thorium  is less of a storage problem than spent Uranium because in theory it burns more completely and it decays faster so it needs to be stored for hundreds not thousands of years, but it still makes one hell of a dirty bomb if the wrong people get their hands on the waste.

Not to mention, if we do go MSR - which I'm fine with by the way, you've put the US coal miners out of work and that's been an issue here - look I'm all for it.   But your solution is partial and has risks and faces political objections too.     I'm just injecting reality into the discussion.    It's dumb to say "build MSR, problem solved".    And I say that as someone who's fine with building more MSR reactors and shutting down the coal industry.    I'm 100% OK with that.   If we do that, maybe we only need 750 billion trees, not a trillion.   :-)

Math, logic, understanding the risks and knowing all the facts.   That's where it's at.

text:
Thanks for the update
By reading your previous statements (against me, and probably against a skeptic), I thought you were totally unaware of the MSR options. I agree, it's a hard sell!
 I did some math and I think there is enough deserts in the world to grow all that extra soil. You see, trees are not really the solution, but the soil beneath can be.
SOC or soil organic carbon is much higher in some soils than in others.

Now, what probably set you off is that I said something about the Sahara, and yes, that's a no no (because of political and religious problems)'

However, here's my "math" that I just figured out a few days ago (hence my excitement, last night).

We need to get the 410 ppm CO2 back down to about 300 ppm. How do we do that? First, how much is that?
The atmosphere currently has about 0.041% by volume CO2, (equal to 410 ppm) which corresponds to approximately 3200 gigatons of CO2. Simple math tells us we have to safely sequester 850 gigatons of the CO2 from the air.
How do we put all that into the soil?
First, how much land is required?
SOC or soil organic carbon is only 0.5% in desert soils. But is usually about 2.5% in rather good soil.
CO2 weighs more than just the carbon component. The carbon content of CO2 is 12/44. The "44" is one carbon at molecular weight of 12 and two oxygen at 2 x 16. Therefore, we can divide the 850 GT of CO2 by the inverse, 3.666 to get a total of 230 GT of actual carbon that needs to be put back into the ground.
This is what photosynthesis is for!
There's only about 36,000 tons of carbon per sq km at 2.5% SOC, possible to be sequestered. Perhaps much more. 230,000,000,000 tons of excess carbon divided by 36,000 equals almost 6.4 million sq km of desert needed to be irrigated. That's almost 2.47 million sq miles or fully FIFTEEN Californias!
However, it's less than the Sahara's 3.55 million sq miles.

Now that we know that it's possible to sequester the excess CO2 into the desert ground, we need to find out how much water will be required.
I believe, that's the hard part! Too much nuclear, or way too much solar? We'd probably need 10x our present global energy demands just to build everything, desalinate such vast quantities of water, and supply the usual power demands for more developing nations, a greatly expanded space presence, too. All the while reducing FFs via the electrification of "everything".

However, the battery revolution is coming because some (albeit, very few at this time) are already buying "home batteries". Billions of those connected to billions of solar roofs and other solar and wind installations via a global grid (that political problems again seems to thwart) would solve the clean energy challenge without nuclear.
And yes, I really do believe that in just 20 years, we'll have over 80x the solar we have now (based on 125% growth rate) and 20x the wind we have now (based on totally uneducated guess, and that wind is already more mature, unless structural graphene is ever developed). And batteries will be cheaper and better (based upon history of their continual improvements).
I'm trying to figure out where I got that "36,000 tons of carbon into a sq km of soil". 
I need to find out just how long that would take, assuming adequate energy supplies for water.
author: Robert Bernal

text:
@Robert

You've got an incredibly sarcasting and belittling approach to your writing.   It's not a selling point at all.

Yes, I'm educated.  I knew about MSR reactors.   Didn't know about Molten Salt energy storage, though it's a pretty straight forward concept.    The cost of building is still an issue, that doesn't mean I don't support technology.  I do.   110%.

But what I don't get is, why deny that CO2 heats the planet.   Say "yes it heats the planet, let's invest in this".    Part of the whole carbon credit trading approach, which has it's drawbacks, but part of the whole point is to encourage the building of solar plants.    Denying that the very real man made climate change is happening makes no sense, even if you think you can solve it in 20 years, and I'm not sure it's that simple, but even if you believe that, start by saying it's real and it's a problem that needs to be addressed.   Then talk about solutions.   But it makes no sense to get mad at people who are saying it's real.   Get mad at the people who are denying it, then talk about solutions, but keep in mind, production cost and nimby need to be kept in mind too.

I don't think you're right about soil.  When a tree grows, 90% of the growth is above ground.   Long term bacterial storage in soil?   Maybe, but where does the energy come from?   It takes energy to get rid of CO2.  Plants use photosynthesis for that energy source.   What would the soil use?   You seem to be missing some very basic chemistry in your calculations.    That said, soil sequestering is a method of carbon capture that scientists are exploring.   I don't think it's the miracle pill that you imply, but people are looking into it.    The thing about scientists is, they want solutions.   Some scientists study soil, some study the oceans, some study engineering approaches like the one mentioned in this video.   The scientist who solves the riddle will have a shot at a nobel prize, so all scientists in all fields are interested.   You seem to imply that you have this idea that nobody else has thought of.   That's not how science works.  It's nearly impossible today to have an idea that nobody's thought of.

Your math (850 billion tons of CO2) is about right, I get 860, but minor point.  But your mathematics for carbon storage sounds idealistic.   You don't quote a single source, you're just making estimates.   And you're ignoring that as plants die, they decompose and the CO2 is returned.   Yes, there are some swamps with low oxygen where growth tends to get submerged with little decomposition but you can't just build a sahara desert sized swamp.   There's no good way to avoid the natural decay process, nor should you want too, that creates soil and fertilizer and growth.   The best way to solve it is to grow trees which have the best and longest carbon storage, which brings us back to the 1 trillion tree estimate that I proposed a few posts up.    Your soil sequestering doesn't sound well thought out.   Idealistic, not realistic.    And there are scientists and scholarly articles on soil sequestering of CO2.  It's not like it's an ignored area of research.

I find your last paragraph odd.  You talk about how hard it would be, and 10 times our current energy production.    That's gonzo amounts of money right there.   Insane amounts of money.   Can we start by saying that man made climate change is real and then look at all the avenues to address it.   And can you stop saying that it will be solved in 20 years, because that's very far from certain.    I'll add to that, it's not even all that likely.    What we might have in 20 years is a better organized plan to address it.   If we can get the republicans and concervatives to turn down the fog and controversy.
author: YTEdy

text:
But what I don't get is, why deny that CO2 heats the planet.

Why, just why i would I even care about greening deserts and nuclear powered desalination, if I wasn't concerned about excess CO2. 
Hmmm.
Now, I shall get even more sarcastic?

How could I be ignoring the fact that plants die (and re-release CO2 back into the air, when in fact, I was talking about the soil and even said trees are not "really" the solution (because of this very fact).
However, if you want combative, I will remind you that some trees live to many hundreds of years old, and so, they are not "really" part of the problem either.

It's the soil, especially new soil. I'm not a farmer, however, have looked into good soil. without it, we wouldn't even exist! And that's definitely part of the carbon cycle.

Concerning the math, I assume that we all know the gigatons of excess CO2 by simple search.

I can't find the link to SOC, so, I'm pasting another that leads to a paywall. This is just the first few paragraphs, shown.

   Blockquote

Maintaining sustainable and environmentally friendly fresh produce production in the context of climate change
D. Pimentel, M. Burgess, in Global Safety of Fresh Produce, 2014

10.3.1
Carbon
Soil carbon, which correlates with the soil organic matter levels, was measured in 1981 and 2002. In 1981, the soil carbon levels were about the same (about 2%) in both the organic and conventional systems (Pimentel et al., 2005). In 2002, however, the soil organic matter in the organic systems was about 5%, whereas in the conventional system, it remained about 2%. The higher soil organic matter levels found in the organic systems cause the soil to retain more water that results in better crop yields during droughts, reduces soil erosion, increases plant nutrient retention and increases biological diversity. There was about 4000 kg per ha of soil carbon in the conventional system but about 10 000 kg per ha of soil carbon in the organic system in 2002. The higher water content accounted for the higher corn and soybean yields during the drought years faced by these systems (Lotter et al., 2003).

Higher soil organic matter levels cause greater soil nitrogen retention, greater microbial biodiversity, and promote the presence and growth of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi that penetrate the roots of crops and facilitate the movement of plant nutrients from the soil into the crop plants resulting in better crop growth and yields (Pimentel et al., 2005). Higher soil carbon levels also hold soil particles together so less soil erosion occurs (Pimentel et al., 2005).

   End blockquote
From https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/soil-carbon

So, If I go with 5 tonnes/hectare, that's 500,000 tonnes/sq km of actual carbon that can be sequestered from the air using whatever best plants to do so. 230 (? or is it 250, I forgot). Ok, 250 billion divided half a million equals 5 million sq km of new soil needed.
Of course this would take time, and of course more is being added to the air every year, but this seems to be the major way of natural sequestration, given enough clean energy to get the water needed, and more clean energy to power the growing world.

Stuff like this motivates me away from the depression of today's reality.

text: About public transport; it depends. If you talk about buses and diesel trains, they pollute as much as a car per passenger. Partly because their utilisation is low when you factor in lines in rural areas and off hours and the fact that they employ people that need vacations and sick leave and go on strikes regularly. Further they generate more tax revenues that are used to pollute even more. There is a reason why public transport is 20 times as expensive per distance unit than driving in your car. Un-piloted autonomous electric trains are the only mass transport that pollutes less than driving in your own car, but building them creates massive CO2 deficits, that takes decades to catch up with. Cycling, even better on an E-bike is the least polluting means of transport, but that is only if you are a vegetarian. A meat eating cyclist emits 85g CO2 / kilometre (almost as much as a car) if you factor in pollution created from farming for the extra food needed to propel you down the bike lane. Remember we out-phased oxes and horses for a reason.The only way to curb CO2 emissions at a scale where it will have an effect great enough to catch up with this exponential growth in CO2 emissions, is to limit human mobility, i.e. work from home, reduce consumption and spending and curb economic growth, even limit the number of children each couple is allowed. The country that does that puts itself a serious serious competitive disadvantage, so no government would ever consider this. The conclusion is we will not make it in the long run even if the most ambitious initiatives from around the world are implemented today, put together, they are still 50-100 times too small to have an impact.

text: 2016. Its a pointless question.  So what if it is the hottest ... and importantly ... the hottest on the rather short record? The reconstruction data says it was warmer during the Minoan, Roman, and Medieval warm periods as it is now. Viking farms on Greenland are still frozen in permafrost. Now its at the end of a grand solar minima ... and temperatures have been rising since the last grand solar minima and the mini ice age ... so of course you're going to get a hottest year. It doesn't prove AGW hypothesis; there is no way to tell how much, if any, of the modest warming that has been observed is due to human activity.

text:
The data is found here:
http://www.drroyspencer.com/latest-global-temperatures/

Please note the data is global ... a much larger area than USA.

When you consider the difference from 1880 to 2016 is 0.8C with error bars +/- 1C, that most of the data prior to satellites is continental USA and West Europe, and the fact that we are talking about the hottest year on the basis of 1/100ths of a degree ... its pointless. It does not shed any light on what is causing the warming. It does not make the case that it will get warmer or cooler. It does not prove that the modest warming being observed will lead to catastrophe. It is simply a statistic that signifies nothing.

Oh yeah, one other thing. 2016 was an el nino year. The warm spike in the data is due to ocean currents.
author: Ken Van de Burgt

text:
1. The climate is always changing; changes like those of the past half-century are common in the geologic record, driven by powerful natural phenomena
2. Human influences on the climate are a small (1%) perturbation to natural energy flows
3. It is not possible to tell how much of the modest recent warming can be ascribed to human influences
4. There have been no detrimental changes observed in the most salient climate variables and today’s projections of future changes are highly uncertain

Source:
http://blogs2.law.columbia.edu/climate-change-litigation/wp-content/uploads/sites/16/case-documents/2018/20180319_docket-317-cv-06011_na-1.pdf

text: Ken Van de Burgt, Hurricane Harvey dumped 33 trillion gallons of water on the U.S. There has been two category 4 hurricanes thus far this year. You don't think these two facts alone are cause for concern?
author: RandomVariable

text:
No its not a matter for concern ... unless you happen to be directly affected ... in which case you have my sympathies.  Hurricane Harvey is not unprecedented in the hurricane record. 

The only unusual thing in the climate record is the 12 year hiatus in landfall hurricanes between Katrina and Harvey. Its never been that long a respite. The amount of rain from Harvey was not unusual; what was unusual was the storm stalled instead of moving as most hurricanes do, and all the rain fell in one location.

There is a paper by Hodges and Elsner that finds correlation between solar cycle minima and incidence of land fall hurricanes. The hypothesis is that sunspot activity increases UV light. The increase in UV energy warms the upper atmosphere and a warmer upper atmosphere means a more stable atmosphere with fewer hurricanes. There is evidence we are going into a grand solar minima ... which could really mean more hurricanes. https://rmets.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/joc.2196

Even UN IPCC AR5 assigns low confidence to any hypothesis that there is an increase in number or intensity of cyclone activity due to an increase in CO2 in the atmosphere.

Here is a book you really should read so you have some knowledge of hurricanes and hurricane trends: https://www.amazon.com/Inevitable-Disaster-Hurricanes-Blamed-Warming-ebook/dp/B075QN3KFY/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1506014459&sr=1-1&keywords=inevitable+disaster

text:
Infinit888, the data proves nothing of the sort. Not even the most rabid proponent of catastrophic greenhouse theory (AGW) suggests anything of the sort. Only utter morons like Bill Nye the Science Guy, Al Gore and loony Obama make such wildly inaccurate statements. At best CO2 only contributes to warming. The Earth is a water planet and water vapour is the principle greenhouse gas. That's an indisputable fact.

The planet has been warming since the end of The Little Ice Age, roughly 200 years ago ... entirely from natural causes. It has only been since the 1940s that humans began to release sufficient CO2 to have any anthropogenic  GHE at all. The problem is, as that was happening temperatures began falling for around 30 years. Obviously there is no causative correlation between CO2 and temperature. Presently there has been no statistically significant warming for two decades ... but CO2 concentrations have continued to climb.
author: RORY FORBES

author: RORY FORBES

text:
Andy Lee Robinson ... yes indeed, climate change effects everyone and always has. Guess what, it always will. Climates always change. If they didn't we'd be in deep trouble. Nothing we do or don't do will alter that fact.

However, the only change humans need to fear is cooling ... yes cooling, a resumption of the ice age we're currently living in. At present we're all living in the Goldilocks period of the Holocene Inter-glacial which usually last around the time span ours has lasted already, around 15,000 years.THEN IT GETS COLD AGAIN ... real cold. Long before the pitifully tiny warming effect due to CO2 can become dangerous ... we'll be well in to the next cold phase of the present ice age.

In fact, the Holocene has gradually cooled since what is known as The Optimum, roughly 8000 years ago. Temperatures have dropped approx. 1 - 2 degrees every thousand years or so with each warm period. Our present warm period needs many degrees more than the present to win back the heat that was lost during The Little Ice Age.

text: Anthropogenic global warming is not fake, it is exaggerated for political purposes. Most of the warming that has taken place is from solar activity, namely the Modern Maximum that started around the industrial revolution. In addition, Earth is dipping back down into the next glacial maximum of this ice age where co2 levels will drop by as much as 250 ppm naturally for 100,000+ years. Finally, 400 ppm is nowhere near enough to cause runaway greenhouse effect. For most of Earths history, co2 levels have been around 2,000 ppm. Earth is at all time low co2 levels. Most vegetation is suffering because of it. If it drops below 150 ppm, all photosynthetic organisms will go extinct and virtually everything else with them. We are at a much greater risk of freezing than we are of burning, not that you need to worry about either of those things anyway.

(Go ahead and prove me wrong!  Lol you can't!)
Let me put it in a way that even you can understand it:

The Milankovitch cycles reveal a picture of earth's long term climate.  This climate consists of vast cold periods known as Ice ages repeating roughly every 100 thousand years or so.  We happen to be in the middle of one such Ice age.  Within this vast Ice age there are brief spikes of warm weather known as interglacials, one of which, a particularly mild one, we happen to find ourselves in.  
Now if you still don't get it, let me spell it out for you:  
For the average Man on the street who only gets to hear the stories of doom from the alarmist media and from climate change cultists such as yourself it would benefit them tremendously to know about the Milankovitch cycles.  It would help them to know that there is ice age behind us and in front and that the interglacial we are is a mild one.  If cold is in our future perhaps global warming will help keep the winter at bay for a few more years.  Perhaps also the chicken little-sky is falling stories of what will happen if the planet heats up a few degrees won't seem that real if they knew we've experienced much warmer interglacials than what we have today and that this is indisputable given the fossil record. Europe had a flora and fauna much closer to what you see in Africa today.  In fact hippos roamed as far north as Scotland.  So they'll see that global warming did not precipitate the apocalyptic scenario of the climate alarmists instead lush forests and megafauna covered the planet.  
Imagine what this will do to agriculture in the coming century!

Are you starting to get it now?  I don't think so.  You can't even grasp the scientific concepts behind the Milankovitch cycles!
author: estontin123

text:
Hank
This is universally used data all heavily peer-reviewed and used almost ubiquitously for the last couple of decades in a wide range of studies. 


The first graph is GISP2 ice core data from Greenland by R.B. Alley who was invited to testify for climate change by Al Gore in 1999. 

The second is a graph of estimated solar activity, it is used everywhere in the context of solar activity. You would have probably seen it before if you looked at studies involving it more often. I simply threw it in there to illustrate the cyclic nature of solar activity. 

The third is the UAH satellite-based temperature record of the lower atmosphere. This data is used by everyone, NASA, NOAA, independents, EVERYONE. There is even a Wikipedia page about UAH data. This is all accurate and respectable data sets. 

The fourth is simply actual records of solar activity by the Royal Observatory of Belgium. This data is completely accurate and universally used by scientists. The fact that you have never seen a study using it doesn't at all surprise me.

The fifth graph is 400 years of sunspot records going back to the 1600s. Are you seriously trying to claim it's incorrect?

The sixth graph is also universally used data that's been reviewed by the American Journal of Science and the Geological Society of America. It's not wrong.

The seventh is, again, universally used data, peer-reviewed by as much as it possibly could be. It is simply showing co2 levels vs temperature during the Eemian and Holocene interglacial. It's not an "interpretation" it is raw data, like all the other graphs I've shown you.

The eighth and final graph uses several different data sets and labels them on the graph. There is no excuse for you not knowing the validity of this data. It uses GEOCARB III, COPSE, Rothman, Royer compilation, and the 30 Myr filter models.


I'm not giving you an interpretation of the data, I'm literally just telling what the graphs are. Again, I got the images off of google images, just because some sketchy websites used them too doesn't cancel out the fact that this is all peer-reviewed, reliable data that has been used for years even decades. I've already devoted too much of my time trying to relieve you of your ignorance, I'm not going to scour the internet for specific studies that use this data (I don't think that would convince you anyway). Now that I've spent at least an hour showing you my sources, and then proving to you my sources are peer-reviewed, can you now finally begin to refute my argument? Or should I hire a team of scientists for you to confirm the validity of the graphs?

I don't know how this is supposed to help you understand it. http://www.climatedata.info/proxies/ice-cores/ Also http://www.nbi.ku.dk/english/news/news13/greenland-ice-cores-reveal-warm-climate-of-the-past/ It took me about half an hour just to find these. There is no reason for you to think it is unreliable. 


I have no idea why you think that if I've done my homework I should remember the exact URL of each and every article I visited that had the data on them. That's why I just used google images and looked for the graphs themselves. It's almost impossible to find an article that uses a graph just by typing in the name of the graph. Take the temperature record I cited for instance, can you find a temperature record that goes right to 2018? No, you can't. Even NASA only goes to 2016 because they haven't updated their graphs since then (partly because it would go against their narrative, temperatures have started to decline since 2016). Just because it is compelling data doesn't mean NASA or NOAA will stand up and make a study around it. They only do whatever they are paid to do and usually only things that reinforce their narrative. Looking directly at raw data is the most unbiased, objective way of examining the data. If that isn't good enough for you, nothing will be.

text:
Hank
I appreciate your newfound modesty but after all you've said it is hard to tell if you're not just trolling sarcastically. This is the last time I am going to hold your hand through my argument, ok? If you still don't get it after this, that is your problem, not mine.

2. Yes, it is about sunspots. They reflect solar activity and have been kept track of since the 1600s soon after the invention of the telescope. There is a very strong positive correlation between them and temperature, much greater than with CO2. Again, this is my weaker point.

You did not refute the approaching glacial period and the fact that 400 ppm does not cause runaway greenhouse effect (which together make a single point).
