author: Tristun Alekzander

text:
1. Yes, I realize you were talking about the second graph... you cited that Wikipedia page as a source of information related to the graph (which is what I asked you for). Also on the page was the first graph. I asked you in what way THAT graph supports your position. If your position is supported by information regarding the Medieval warming period then shouldn't the first graph also have relevance? Specifically I am referring to the large temperature spike on the right hand side of that graph. Does that coincide with us entering an ice age and drop in temperatures? Aren't current temperatures well above the Medieval warming? What is the significance of the graph showing us just coming out of the Little Ice Age? Are you aware that some people claim our current warming is a result of the ending of an ice age, not entering a new one?

2 & 4. I knew it was about sunspots!! Ok, so what is a 'Peak' and what is the difference between a peak and a double peak? Everything I have ever read about the double-peak cycles is referring to the sunspot number but you say that is wrong. Also, if they have only been keeping track of sunspots since the 1600's, how can they detect 1000 year cycles? To the best of my knowledge, the earliest sunspot records are only from about 2000 years ago (and they are from unaided observations and not reliable enough to determine the cycles) so how are these 1000 year cycles detected? What is the significance of these 1000 year sunspot cycles... like what effect did the one that you say just passed have on our climate? Why is the most recent warming in stark disagreement with our decreasing solar activity? If the climate is mostly a result of these solar cycles, shouldn't it be fairly easy to produce a climate model which reproduces the recorded history (and reproduces the warming of the past 100 years)? Why have models like that failed?

5. The 'points' I was refuting are the multiple statements you have made in your first posts here, not necessarily the specific claims you are numbering now.

Please tell me what you mean by a 'Runaway Greenhouse Effect'. Are you saying this should make the Earth like Venus (who's temperature is often described as a runaway greenhouse)? Are you saying the Earth's climate is dependent mostly on these solar cycles so that a positive feedback of rising CO2 is not possible? And the most important question: If you have figured all this out and accept it as the most reasonable explanation for the data, why have scientists who have studied this for their whole careers dismissed it as insufficient to account for the warming we are experiencing?

Thanks for explaining all this to me!!
author: Hank

text:
Hank
I just want to say that your change of attitude has made this debate much more pleasant. I very much appreciate it and commend you for your objectivity and respectfulness and I apologize for insulting you so many times. Also, sorry for writing so much, but you asked some big questions that I could have written an entire book on and I had to refrain from typing even more than I did. This is a very complex topic and even many scientists do not fully understand it (and I certainly don't either).

1. Yes, temperatures are currently higher than that of the last warming period, the Medieval Warming period, but not by much, just enough to account for the extra bit of CO2 we have added. It is nowhere near enough to override the next glacial period. That graph is stretched out to exaggerate our current warming. Temperatures during the Jurassic or Cretaceous, for instance, wouldn't even fit on that graph, they would be miles above it.

We are currently in an ice age called the Quaternary Glaciation. A "glacial period" is not an ice age (a common misconception). Ice ages last tens of millions of years (sometimes hundreds), while glacial periods within ice ages last only around 100,000 years. The interglacials in between them (such as the one we are in now called the Holocene interglacial that started 13,000 years ago) only last around 10-15,000 years. The Quaternary Glaciation only started around 2.5 mya so it is unlikely that it is ending. 

2. Yes, we only know for sure what the solar activity is back to about the year 1600, but since then, it has had an almost 100% correlation with temperature, whether that is coldness or warmth. It is common knowledge among climatologists that the Maunder Minumum or the "little ice age" was caused by low solar activity. As you can see from the  "400 years of sunspot observations" graph, the sun has small 11-year cycles, but the graph shows about half of a complete grand solar cycle, showing its low point in 1600 and the high point in 1950. I think there are even larger cycles the sun goes into accounting for the glacial and interglacial periods and ultimately the ice ages but that goes outside of my realm of knowledge.

The term "double peak" is rather confusing. What I'm only fairly certain it means is that in 1950 there was a single peak, the grand solar maximum of the Modern Maximum, activity began to decrease, but, out of nowhere, there were two consecutive "peaks" in 1980 and 1990. This is thought to be unprecedented in solar activity but like you inquired, we can't know for sure. You may want to fact check that as I am not very versed in solar activity but the meaning of the term "double peak" is irrelevant to my argument.

We approximately know what solar activity was by studying geological indicators on Earth. Temperature and CO2 are easy to detect but I'm not exactly sure how we look for solar activity, but, with the magic of science, we can. That is probably something for you to learn on your own.

A lot of the models didn't even take into account solar activity or even cloud cover because it was decided by the mainstream that it has nothing to do with temperature. That is why they were mostly wrong. As you get more into this subject, you will begin to realize just how incompetent and echo-chambered our "scientists" can be.

3. I made three claims in my original post: the main one was, basically, we are heading into another glacial period and there is no reason to worry about warming. The second was that solar activity has a much greater impact on temperature than CO2 alone. The third was simply me saying that we are closer to being low on CO2 than having too much of it. Levels below 150 ppm and we are talking of mass extinction on a scale Earth has only seen once before 600 million years ago. I didn't count that as a point though. I haven't made any new points I'm fairly certain.

The ugly truth is, despite the fact that they have PhDs, they are about as objective as anyone in these goddamn YT comments lol I know it sounds sad but it is the truth. The courses they take are often taught by professors who know about as much as you do or did. Our entire educational system is corrupt and mostly run by left-wing extremists trying to promote their political narrative. BTW, I am centrist.

Runaway greenhouse effect: CO2 causes temperatures to rise, but, rising temperatures also cause a rise in CO2. If CO2 levels become so high, there will be no way of stopping the rise in temperature and this is known as a "runaway greenhouse effect." At a certain point, it gets so hot that co2 will start evaporating into space. This is actually how scientists believe Earth will die, by a lack of CO2. In around 600 million years, the sun will become hot enough that it evaporates all of our precious CO2, killing all photosynthetic organisms and everything else with them. 400 ppm is nowhere near enough CO2 to cause runaway greenhouse effect. We know that because CO2 has been much higher in the past and there was no runaway greenhouse effect.

You asked some big questions so please kindly let me know if I left something out or didn't give you the answer you were looking for. Also, I will try writing less. I understand that it not only makes it hard to digest but hard to respond to. Thanks again.
author: Tristun Alekzander

text:
1. The graph is not stretched out, the y axis (time) is linear and the data sources are available to verify it is accurate. While the current temperatures & CO2 would not be able to prevent another glacial period, you are neglecting the fact that both are increasing at a rate that exceeds the records of natural warming. You are correct that the temperatures of the Jurassic or Cretaceous periods would not fit on that graph but there were also no people alive during those periods and there likely won't be if/when we return to the same global average temperatures.

Yes, we would naturally reach a point where the glaciers would return but the build-up of ice is extremely slow. The increasing CO2 and temperatures indicate that we are no where near the return of the glaciers. Current estimates are still thousands of years away just for the cooling to start and another 100,000 years for the glaciers to return.

2. The correlation between solar activity and average global temperatures is no where near 100%. Your belief of 'the little ice age was caused by low solar activity' being common knowledge among climatologists is 100% wrong. The Maunder minimum and the little ice age are two different things that should not be equated with an 'or' the way you did; one describes solar activity, the other a climate event affecting mostly the Northern hemisphere. The little ice age started before the Maunder minimum and was NOT a global event (which changes in solar dynamics are) thereby proving that the little ice age was not 'caused by' the lower sunspot activity of the Maunder minimum. The Dalton minimum is more indicative of a correlation but the relationship is not well understood. It is certainly not causal.

The term double peak is not confusing at all, the way you are trying to use it is. Since you say it is irrelevant to your argument, I won't waste time on it or explain how solar cycle data for early periods is estimated.

I think you misunderstood my question about the models. Many of the current models don't take solar activity into account because it has already been measured to have around a .1 degree temperature variation associated with it. Recent high quality measurements show the solar output varies very little with sunspot activity. The models actually work very well despite not including this solar variation (which further suggests it is not the cause of the current warming). The question I was asking you is: If the warming is being caused mostly by solar cycles, why can't you (or some other amateur climatologists) develop a model based on this solar activity that replicates the temperature data we have available? You are right that THOSE TYPES of  models simply don't work and that is more evidence that the warming is not related to solar cycles. By all means, come up with a solar model that does better than the current models and you WILL be taken seriously.

3. The Earth has been through many extinction events, the worst of which was 250 million years ago (not 600). Since it is not one of your points, I will not dwell on it except to say that we are currently in an extinction event and the consensus is that we are causing it. 

The 'runaway greenhouse effect' is indeed what you are describing but I have never heard a climatologist suggest we are causing that. Most believe it is not even possible for the Earth if ALL carbon were converted to CO2. The term is usually  used as a straw argument for the positive feedback system we know about or for media sensationalism to make money. It is this feedback system that causes the swings of natural warming/cooling cycles and the data strongly suggests we are altering that natural cycle. It is not that 400 ppm of CO2 is some magic number which causes it, it is the RATE at which we are pumping it into the atmosphere will push us past a tipping point and cause the positive feedback to take over. Current data suggests this may already be happening.

The idea that, as the temperature increases, we will lose our CO2 is fantasy. The scenario you describe is for WATER, not CO2. Yes, in 500M to 1B years, the sun's intensity will have increased enough that the water will 'boil away' from the planet. Carbon Dioxide is more dense than water and will remain in the atmosphere long after the water leaves. All one has to do is look at Venus to see that the ~900 degree surface temps have not boiled away its atmosphere of 95% CO2. The thing that strips gasses from the atmosphere of a planet are solar winds. This has ABSOLUTELY NOTHING to do with AGW.

I will limit my critique of your opinion of scientists and the education system except to say that they are the ones collecting the very data you are using to form your argument. You cannot simultaneously smear them as nonobjective and then accept their data which you pick to suit your argument as valid. The simple fact is that the majority of people in the US who refuse to accept the science demonstrating AGW are Tea Party Conservatives. This is not surprising since the Tea Party was primarily the work of the Koch brothers and Americans for Prosperity (their political advocacy group). Koch Industries, a very large petroleum oriented company and the brothers (along with the Heartland Institute, CFACT, and others), invest large sums of money in propaganda to deliberately misinform people about AGW. It is all very well documented if you care to research it. I am also not impressed by your claim of being 'centric.' People can label themselves with whatever they want; the Fox News loving Trump supporters and the Leftist Social Justice Warriors generally both describe themselves as 'centric'. A political label can only be assigned considering your political position relative to the rest of the world. I don't claim to know where you lie on that scale and I don't really care. Your arguments stand or fall based on their own merits.

I generally don't bother trying to teach deniers where their arguments have gone wrong any more... the science is out there but they really have no interest in learning it except to look for flaws. It really is a waste of time to get into arguments over it. It is also a waste of time to try to associate unrelated graphs and form a conclusion about what you think the data suggests unless you also research the underlying dynamics. Your posts here indicate to me that you have very little background knowledge in the subjects and you are misunderstanding the stuff you are finding; Caty Marvelous is doing the same thing. I implore you (both of you) to research actual scientific papers (which you clearly aren't doing) and avoid the propaganda if you want to come to a realistic conclusion. You are not doing yourself or anyone any favors by pretending these counter arguments hold equal weight. Your main area of misunderstanding is the time scales of the various factors you are trying to associate. The warming we are now seeing is not related to previous natural warming cycles. This is the most information I will give you on the topic. If you want to dispute it, please do so with actual peer reviewed research rather than more graphs or what you think the raw data indicates. Anything short of this and I will return to simple ridicule which is all people who refuse to look at the science deserve. You have admitted to not understanding some of the things mentioned which I applaud you for. If not for that I wouldn't have spent this much time on a reply.
author: Hank

text:
Hank
1. I didn't really mean stretched out rather than zoomed in. But yes, that graph is completely accurate. It is certainly not a completely natural warming. It is a combination of a normal warming period (the Modern Maximum) and about 100 ppm of extra CO2. The rate of warming is only unprecedented in the last 23,000 years, while the magnitude is only unprecedented in the last 2,000 if I am remembering correctly. 

It takes thousands of years for glaciers to form. You are confusing a glacial period with the height of its glaciation called a glacial maximum. Though we won't be a mile under ice for thousands of years, there is evidence that when glacial periods start, the temperatures fall down to about as cold as they will get almost instantly. Though you could accuse me of fear-mongering in the opposite direction I believe it is absolutely warranted.

2. I guess you are right about that one. I was sort of speaking off the cuff when I said that, I don't even think people use language like "100% correlation."

And yes, apparently me thinking the Maunder Minimum and the Little Ice Age were the same thing is a common misconception. However, it is still controversial whether or not it was the cause. Most scientists think that it was mainly caused by volcanic activity which usually coincides with solar minima. Comparing the first graph and the "400 years of sunspot observations"
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Ice_Age
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maunder_Minimum#Little_Ice_Age
 it is indeed clear that temperatures started declining before the sun entered a full solar minimum. One thing to note is that temperatures started falling right as soon as the Medieval Warming period peaked and as such correlate with the declining solar activity. The way you make it sound is that temperatures were level right up until they abruptly dropped in 1560, around 50 years before solar activity did the same when in reality, both temperatures and solar activity were declining together as soon as the Medieval Warming peak ended.

"Recent high quality measurements show the solar output varies very little with sunspot activity." I would love to see this. From my understanding, solar output is directly correlated with sunspots. Sunspots are black because the sun is releasing such high energy, that it is outside of our perceptible visible light. It means the sun has high solar activity and it results in a stronger magnetosphere on Earth. Lower numbers of sunspots coincide with weaker solar output and a weaker Earth magnetosphere. To say that solar output doesn't increase when the sun starts blowing out massive high energy holes in its outer layer just seems a little illogical to me. I would be very surprised if you were right about that one.

The .1 degree of temperature change still has quite an impact on temperature as well as co2 levels themselves. Not only that but its impact changes as its output changes so it is completely illogical to not include them in their models and as such most of the predictions made about global warming were very, very inaccurate. For instance (I'm not sure which specific model), it was predicted that our ice caps would be almost completely gone by this time when instead, we are seeing a resurgence in ice formation in both the poles and Greenland. The temperature rise is also much less than what was originally predicted, in fact, our temperature rise has slowed down and may even start declining, exactly what they should have predicted had they taken into account solar activity and cloud cover (which are closely related).

3. The Snowball Earth hypothesis is just that, a hypothesis. We have evidence of glaciation at the equator estimated from somewhere before 650 mya. Unless the Earth flipped on its axis, it would have been the largest and most severe extinction event in Earths history. Although, all organism at the time were single-celled microorganisms so there is not much more evidence for it.

A runaway greenhouse effect would be needed to override the next glacial period. Otherwise, there is no reason to think we will just continue warming forever. I really don't see how the rate of CO2 emissions matters. We are almost out of oil anyway and CO2 will begin declining (as it always does) as we enter the next solar minimum and on top of that the next glacial period.

I wasn't trying to claim that high temperatures will balance out co2. By the time it gets hot enough to evaporate co2, it will be very, very hot indeed.

4. I'm not criticizing the scientists that collected the data and I'm not trying to claim that all scientists are fraudulent. I'm saying that the business, politically oriented board of directors that make the decisions for all of the major science institutions are not only usually not even scientists, but always just agree with the majority in a massive "circle jerk." In fact, it is their rule that they have only at least one scientist on their board. They are mostly nonscientists and had nothing to do with collecting the data.

I say I am centrist because I actually am. I took the popular political compass test and landed smack dab in the center. Not near the center, literally directly on top of the center. I am centrist. I hold many conservative views as well as liberal, for instance, you know my stance on climate change but I also am "pro-choice" and other such things. It actually helps a lot for people to know that I am not their opposing political party. A lot of times, people will just disagree with me because they think I am some looney right-wing conspiracist and they will only start to consider my opinion after knowing I am not the "enemy." That is why I told you, I'm glad you are someone who doesn't care.

5. "the science is out there but they really have no interest in learning it except to look for flaws." I often say this same exact thing to flat-earthers and deniers of evolution. I intentionally tried to use data that both sides accept and use for this very same reason. I also avoided articles from either side that could be interpreted as biased. Yes, I don't have a huge background knowledge of this, neither do you, we are both dependent on whatever the mainstream spoon feeds us. I think everything you have typed you had to research first and everything I'm saying I'm remembering from researching a long time ago. If you believe that my information is propaganda (which it is, doesn't mean it's bad), then isn't it logical to assume yours might also just be propaganda? Don't these institutions and political advocates have billions of dollars to gain off of taxing CO2? There is just as much or more incentive for them to promote AGW as it is for oil corporations to deny it. 

"The warming we are now seeing is not related to previous natural warming cycles." So why almost exactly 1,000 years later, right on schedule, we are seeing warming that roughly coincides with a grand solar maximum? I'm not saying it is the sole cause, obviously, the CO2 we have added has a lot to do with it (which is why I'm not a "denier") but you are basically trying to claim that our grand solar cycles suddenly stopped after the medieval warming. They did not stop and anthropogenic CO2 can absolutely not account for all of our current warming. Again, you don't need to look at peer-reviewed articles to confirm this. I don't even know if I (or you) would be able to find an article specifically addressing these exact points and I'm not about to scour the internet a second time to show you arguably biased propaganda, I would say at this point, the burden of proof is on you. Show me how anthropogenic CO2 alone was the cause of the Modern Maximum warming, and why the solar activity that coincided with previous warming periods for some reason didn't have anything to do with this specific cycle. All you will find is articles saying that "since solar activity is on the decline, and temperatures are still rising (despite them slowing down), we can conclude that solar activity isn't the cause of our current warming." Which you must realize does not at all answer my claim. The subtracted difference in solar activity and temperature compared to the previous warming periods (the Medieval Warming, the Roman Warming, the Minoan Warming) is a small amount and is perfectly explained with a small increase of 100 ppm of CO2. If there were peer-reviewed studies addressing these points then certainly you could find them. Every time you ask me to find you peer-reviewed articles I get the sense that you have become stumped.

I did, however, find this article when trying to look up the definition of "double peaking grand solar maximum" that you were able to easily find apparently. I am sure you will just write this off as another denier blog. Also, you will realize how stupid it is to make someone read an entire article just to show you that other scientists do indeed think what I think.
https://wattsupwiththat.com/2014/08/06/recent-paper-finds-recent-solar-grand-maximum-was-a-rare-or-even-unique-event-in-3000-years/
It says that the solar activity is not only highest in 1,000 years, but that it is highest in 3,000. Your claim that it has nothing to do with temperature is absolutely ignorant and frankly, ridiculous.
author: Tristun Alekzander

text:
"It is a combination of a normal warming period (the Modern Maximum) and about 100 ppm of extra CO2."

The Modern Maximum refers to the number of sun spots, not a warming period... I really don't think you understand that.

"there is evidence that when glacial periods start, the temperatures fall down to about as cold as they will get almost instantly"

Nope, there is a sharp turnaround and then a slow decline in temperatures. That is backed up by your own graphs. NOTHING about climate is 'almost instant'. The change we are now seeing is faster than any climate change for the past 65 million years. That is not explainable by sunspots. And our temperatures are still very much on the increase.

"Recent high quality measurements show the solar output varies very little with sunspot activity." I would love to see this.

It was in the paper you cited for me, I pointed it out to you several times, you should try actually reading it. I strongly suspect you have tried and simply don't understand it.

"Sunspots are black because the sun is releasing such high energy, that it is outside of our perceptible visible light."

Nope, sunspots are dark because they are cooler than the surrounding photosphere.

"It means the sun has high solar activity and it results in a stronger magnetosphere on Earth. Lower numbers of sunspots coincide with weaker solar output and a weaker Earth magnetosphere."

Nope. Increased solar wind and CMEs will compress the Earth's magnetosphere.

"To say that solar output doesn't increase when the sun starts blowing out massive high energy holes in its outer layer just seems a little illogical to me. "

That's probably because you don't understand solar dynamics very well. There are lots of videos on Youtube that explain these things since you don't like to read.

"Not only that but its impact changes as its output changes so it is completely illogical to not include them in their models..."

The models work very well actually, without sunspot information.

"instead, we are seeing a resurgence in ice formation in both the poles and Greenland"

Nope. The 2018 ice levels are still lower. There is a small stretch this month of Arctic ice increase which is more than offset by the increasing loss of Antarctic ice. The claimed increase is denier propaganda.

"If you believe that my information is propaganda (which it is, doesn't mean it's bad), then isn't it logical to assume yours might also just be propaganda?"

Nope. Denier propaganda is deliberately false information (bad) with a political agenda behind it. The attempts to accuse scientists in many different fields in many different countries of some massive conspiracy is ridiculous. It is a childish tactic to simply turn the facts around. The carbon tax was not proposed by scientists nor would they receive the monies. It was proposed by the Clinton administration long after AGW had already been accepted. This accusation is in 'flat-Earth' territory and I now seriously doubt your sincerity.

"...but you are basically trying to claim that our grand solar cycles suddenly stopped after the medieval warming. They did not stop and anthropogenic CO2 can absolutely not account for all of our current warming."

This is ridiculous, I never claimed anything of the sort. The solar cycles have continued as they will for billions of years. I am claiming that there is no demonstrated connection between them and the warming we see. CO2 is not the only factor; water vapor, methane, nitrogen oxides, CFCs, deforestation, reduced ice albedo... there are MANY factors. CO2 is the biggest.

"I would say at this point, the burden of proof is on you."

LOL, go ahead and say it, still not true. All you are doing is showing your ignorance of the subject material and unwillingness to bother doing research. Yet you still claim to have figured this out better than the scientists... a-freaking-mazing!

"Every time you ask me to find you peer-reviewed articles I get the sense that you have become stumped."

Nope. It is because I know you will not find it... your claims are wrong. It is to encourage you to do actual research. Googling things like "double peaking grand solar maximum" is not research.

"Also, you will realize how stupid it is to make someone read an entire article just to show you that other scientists do indeed think what I think."

I asked for peer reviewed articles to back up your claims... you gave me WUWT <Major facepalm>. This quote of yours borders on one of the most idiotic things I have read in a long time. I am making you learn, you poor fellow! So sorry you think that's stupid! 

The scientists who wrote the paper (that WUWT is misusing) made no claims what ever in relation to solar cycle effect on climate. They simply came up with a new reconstruction of the sunspot data that can only be estimated (and say they have discovered modes but that is over your head). The paper doesn't help your argument in the SLIGHTEST. The grand maximum is already known to be a somewhat rare event, no one disputes that. The sunspot cycles' relation to climate is correlative at best and already demonstrated NOT to be causal. You have provided ABSOLUTELY NOTHING to suggest otherwise. At this point you have no logical reason to hold on to your misconceptions. If you persist in this nonsense I will take great pleasure in further ridiculing your denier antics.
author: Hank

text:
Tristan
Why are you still pretending? We both know you don't understand this material and that's ok. Admitting that was the first step towards learning. I am not telling you to believe what I say is right... you shouldn't believe someone just because they tell you to. But you are at the point where you should let go of your erroneous belief.

You like graphs... I get it. Pretty pictures are easier to digest than big science words when you don't know what they mean. Do yourself a favor and learn them. Watch reputable videos that explain AGW, not propaganda videos that are deliberately keeping you stupid.

Give up the charade, you aren't fooling anyone.
author: Hank

text:
Hank
I could say the same about you. Just a few responses ago you were kindly asking me "I knew it was about sunspots!! Ok, so what is a 'Peak' and what is the difference between a peak and a double peak?" You are the only one pretending here, Hank. 

I'd love to see you finally refute my main argument:

"We are heading into a glacial period, CO2 levels will drop naturally by as much as 200 PPM for 100,000+ years. If anything, we (and all other life) will be glad we made things a little bit warmer and richer in CO2 if it even makes a difference at all."

The only time you even got close to addressing this argument is when you talked about the runaway greenhouse effect (that I brought up) and how despite CO2 levels and temperatures being nothing special relative to most of Earth's history, it's possible that the rate of increase will cause runaway greenhouse effect. You pulled it out of your ass and had no idea what you were talking about. You seem to at least be able to understand that that is the only way to refute my argument. You've spent this entire time focusing on my weaker claim about solar activity and through all of our subsequent research it turns out you were wrong about that too lol. Solar activity correlates strongly with temperature. The Modern Maximum (1950-2009) solar activity was higher than the three previous solar maxima, it is likely that our current warming can be mostly attributed to solar activity and only partly attributed to anthropogenic CO2. Just because NASA or NOAA decided not to completely discredit themselves by looking at this, doesn't mean it's not true. BUT, even if it's not, you still have to prove to me that 400 PPM causes runaway greenhouse effect to refute my main argument. I think even you realize that it doesn't. The effects of AGW are exaggerated and not nearly as detrimental as you seem to have thought. In fact, it will begin reversing very soon and some data even shows it has already begun reversing, all while oil is not only almost depleted but obsolete, and at the verge of another solar minimum. You have lost this debate, Hank.
author: Tristun Alekzander

text:
LOL, there is no reason at all to 'refute' uneducated denier guesses. You are engaging in fortunetelling, not science. 

I already explained that your 'Runaway Greenhouse' is a straw argument and your claims regarding solar activity have already been proved wrong (by your own references no less!)... you just refuse to accept it. Not my problem if you choose to remain willfully ignorant.

text:
Personally I don't see the fuss with climate change. I believe that it is very real and will bite us in the ass, but the Earth itself will not be harmed in the process. 

Think about it, the same matter has always been on Earth, all climate change is is the redistribution of certain elements that makes it harder for humanity, and some wildlife, to inhabit the planet. When shit hits the fan, humanity will die out but the Earth will restore itself as it always has through an ice age or something along those lines. Then life will come back again as it has before. As for the use of irreversible/forever, these are studies conducted by the very best in the field, and go through rigorous review. text:
My reply to another thread above:

https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases

NOX and Methane are ~15% of GHG combined. Of those, animal agriculture is about 5% and 35% respectively. Growing crops contributes about 75% of the NOX emissions, with all vehicular transport being 5%. Coal mining is about 8% of Methane, and natural gas and petroleum systems account for 31%.

81% of GHG is CO2, and ~75% of that is electricity, transport and industry.

I think it's pretty clear where we should be concentrating. 75% of 81% is a way bigger problem than 75% of 6%. Exchanging fossil fuels for renewables will not only eliminate that 75% of CO2, but also the 39% of Methane from coal and gas/petroleum.

So in both cases, energy and transport VASTLY outweigh the emissions from the animal agriculture sector. What I didn't realise is how bad the NOX emissions are from plant agriculture, and this is legitimately something that we could do better, but it definitely does not help to stop eating meat.

Having said that, I think we should all eat less meat, and better quality produced with better standards. I pay a premium (20-30% I guess) at a butcher that sources responsibly, they can tell me where all the meat comes from and I can check on those producers. As a bonus, it's FRICKIN' DELICIOUS!! I will never go back to supermarket meat, I just eat a little less than I used to.

text:
chem - You're apparently unaware of how Earth's ecosystem is extremely interconnected. There's an absurd number of factors that keep the entire food chain in existence. Obviously there are species that would outlive us, but an Earth that is so badly damaged as to be inhospitable for humans would likely be on such a severe decline that the extinction of all other species would inevitably follow, whether it be hundred or thousands of years later. It would not just "bounce back" as if nothing happened after we've completely ruined the atmosphere, which by the way is the only thing keeping us from looking like every other dead planet. 

In simpler terms: Any man-made changes that are drastic enough to cause our extinction will probably extinct most if not all other species in time. You should study mini ecosystems and how they work. Basically, you mess up one component and you fu*k the whole thing up. Pretty simple concept. That's where we're at right now. We're messing up the atmosphere, which is THE main component that you can't just slap a band-aid on or do without. You can't just assume it will start fixing itself because we're gone, it will just continue on the same detrimental path that led humans to extinction, which eventually would extinct everything else. Make sense?

author: chem

text:
Man, you have a very elementary understanding of how Earth's climate works AND what it would take to render humans extinct, especially given our current technology, underground bunkers, the ability to create artificial environments, indoor food growing... science. Ya know, things that cockroaches don't have. So, yeah if we were brought to complete extinction despite all of our cerebral advantages, then yes the outlook would be rather bleak for other species, none of which would even know what the hell is going on let alone have the ability to prepare. Now, you mentioned the dinosaurs -- planets survive asteroid strikes. In fact, asteroid strikes are relatively common in cosmic terms. Rapid artificial pollution is a much worse and far more unnatural problem, for which there is no precedence. 

Right now humans are setting off a CHAIN REACTION in the atmosphere via rapid artificial pollution, which A) the Earth has never encountered -- slow and gradual climate change, yes, but not extreme adjustments in the course of a century like what we've caused since beginning of the Industrial era, AND B) Is threatening to ruin not only the atmosphere but also the oceans, oxygen levels, temperatures... pretty much everything required for any form of life. The keyword that you might be missing is CHAIN REACTION, so that explains why you can't understand how the atmosphere would continue to deteriorate after we're gone.

text:
A common fallacy.   People need to realise that our society (regardless of widespread dietary proclivities...) will  continue to cause global warming.    To change from a carnivorous to herbiferous diet will still require mass industrialisation.   Thus, will still generate heat as well as GHG emissions.   
.
The underlying cause being simply TOO MANY PEOPLE.   We are heading towards population overshoot.   
.
And no,   livestock agrigulture, though a serious contributor to atmospheric GHG emissions, is not the largest contributor.   That forcing belongs to industrial civilisation and a large chunk of that is the military industrial complex.    
.
The point is so often missed, though Simon did  mention it...   Global warming is  LOCKED IN for the forseeable future.   So even if, all humans ceased producing CO2 (et al) and turned vegan this evening, it would not make one jot of difference to global warming.    This is due to the latent effect of GHG molecules in the atmosphere.  
.
Also, one particular GHG - Methane (CH4), which is yet another sequestered carbon deposit (a fossil fuel...), has been kept sequestered by a relatively stable climatic period (the 18 odd thousand years up to the industrial revoloution...).   
.
CH4 can only be stored under extreme pressure and at sub zero temperatures.   Here the CH4 molecules are locked within 'cages' of frozen H2O molecules - ice.   These cages are called 'clathrates'  or 'hydrates'.    They exist naturally all over the planet.  Locked up in the sediments of the planet's oceans.   Where they remain sequestered by the extreme pressures and sub-zero temperatures that are prevalent at extreme depths of all the major oceans.   
.
However,   CH4 clathrates also exist in large quantities in the more shallow regions of our oceans, essentially the continental shelves surrounding each continent.    Any release of CH4 from deep clathrate deposits, would not reach the atmosphere in large quantites, due to absorption/assimilation of CH4 in the ocean water column.   Whereas clathrates thawing in shallow regions, have less of a water column (a difference, on average of around 14 thousand feet....).   Thus more CH4 can and is reaching the atmosphere.   
.
Currently,  the East Siberian Sea, continental shelf, the region of the Arctic ocean that is directly north of eastern Russia (Siberia) is outgassing methane.   This is increasing and is directely related to a warming Arctic ocean.   CH4 is also outgassing from the Canadian shelf and of course all across the northern tundra regions (Canada, Scandinavia and Siberia).   Here the clathrates that were hitherto locked up in deep permafrost, which of course is now thawing, as part of the retreating cryosphere (the planet's 'icy' regions -  Ice Sheets - Greenland, East and West Antarctica -  Sub tropical glaciers - Alaska, The Rockies, The Andes, The Alps, The Himalayas, Kamchatkan peninsular and the odd high mountains elsewhere -  Sea Ice - Arctic and Antarctica - Permafrost regions - Tundra), all in retreat, due to global warming.    
.
The release of CH4 is of extreme concern and is one of countless ' positive feedback loops'  triggered by GW.    
.
CH4 - molecule for molecule is around 100 times more potent as a greehouse gas (GHG) than that of CO2.   The concern is that it is estimated that around 500 GIGAtons of CH4 exist in the ESS (East Siberian Shelf) alone...   That with the continual increase in Arctice oceanic temperatures, a large outgassing may occur.   This is coloquially termed - a 'Clathrate Burp/bomb/gun'  event.   Such an event, will accelerate the ongoing GW.   
.
None of this was mentioned in this video because CO2 emissions still remain the primary driver for global warming.   Also there is a MSM clampdown on information regarding the Arctic CH4 emissions....   But the research is not new and is readily available to anyone who wishes to dig further.   
.
The point is, that global warming is locked in.   There is no feasible technology that can mitigate this process.  Nor will any personal endeavour make one jot of difference.    We started the snowball...  Now it is out of control.
.
Running in paralell to global warming/climate change is the ongoing Sixth Mass Extinction.   This too, was triggered by the rise of human civilisation.   Given that humans would not readilly agree to curb population, nor reduce or abolish industry - a return to medieval living -  Both the MEE VI  and global warming will continue apace. 
.
The upshot is - the EXTINCTION of all major species on this planet, which includes all vertebrates and by physical definition - homo sapiens-sapiens.   
.
I have only mentioned TWO vectors here -  Global warming due to GHG emissions (CO2/CH4/NO2/H2O) and sequestered carbon release (CH4).  The reality is far worse - for there are those countless self-reinforcing feedback loops, as well as other anthropogenic vectors -  Radionuclides (nuclear power and weapons...), which is the ionising radiation emtted by the nuclear process  and extremely lethal to life...  Toxins - plastics, chemicals, pesticides, mineral processing etc...  And the ongoing destructive processes - deforestation,  mass habitat loss mining and drilling, fracking, dam building, urban growth, the depletion of the planets FINITE resources and of course - fisheries and (MONO)AGRICULTURE...  
.
Not to mention the planet's own natural processes of tectonics, volcanism, ocean circulation etc...  In fact the latter is being seriously affected by global warming as the oceans are the primary absorber of CO2, which in turn increases the mass of the oceans and decreases the pH levels - hence that oceans are turning acidic, with subsequent  habitat loss and species extinction.   The increase in mass, of the oceans, together with the thawing of all land-borne ice - deglaciation - causing  higher global sea levels, again resulting in habitat loss and species extinction.   
.
Also Oxygen levels (atmospheric and marine) have decreased over recent decades.  Anoxic conditions (depleted O2) are not conducive to the continual survival of O2 breathing/processing organisms...  
.
All this is accelerating at a pace that even our science cannot grasp.   Last week, a report was published that shows that Antarctica, hitherto regarded as the region of the cryosphere that was the slowest to be shedding ice mass, has overtaken Greenland as being the fastest contributor to rising oceanic sea levels...  This can only happen on planet that is undergoing accelerated global warming.  
.
Humans have around fifty years tops.   Homo sapiens-sapiens, along with most other species, will become extinct before the close of this century.   If not far sooner...    And no one has mentioned the wildcard - war.   
.

text:
https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases

NOX and Methane are ~15% of GHG combined. Of those, animal agriculture is about 5% and 35% respectively. Growing crops contributes about 75% of the NOX emissions, with all vehicular transport being 5%. Coal mining is about 8% of Methane, and natural gas and petroleum systems account for 31%.

81% of GHG is CO2, and ~75% of that is electricity, transport and industry.

I think it's pretty clear where we should be concentrating. 75% of 81% is a way bigger problem than 75% of 6%. Exchanging fossil fuels for renewables will not only eliminate that 75% of CO2, but also the 39% of Methane from coal and gas/petroleum.

So in both cases, energy and transport VASTLY outweigh the emissions from the animal agriculture sector. What I didn't realise is how bad the NOX emissions are from plant agriculture, and this is legitimately something that we could do better, but it definitely does not help to stop eating meat.

Having said that, I think we should all eat less meat, and better quality produced with better standards. I pay a premium (20-30% I guess) at a butcher that sources responsibly, they can tell me where all the meat comes from and I can check on those producers. As a bonus, it's FRICKIN' DELICIOUS!! I will never go back to supermarket meat, I just eat a little less than I used to.

author: Wobbly Bit

text:
good question.
The soils are the carbon sink. The herbivores mediate nutrient cycling via digestion of cellulose containing materials. so basically plant grows putting out exudates into the soil which contain carbon and facilitate the population growth of microbiota which use soil parent mineral material and photosynthates leached out by the plant via its root system to increase soil carbon.  the plants indirectly and directly benefit from this microbial population via the minerals they make bioavailable from unavailable soil parent material (basically weathered down rocks that form sand silt and clay).

 however the important part Is grasslands which dump an enormous amount of carbon into the soil via aforementioned process when reaching maturity become lignified and the process(carbon cycling) slows down significantly (the plant is worried about seed production for the Next Generation not vegetative growth). 

 enter the herbivores.

Herbivores prune down the grassland and predigest  the hard to break down cellulose for insects and micro fauna to turn the dung into a stable form of carbon such as Olmec, fulvic or humic acids. This eventually becomes a positive feedback loop and soil carbon begins to build  to enormous levels such as what can be seen in the American Bread Basket where the Bison once roamed.

text:
+Ken Van de Burgt
Yeah you just repeated what I said without my paradoxical conclusion. Here's my argument:
1) As CO2 levels increase, temperature also increases.
2) As temperature increases, sea temperature increases (duh).
3) As sea temperature increases, CO2 dissolution rates decrease.
4) As CO2 dissolution rates decrease, CO2 levels increase.

Do you not see the contradiction here?
By that logic, CO2 levels would NEVER be able to decrease. Because as soon as there's an increase for whatever reason, that amplifies the effects and makes it increase MORE and MORE! That means CO2 levels must have been increasing at an exponential rate throughout all of history!!! Or in other words, it'd be impossible for CO2 levels to be "stable". 
It's like if you were to stand a long stick perfectly straight up and let it go, it might stay up for a while, but as soon as it starts to lean even the slightest bit, that will cause it to lean even more, which will make it lean EVEN MORE etc. etc. and so the falling of the stick is IRREVERSIBLE even naturally!

author: Zacharie Etienne

text:
+Zoe Phin
No it's certainly possible CO2 has a positive feedback loop, but if that were true then the planet should have been very slowly yet exponentially heating up ever since it's creation well before humans - which is not the case.

The reason a feedback loop doesn't violate the conservation of energy is because extra CO2 doesn't produce energy, it traps more of the sun's energy. 
What happens is the suns rays enter our atmosphere, hit the earth and bounce off. But what CO2 does is once the light rays go through, and bounce off the earth, they sort of "bounce back" off the CO2 back down to earth, like 2 mirrors facing each other. And the more CO2, the more efficiently the mirrors reflect. 
So it's not a perpetual motion machine scenario, it's just stopping the Earth from radiating so much of it's energy into space, like an oven, hence the warming.

text:
I should mention I received a reply from Simon Clark himself on another comment thread here. Since he's the go to man, figured I should repost his reply and mine for honesty's sake.

Simon Clark
Because it's not that simple - there are both positive and negative feedback loops. For example more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more photosynthesis from plants -> less CO2. But then at the same time more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more water vapour absorbing thermal wavelengths of radiation -> warmer planet. There are feedback loops all over the place, hence the need for complicated models!

Zacharie Etienne
Holy shit a reply from the man himself!!
If there are both positive and negative feedback loops - that only means they would either cancel each other out, or they average out into one positive feedback loop, or a negative one. 
If it's positive or negative, the Earth would've been screwed from the get go regardless of humans.
Therefore, when there's no human input, the Earth's CO2 levels must be self correcting , i.e. when CO2 levels are too high, the negative feedback loops have more punch, and when CO2 is too low, the positive feedback loops win over. Only this scenario would create an equilibrium allowing CO2 levels to remain stable over time, any other scenario would have CO2 levels spiral exponentially to either 0 or infinity due to effects of chaos.

And if that's the case, then while an additional human input of CO2 will produce a temporary rise in temperature, eventually we will again find a natural equilibrium, because although we've increased the CO2 levels, because we've done that, the net negative feedback loops will become more pronounced, while the net positive feedback loops will diminish, and (as long as human CO2 input is constant), they'll be a point where the loops once again reach equilibrium.

I can make an analogy with air resistance vs gravity. As you know, falling objects have air resistance, and the faster the velocity, the more air resistance. Therefore this is an example of a negative feedback loop, because if a falling object momentarily goes faster than the terminal velocity where air resistance and gravity are in equilibrium, then the object slows back down to terminal velocity. Likewise, if the object momentarily goes slower than the terminal velocity, gravity win over the air resistance, creating a positive feedback loop, and making the object speed back to terminal velocity. Any other universe where the object didn't have a positive feedback loop when going to slow AND a negative feedback loop when going to fast, would inevitably result in the object either coming to a complete stop or speeding up indefinitely. 

Now in this analogy, human input of CO2 is equivalent to reducing the object's surface area. By doing so, you'll have decreased the force of air resistance, making the object fall faster/have a higher terminal velocity. But the same positive/negative feedback loops apply, so although the object will temporarily fall faster, it will inevitably reach a new terminal velocity again, where the feedback loops cancel out and it's all ok.

text:
There is global warming. Its not being caused by increasing CO2. Its the suns activity that causes phases of warming and cooling in our climate.

Rising CO2 levels do not increase global temperature very much ... Total CO2 contributes about 3.5w/m^2 max which is noise compared to the 1360 w/m^2 of solar irradiance. CO2 is a greenhouse gas. It absorbs long wave radiation 2.7, 4.3, and 15 um. So does water vapor. The earth radiates heat as a blackbody.  The greenhouse effect of CO2 is logarithmic. Most of the warming effect occurs in the first 200 ppm. At the current 410 ppm the absorption spectrum is saturated; there is not an infinite amount of heat available to be absorbed. Even if you double or triple CO2 you will only get perhaps 0.1C more warming due to absorption at the boundaries of the spectrum. 

It is estimated that the increased CO2 has caused an increase of 1.7 w/m^2 to total 3.5 in the radiation balance ... but this ignores the warming effect that was already being caused by water vapor. 

Here is a chart showing atmospheric transmission spectrum.
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Atmospheric_Transmission.png

Humans do not produce more CO2 than they take in. Humans consume food that has absorbed CO2 from the atmosphere to grow ... so its zero sum.

text: Ken Van de Burgt  Just FYI  The reason for that phenomen is known.  Deep ice cores  from the Antarctic French Dome C station and the Russian Vostok station span some 800,000 years. During that period there have been eight glacial advance and retreat cycles of about 100,000 years each. The cycles are being driven by the Milankovitch forcings  of Earth orbital excentricity, wobble, and axial tilt. Those forcings were  NOT regulated by atmospheric CO2 concentrations. During the Pleistocene Epoch, atmospheric CO2  averaged about 180ppm during glacial advances and 280ppm during glacial retreats,  always lagging the celestial forcings.  Now, that trend is being reversed by humans burning millions of years worth of carbon sequestered in the Earth's crust into the atmosphere within the about 250 year span of the Industrial Revolution plus cattle feedlot methane, Arctic tundra melting and sea floor methane clathrate sublimation, and some nitrogen compounds being released into the atmosphere. Sea warming has increased the amount of atmospheric water vapor, itself a potent greenhouse gas. IF you go to my, not for profit, web site  www,ciclicoahuila.com  you will see side by side images of the Earth showing a relatively clear sky in 1972 and a hazy, carbon polluted, sky in 2017.   Currently, atmospheric CO2 concentration is about 410ppm and rising.  !Saludos desde Mexico!  old geologist  .' )

text: Kevin Richards RPM Vocal Studio From what I understand, scientists HAVE taken into account solar radiation, the oceans and water vapor. The issue is that our planet's temperature is rising at an UNPRECEDENTED rate. This rise in temperature has not been seen anywhere else in the Earth's history. Yes, solar radiation and the oceans and water vapor HAVE contributed to the rise in temperature in the past and continue, but the rise that we are seeing in the present is being pushed by SOMETHING ELSE, otherwise our current warming would line up with the warming from centuries and millennia past.  CO2 can both contribute to AND is a side effect of global warming. It contributes to global warming by trapping some of the Earth's heat. It's also a side effect because the warmer the Earth gets, the more CO2 in the ground and ice gets released. Also, I've never seen a climate scientist suggest that we get rid of all CO2 on the Earth. The issue is that our level of CO2 is out of balance, because we keep injecting it into the air from the fossil fuels we dug up underneath the ground. If you pump up a closed fish tank full of water, eventually the tank will crack. The solution obviously isn't to remove all the water because the fish would die, but to keep the water at a reasonable amount.

text:
He knows that his only alternative is to become a con artist. Here is why:
Earth radiates at peak wavelength of 10 microns which corresponds to 59 degrees F, which is the average temperature of our planet. Most of this radiated energy( about 63 % of the total) is centered about 10 microns and within a couple of microns above and below 10 microns. That means whatever is absorbing the majority of the infrared radiated by Earth should have an peak absorption in the 8- 12 micron bandwidth.
 CO2 absorbs strongly at 2.7, 4.3, and 15 microns. Most gases including CO2 all absorb in very narrow bands around their peaks, no more than 2 microns on either side of the peak. This means that CO2 is absorbing only very negligible amounts of energy from the Earth. Coupled with that and the fact that Earth is not even close to being a perfect blackbody radiator(a perfect blackbody radiator does not exist in nature).


 The Earth is at best radiating with an emissivity of ..8 to .9. This means that the radiated energy of the Earth's surface is a smaller percentage of the total infrared held by the surface of the Earth. Furthermore, when CO2 absorbs a photon it vibrates over a period of time in the microsecond time range and then emits a different wavelength that is not in the CO2 absorption band. That photon has less than a 50% chance of being reabsorbed by the Earth since CO2 emits in a solid angle in all directions which includes back into space. 


What all this boils down to is that 1 molecule of CO2 is absorbing such extremely small amounts infrared that it's vibrations would be completely incapable of heating even a few molecules( say 4-5 molecules) of N2 and O2 around it to a temperature of even a fraction of a degree, let alone the 2500 molecules that surround it.
